paragraphs.content: Ὅτι μὲν οὖν ἐκ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ τὰ μὲν ζώων σώματα κέκραται, καὶ ὡς οὐκ ἴση πάντων ἐστὶν ἐν τῇ κράσει μοῖρα, παλαιοῖς ἀνδράσιν ἱκανῶς ἀποδέδεικται, φιλοσόφων τε καὶ ἰατρῶν τοῖς ἀρίστοις· εἴρηται δὲ καὶ πρὸς ἡμῶν ὑπὲρ αὐτῶν τὰ εἰκότα δι’ ἑτέρου γράμματος, ἐν ᾧ περὶ τῶν καθ’ Ἱπποκράτην στοιχείων ἐσκοπούμεθα. νυνὶ δὲ, ὅπερ ἐστὶν ἐφεξῆς ἐκείνῳ, τῶν κράσεων ἁπάσας ἐξευρεῖν τὰς διαφορὰς, ὁπόσαι τέ εἰσι καὶ ὁποῖαι, κατ’ εἴδη τε καὶ γένη διαιρούμενος, ἐν τῷδε τῷ γράμματι δίειμι, τὴν ἀρχὴν ἀπὸ τῆς τῶν ὀνομάτων ἐξηγήσεως ποιησάμενος. ἐπειδὰν μὲν γὰρ ἐκ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ κεκρᾶσθαι λέγωσι τὰ σώματα, τῶν ἄκρως τοιούτων ἀκούειν φασὶ χρῆναι, τοῦτ’ ἔστι τῶν στοιχείων αὐτῶν, ἀέρος, καὶ πυρὸς, καὶ ὕδατος, καὶ γῆς. ἐπειδὰν δὲ ζῶον, ἢ φυτὸν, ἢ θερμὸν, ἢ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ξηρὸν, ἢ ὑγρὸν, οὐκέθ’ ὡσαύτως. οὐδὲ γὰρ δύνασθαι ζῶον οὐδὲν οὔτ’ ἄκρως θερμὸν ὑπάρχειν, ὡς πῦρ, οὔτ’ ἄκροις ὑγρὸν, ὡς ὕδωρ· ὡσαύτως δὲ οὐδὲ ψυχρὸν ἢ ξηρὸν ἐσχάτως· ἀλλ’ ἀπὸ τοῦ πλεονεκτοῦντος ἐν τῇ κράσει γίνεσθαι τὰς προσηγορίας, ὑγρὸν μὲν καλούντων ἡμῶν, ἐν ᾧ πλείονος ὑγρότητός ἐστι μοῖρα, ξηρὸν δὲ, ἐν ᾧ ξηρότητος· οὕτω δὲ καὶ θερμὸν μὲν, ἐν ᾧ τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ πλεονεκτεῖ, ψυχρὸν δὲ, ἐν ᾧ τὸ ψυχρὸν τοῦ θερμοῦ. αὕτη μὲν τῶν ὀνομάτων χρῆσις.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
That the bodies of animals are composed from the hot and the cold and the dry and the wet, and that the share of each is not equal in the mixture [krāsis, “blend/temperament”], has been adequately demonstrated by the ancients, the best among both philosophers and physicians; and I too have set forth the probable considerations on these matters in another treatise, in which we examined the elements according to Hippocrates.

Now, what follows upon that, I shall set out in this present treatise: to discover all the differences of mixtures—how many they are and of what sort—dividing them by species and by genus, beginning with an explanation of the terms.

For whenever they say that bodies are mixed from the hot and the cold and the dry and the wet, they say one must understand by these the things that are such in the extreme, that is, the elements [stoicheia] themselves—air, fire, water, and earth. But whenever they speak of an animal, or a plant, or [of something as] hot, or cold, or dry, or wet, it is not in the same way. For no living creature can exist that is extreme in heat, like fire, or extreme in wetness, like water; and likewise neither can it be utterly cold or dry. Rather, the designations arise from that which predominates in the mixture: we call “wet” that in which there is a greater share of wetness, and “dry” that in which there is [a greater share] of dryness; and likewise “hot” that in which the hot prevails over the cold, and “cold” that in which the cold prevails over the hot. This, then, is the usage of the terms.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is my translation of the Greek paragraph:

It has been sufficiently demonstrated by ancient authorities - the best among both philosophers and physicians - that the bodies of living creatures are composed of a mixture of hot, cold, dry, and moist, and that the proportion in the mixture is not equal for all beings. We have also discussed these matters appropriately in another treatise, where we examined the elements according to Hippocrates. But now, in this present work, which follows that one, I shall examine all the different types of mixtures [krases], both how many there are and what they are like, dividing them by species and genera, beginning first with an explanation of terms. For when they say that bodies are mixed from hot, cold, dry, and moist, they claim one must understand these in their extreme forms, that is, as the elements themselves - air, fire, water, and earth. However, when speaking of a living creature or plant as hot, cold, dry, or moist, it is not meant in the same way. For no living creature can be extremely hot like fire, nor extremely moist like water; likewise, neither extremely cold nor extremely dry. Rather, these terms are applied based on what predominates in the mixture, with us calling 'moist' that in which the portion of moisture is greater, and 'dry' that in which dryness predominates. Similarly, we call 'hot' that in which heat exceeds cold, and 'cold' that in which cold exceeds heat. This is how these terms are used.

[Note: "krases" refers to the Greek medical concept of bodily mixtures or temperaments]
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
That the bodies of animals are blended [lit. mixed] from the hot, the cold, the dry, and the wet, and that the proportion of each quality is not equal in this mixture [Gr. *krasis*], has been sufficiently demonstrated by the ancients—by the best of the philosophers and physicians. The relevant points concerning these matters have also been stated by us in a separate work, in which we examined the elements according to Hippocrates. But now, in this present work, which follows on from that one, I shall proceed to discover all the differences among the temperaments [Gr. *kraseis*]—how many and of what kind they are—dividing them by species and genera, beginning with an explanation of the terms.

For whenever they say that bodies are blended from the hot, the cold, the dry, and the wet, they mean, it is said, that we should understand this to refer to these qualities in their absolute form, that is, the elements themselves: air, fire, water, and earth. But when they call an animal or a plant hot, or cold, or dry, or wet, it is no longer in the same sense. For no animal can exist in a state of extreme heat, like fire, or extreme wetness, like water; and likewise, it cannot be cold or dry to the utmost degree. Rather, the designations arise from the predominant quality in the temperament, so that we call 'wet' that in which the share of wetness is greater, and 'dry' that in which the share of dryness is greater; and in the same way, 'hot' is that in which the hot prevails over the cold, and 'cold' is that in which the cold prevails over the hot. Such, then, is the usage of these terms.

paragraphs.content: Ὥρα δ’ ἂν εἴη λέγειν ἤδη καὶ περὶ τῶν κράσεων αὐτῶν. ἡ μὲν δὴ πλείστη δόξα τῶν ἐπιφανεστάτων ἰατρῶν τε καὶ φιλοσόφων, ὑγρὰν εἶναι καὶ θερμὴν κρᾶσιν, ἑτέραν τῆς ὑγρᾶς καὶ ψυχρᾶς, καὶ τρίτην ἐπὶ ταύταις τὴν ξηρὰν καὶ ψυχρὰν, ἑτέραν τῆς ξηρᾶς τε ἅμα καὶ θερμῆς. ἔνιοι δ’ ἐξ αὐτῶν ὑγρὰν μέν τινα καὶ ψυχρὰν ἅμα κρᾶσιν ὑπάρχειν φασὶ, θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰν ἑτέραν· οὐ μὴν οὔτε τὴν ὑγρὰν ἅμα καὶ θερμὴν, οὔτε τὴν ψυχρὰν ἅμα καὶ ξηράν. οὐ γὰρ ἐγχωρεῖν οὔθ’ ὑγρότητα πλεονεκτούσῃ θερμότητι συνδραμεῖν, οὔτε ξηρότητα ψυχρότητι. δαπανᾶσθαι μὲν γὰρ ὑπὸ τοῦ θερμοῦ κρατοῦντος τὴν ὑγρότητα, καὶ οὕτως θερμὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν γίνεσθαι τὸ σῶμα, μένειν δὲ ἄπεπτόν τε καὶ ἀκατέργαστον, ἐν οἶς ἂν σώμασιν ἀῤῥωστῇ τὸ θερμὸν, ὥστ’ ἀναγκαῖον εἶναι, θερμότητος μὲν ἐπικρατούσης, ἕπεσθαι ξηρότητα, ψυχρότητος δὲ πλεονεκτούσης, ἀκολουθεῖν ὑγρότητα. οὗτοι μὲν οὖν κατὰ τάδε πεπείκασι σφᾶς αὐτοὺς, ὡς δύο εἰσὶ πᾶσαι τῶν κράσεων αἱ διαφοραί. ὅσοι δὲ τέτταρας εἶναι νομίζουσι, διχῶς τούτοις ἀντιλέγουσιν· ἔνιοι μὲν εὐθὺς τὸ πρῶτον ἀξίωμα μὴ συγχωροῦντες, ὡς ἐξικμάζεσθαι τὴν ὑγρότητα πρὸς τοῦ θερμοῦ κρατοῦντος ἀναγκαῖόν ἐστιν· ἔνιοι δὲ τοῦτο μὲν συγχωροῦσιν, ἀμφισβητοῦσι δὲ ἑτέρως. οἱ μὲν δὴ πρῶτοι τοῦ θερμοῦ μὲν ἔργον εἶναί φασι τὸ θερμαίνειν, ὥσπερ καὶ τοῦ ψυχροῦ τὸ ψύχειν, τοῦ ξηροῦ δ’ αὖ τὸ ξηραίνειν, ὥσπερ καὶ τοῦ ὑγροῦ τὸ ὑγραίνειν. καὶ διὰ τοῦτο, ὅσα μὲν σώματα θερμὰ τὴν φύσιν ἐστὶν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰ, καθάπερ τὸ πῦρ, ᾗ μὲν θερμὰ, θερμαίνει, ᾗ δὲ ξηρὰ, ξηραίνει.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
It would now be time to speak also about their mixtures [kraseis: combinations of qualities]. The prevailing opinion among the most eminent physicians and philosophers is that there is a hot-and-wet mixture, another which is wet-and-cold, and, in addition to these, a third which is dry-and-cold, and another which is dry-and-hot.

Some of them, however, say that there exists a mixture that is at once wet and cold, and another that is at once hot and dry, but not one that is at once wet and hot, nor one that is at once cold and dry. For it is not possible, they say, for moisture to accompany heat when it predominates, nor for dryness to accompany cold. For
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the passage:

It would now be time to speak about the mixtures [krases/temperaments] themselves. The predominant opinion among the most distinguished physicians and philosophers is that there exists a wet and hot mixture, distinct from the wet and cold one, and a third in addition to these that is dry and cold, different from one that is both dry and hot. Some among them say that there exists a mixture that is both wet and cold, and another that is hot and dry; however, they deny both the wet and hot mixture, and the cold and dry one. For they claim it is impossible for wetness to combine with predominant heat, or dryness with cold. For moisture is consumed by dominant heat, and thus the body becomes both hot and dry, while in bodies where heat is weak, it remains undigested and unprocessed, so that necessarily, when heat predominates, dryness follows, and when cold prevails, wetness follows. These thinkers have thus convinced themselves that there are only two distinct types of mixtures in total. But those who believe there are four oppose them in two ways: some immediately reject the first axiom that moisture must necessarily be dried out by dominant heat; while others concede this point but dispute differently. The first group says that the function of heat is to heat, just as that of cold is to cool, and that of dry is to dry, just as that of wet is to moisten. And for this reason, bodies that are by nature both hot and dry, like fire, heat insofar as they are hot, and dry insofar as they are dry.

[Note: "krasis" (κρᾶσις) refers to the mixture or blending of elemental qualities in ancient medical and philosophical theory]
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
Now would be the time to speak of the temperaments [Greek: *kraseis*, literally 'mixtures'] themselves. The prevailing opinion, then, of the most eminent physicians and philosophers, is that there is a moist and hot temperament, another that is moist and cold, a third in addition to these that is dry and cold, and a fourth that is at once dry and hot.

Some of them, however, state that a temperament that is at once moist and cold exists, and another that is at once hot and dry; but not, they say, one that is at once moist and hot, nor one that is at once cold and dry. For, they argue, it is not possible for moisture to combine with a predominant heat, nor for dryness to combine with coldness. For moisture, they say, is consumed by the dominant heat, and so the body becomes at once hot and dry; whereas in whatever bodies the innate heat is weak, matter remains undigested and unprocessed, so that it is

paragraphs.content: ὅσα δ’ ὑγρὰ καὶ θερμὰ, καθάπερ ὕδωρ θερμὸν, ὑγραίνειν ταῦτα καὶ θερμαίνειν πέφυκεν ἀεὶ, ἓν ἑκατέρας κᾀνταῦθα ποιότητος ἔργον ἐχούσης ἀχώριστον. οὐκ οὖν συγχωροῦσιν, εἴ τι θερμαῖνόν ἐστιν, εὐθὺς τοῦτο καὶ ξηραίνειν· ἀλλ’ εἰ μὲν ὑγρότης προσείη τῇ θερμότητι, θερμαίνειν ἅμα καὶ ὑγραίνειν, ὥσπερ τὰ λουτρὰ τῶν γλυκέων ὑδάτων· εἰ δ’, ὥσπερ θερμὸν, οὕτω καὶ ξηρὸν εἴη, καθάπερ τὸ πῦρ, οὐ θερμαίνειν μόνον, ἀλλὰ καὶ ξηραίνειν εὐθὺς, οὐκ ἐκ τῆς θερμότητος τοῦτο λαβὸν, ἀλλ’ ἐκ τῆς συνούσης αὐτῇ ξηρότητος. ὑπομιμνήσκουσι δ’ ἐνταῦθα τῶν ἐν ἡλίῳ θερινῷ διατριψάντων ἐπιπλέον, εἶθ’, ὡς εἰκὸς, αὐανθέντων, ὅλον τε τὸ σῶμα καὶ ξηρὸν καὶ αὐχμηρὸν ἐχόντων, καὶ διψώντων οὐκ ἀνεκτῶς.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Whatever things are moist and hot—like hot water—are by nature always fitted both to moisten and to heat, each quality having here too its own inseparable operation. They therefore do not allow that, if something heats, it immediately also dries; rather, if moisture is added to the heat, it heats and moistens at the same time, as do the baths of fresh water [i.e., non-saline]. But if, being hot, it is also dry, like fire, it not only heats but at once dries as well—deriving this not from its heat, but from the dryness that accompanies it. They remind one here of people who have spent too long in the summer sun and then, as is likely, have become parched, their whole body being both dry and rough [auchnēros: parched/rough], and suffering an intolerable thirst.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

"Whatever substances are both wet and hot, like hot water, are naturally disposed to both moisten and heat continuously, with each quality here too having its own inseparable effect. Therefore, they do not concede that if something is heating, it must immediately also be drying; rather, if wetness is present along with heat, it both heats and moistens simultaneously, as in the case of baths of fresh water. But if something is dry as well as hot, like fire, it not only heats but also immediately dries, deriving this effect not from its heat but from the dryness that accompanies it. They remind us here of those who spend too much time in the summer sun, and then, as one would expect, become parched, having their whole body both dry and dusty [or withered], and suffering from unbearable thirst."

[Note: "αὐχμηρὸν" (dusty/withered) carries connotations of both physical dryness and a weathered, parched quality that is difficult to capture in a single English word.]

The text appears to be discussing the relationship between heat, moisture, and dryness in a medical or natural philosophical context, likely from a work dealing with elemental qualities and their effects on the body.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ἴασιν γὰρ αὐτοῖς εἶναί φασιν ἑτοίμην τε καὶ ῥᾴστην, οὐκ εἰ πίοιεν μόνον, ἀλλὰ εἰ καὶ λούσαιντο θερμοῖς ὕδασι καὶ γλυκέσιν, ὡς τῆς ὑγρότητος, εἴτε μετὰ ψυχρότητος, εἴτε μετὰ θερμότητος εἴη, τὸ ἑαυτῆς δρᾷν δυναμένης, ὑγραίνειν γὰρ τὰ πλησιάζοντα. κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν λόγον φασὶ καὶ τὴν ξηρότητα ξηραίνειν ἀεί. τὸν γοῦν βοῤῥᾶν, ξηρὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν ἄνεμον τυγχάνοντα, ξηραίνειν ἅπαντα καὶ ψύχειν. καὶ τοῦτ’ εἶναι τὸ πρὸς Ὁμήρου λεγόμενον, Ὡς δ’ ὅτ’ ὀπωρινὸς βορέης νεοαρδέ’ ἀλωὴν Αἶψα ξηραίνει. Κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον καὶ τὸν τοῦ μήκωνος ὀπὸν καὶ ἄλλα μυρία φάρμακα ξηραίνειν ἅμα καὶ ψύχειν.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For they say that there is for them a cure both ready to hand and very easy—not only if they should drink, but also if they should bathe in warm and “sweet” waters [i.e., fresh, non-salty]—on the grounds that moisture, whether accompanied by cold or by heat, is able to perform its own proper function, for it moistens whatever is near it. And on the same principle they say that dryness too always dries. For instance, the North Wind, being in fact a dry and cold wind, dries everything and cools. And this, they say, is what is said by Homer: “As when the autumnal Boreas swiftly dries a freshly watered threshing-floor.” Likewise, on the same pattern, the juice [opos: latex] of the poppy [mēkōn] and countless other drugs dry and cool at the same time.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

"For they say there is a ready and very easy cure for them, not only if they drink, but also if they bathe in warm and fresh waters, since moisture - whether accompanied by coldness or warmth - is able to exert its own effect, for it moistens things that come near it. Following the same reasoning, they say that dryness always causes drying. Thus the North Wind [Boreas], being a dry and cold wind, dries and cools everything. And this is what is spoken of by Homer: 'As when the autumn North Wind quickly dries a newly-watered field.' In the same way, they say that the juice of the poppy [opium] and countless other medicines both dry and cool."

[Notes:
- "βοῤῥᾶν" (Boreas) is the personified North Wind in Greek mythology
- "μήκωνος ὀπὸν" literally "juice of the poppy" refers to opium
- The Homer quote is from Iliad 21.346-347]

The translation maintains the medical/philosophical terminology while preserving the argumentative structure of the original Greek, which discusses the properties of moisture and dryness, using both natural and medicinal examples.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: For they say that a ready and very easy cure is available to them, not only if they drink, but also if they bathe in warm and fresh [lit. sweet] waters, on the grounds that moisture—whether it be combined with coldness or with hotness—is able to perform its own function, for it moistens whatever it approaches. And according to the same principle, they say that dryness, too, always dries. The north wind, for instance, being a dry and cold wind, dries and cools all things. And this, they say, is what is meant by Homer: "As when the autumn north wind swiftly dries a newly watered threshing-floor." And in the same way, poppy juice and countless other drugs both dry and cool at the same time.

paragraphs.content: ὥστ’ οὐκ ἀναγκαῖον, οὔτ’ εἴ τι ψυχρὸν, εὐθὺς τοῦτο καὶ ὑγρὸν ὑπάρχειν, οὔτ’, εἴ τι θερμὸν, εὐθὺς καὶ ξηρόν· οὔκουν οὐδὲ τὴν θερμὴν κρᾶσιν ἐξ ἀνάγκης εἶναι καὶ ξηρὰν, ἀλλὰ δύνασθαί ποτε τὸ μὲν θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ πλεονεκτεῖν ἐν τῇ κράσει τοῦ ζώου, τὸ δ’ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ. καὶ γὰρ δὴ καὶ τὴν γένεσιν, καὶ τὴν ἀλλοίωσιν, καὶ τὴν μεταβολὴν ἐκ τῶν ἐναντίων εἰς τὰ ἐναντία γίνεσθαι. τίς γὰρ οὖν εἰπὼν, ὅτι τὸ λευκὸν ἠλλοιώθη τε καὶ μετέβαλεν, ἐγένετο γὰρ θερμὸν, οὐκ ἂν εἴη καταγέλαστος; ἐπιζητεῖ γὰρ ὁ λόγος, οὐ τὴν κατὰ ψυχρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἀντίθεσιν, ἀλλὰ τὴν κατὰ τὸ χρῶμα μεταβολήν· μεταβάλλει γὰρ τὸ μὲν λευκὸν εἰς τὸ μέλαν, ὥσπερ καὶ τὸ μέλαν εἰς τὸ λευκὸν, καὶ τὸ θερμὸν αὖ εἰς τὸ ψυχρὸν, ὥσπερ καὶ τὸ ψυχρὸν εἰς τὸ θερμόν. οὕτω δὲ καὶ τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν εἰς τὸ ξηρὸν, τὸ δ’ αὖ ξηρὸν εἰς τὸ ὑγρόν. εἰ γὰρ δὴ φάσκει τις ἠλλοιῶσθαι τὸ σῶμα τῷ τέως ὑγρὸν ὑπάρχον εἶναι νῦν λευκὸν, ἢ τῷ τέως ξηρὸν ὂν τὸ νῦν φαίνεσθαι μέλαν, οὐκ ἂν ὑγιαίνειν δόξειεν. εἰ δέ γε τὸ τέως ὑγρὸν τὸ νῦν ξηρὸν φαίη γενέσθαι, ἢ τὸ πρότερον ὑπάρχον μέλαν νῦν εἶναι λευκὸν, ἢ ἐκ θερμοῦ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ἐκ ψυχροῦ θερμὸν γεγονέναι, σωφρονεῖν ἂν δόξειεν ὁ τοιοῦτος, καὶ λέγειν τὰ εἰκότα. τὸ γὰρ μεταβάλλον, ᾗ μεταβάλλει, ταύτῃ μεταχωρεῖν δεῖ πρὸς τοὐναντίον. ἐγένετο γοῦν ἢ γίγνεται μουσικὸς ὅδε, φαμὲν, ἐξ οὐ μουσικοῦ δηλονότι, καὶ γραμματικὸς ἐξ οὐ γραμματικοῦ, καὶ ῥητορικὸς ἐξ οὐ ῥητορικοῦ· τὸ δ’ ἐκ μουσικοῦ γραμματικὸν, ἢ ἐκ γραμματικοῦ μουσικὸν, ἢ ἐξ ἄλλου τινὸς τῶν ἑτερογενῶν γίνεσθαί τι λέγειν ἄτοπον. ἐγχωρεῖ γὰρ τὸν τέως γραμματικὸν νῦν μουσικὸν γεγονέναι, προσκτησάμενον τῇ γραμματικῇ τὴν μουσικὴν, οὐκ ἀποβαλόντα τὴν γραμματικήν. καὶ μὴν εἰ προσεκτήσατό τι, μένοντος τοῦ προτέρου, παντί που δῆλον, ὡς οὐκ ἠλλοιώθη κατὰ τὸ μένον. ὥστ’ οὐκ ἐκ γραμματικοῦ μουσικὸς ἐγένετο· καὶ γὰρ καὶ νῦν ἔτι γραμματικός ἐστιν· ἀλλ’ ἐξ ἀμούσου μουσικός· οὐ γὰρ ἔτ’ ἐγχωρεῖ μένειν αὐτὸν ἄμουσον, μουσικόν γε ἤδη γεγονότα. πασῶν γοῦν τῶν μεταβολῶν ὑπὸ τῶν ἐναντίων τε κᾀκ τῶν ἐναντίων εἰς τὰ ἐναντία γιγνομένων, δηλονότι καὶ τὸ ὑγρὸν, εἰ μεταβάλλει ποτὲ, καθ’ ὅσον ὑγρὸν, αὐτό τε ξηρανθήσεται καὶ τὸ ξηραῖνον αὐτὸ ξηρὸν λεχθήσεται. μὴ τοίνυν λεγόντων, φασὶν, ὡς θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὰν κρᾶσιν οὐκ ἐγχωρεῖ γενέσθαι. θερμὴν μὲν γὰρ ἅμα καὶ ψυχρὰν εἶναι τὴν αὐτὴν, ἢ ὑγρὰν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰν οὐκ ἐγχωρεῖ· συνυπάρχειν γὰρ ἀλλήλαις οὐχ οἷόν τε καθ’ ἓν καὶ ταὐτὸ σῶμα τὰς ἐναντίας ποιότητας· ἅμα δ’ ὑγρόν τι καὶ θερμὸν, καὶ ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν εἶναι δυνατὸν, ὡς ὅ τε λόγος ἀπέδειξε καὶ τὰ σμικρῷ πρόσθεν εἰρημένα παραδείγματα. τοιοῦτος μὲν οὖν ὁ τῶν προτέρων λόγος.
paragraphs.openai_translation: So it is not necessary, if something is cold, that it immediately also be moist, nor, if something is hot, that it immediately also be dry; accordingly, a hot mixture [krasis: the temperament or blend of qualities] is not of necessity also dry, but it is possible that at times the hot may prevail over the cold in the animal’s mixture, while the moist prevails over the dry. For both coming-to-be [genesis], and alteration [alloiosis], and change [metabolē] occur from contraries into contraries. For who would not be laughable if he said that the white thing had been altered and had changed—“for it became hot”? For the account inquires not into the opposition according to cold and hot, but into the change according to color: white changes into black, just as black into white, and hot in turn into cold, just as cold into hot. So too the moist into the dry, and in turn the dry into the moist. For if someone asserts that the body has been altered on the grounds that what was formerly moist is now white, or that because what was formerly dry now appears black, he would seem unsound. But if he should say that what was formerly moist has now become dry, or that what previously was black is now white, or that from hot it has become cold, or from cold hot, such a person would seem sensible and to speak plausibly. For that which undergoes change, in the respect in which it changes, must pass over in that respect to the opposite. Accordingly, we say, “This man has become—or is becoming—musical,” plainly from not being musical, and “a grammarian from not being a grammarian, and a rhetorician from not being a rhetorician”; but to say that something becomes a grammarian from being a musician, or a musician from being a grammarian, or from some other of heterogeneous things, is absurd. For it is admissible that the one who was formerly a grammarian has now become musical by adding music to grammar, not by casting off grammar. And indeed, if he has acquired something while the former thing remains, it is evident to everyone that he has not been altered with respect to what remains. So he did not become musical from being a grammarian—for even now he is still a grammarian—but from being unmusical; for it is no longer possible for him to remain unmusical, once he has already become musical. Since, then, all changes come about through contraries and from contraries into contraries, it is evident that the moist, too, whenever it changes, in so far as it is moist, will itself be dried, and that which dries it will be called dry. Therefore, they say, let no one assert that it is impossible for a hot and moist mixture to come to be at the same time. For it is impossible for the same thing to be at once hot and cold, or at once moist and dry; for it is not possible for contrary qualities to coexist in one and the same body. But that something be at once moist and hot, and at once cold and dry, is possible, as both the argument has demonstrated and the examples mentioned a little earlier. Such, then, is the account of the earlier thinkers.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the passage:

Therefore, it is not necessary that if something is cold, it must also be wet, nor if something is hot, must it also be dry. Thus, a hot mixture need not necessarily be dry, but rather it is possible that in an animal's mixture [krasis], heat may sometimes predominate over cold, while moisture predominates over dryness. Indeed, generation, alteration, and change occur from opposites to opposites. For who would not be ridiculous in saying that something white was altered and changed because it became hot? For such reasoning seeks not the opposition between cold and hot, but rather the change in color - for white changes to black, just as black changes to white, and hot changes to cold, just as cold changes to hot. Similarly, wet changes to dry, and dry in turn to wet.

If someone were to claim that a body has been altered because what was previously wet is now white, or what was previously dry now appears black, they would not seem to be thinking soundly. But if they were to say that what was previously wet has now become dry, or what was previously black is now white, or what was hot has become cold, or cold has become hot, such a person would seem sensible and speaking reasonably. For that which changes must, in the way it changes, transition to its opposite.

We say that this person has become or is becoming musical from being non-musical, literate from being non-literate, and rhetorical from being non-rhetorical. But it would be absurd to say that something becomes literate from being musical, or musical from being literate, or that something comes to be from any other heterogeneous quality. For it is possible for someone who was previously literate to become musical by acquiring musical skill while retaining literacy, not by losing literacy. And indeed, if something is acquired while the previous quality remains, it is clear to everyone that no alteration has occurred in what remains. Thus, one does not become musical from being literate - for one is still literate - but rather musical from being non-musical, for it is no longer possible to remain non-musical once one has become musical.

Since all changes occur through and from opposites to opposites, it is clear that if something wet changes, insofar as it is wet, it will itself become dry, and that which dries it will be called dry. Therefore, they say, let them not claim that it is impossible for a mixture to be both hot and wet. For while the same thing cannot be both hot and cold, or wet and dry simultaneously - as opposite qualities cannot coexist in one and the same body - it is possible for something to be both wet and hot, or cold and dry simultaneously, as both reason has demonstrated and the examples mentioned shortly before have shown. Such, then, is the argument of the earlier thinkers.

[Note: "krasis" refers to the mixture or blending of elemental qualities in ancient medical theory]

paragraphs.content: ὁ δὲ τῶν δευτέρων οὐδὲν ἄτοπον εἶναί φησιν, ὑποκειμένου τοῦ θερμοῦ δραστικωτάτου τῶν τεττάρων, ὡς μὴ μόνον εἰς τὸ ψυχρὸν, ἀλλὰ καὶ εἰς τὸ ὑγρὸν ἐνεργεῖν, εἶναι κρᾶσιν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, ὅταν ἐς ταὐτὸ ἅμα συνέλθῃ πλῆθος ὑγρότητός τε καὶ θερμότητος εὐθὺς ἐν τῇ πρώτῃ γενέσει τοῦ ζώου. ὁ δὲ λόγος ἐκείνων οὐχ, ὡς οὐκ ἄν ποτε γένοιτο καθ’ ἓν καὶ ταὐτὸ σῶμα τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ πλέον, τὸ δὲ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ, δείκνυσιν, ἀλλ’ ὡς οὐκ ἂν διαμείναι τοιοῦτο ἄχρι παντός· ἀεὶ γὰρ ἐξικμαζόμενον ὑπὸ τοῦ θερμοῦ τὸ ὑγρὸν ἐν τῷ χρόνῳ ξηρὸν ἀποδείξει τὸ σῶμα· καὶ οὕτως οὐκ ἂν ἔτι θερμὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν, ἀλλὰ θερμὸν εἴη καὶ ξηρόν· αὐτὸ δ’ οὖν πάλιν τοῦτο, τὸ θερμὸν καὶ ξηρὸν, ἐπὶ προήκοντι τῷ χρόνῳ ξηρὸν ἔσται καὶ ψυχρόν. ἐπειδὰν γὰρ ἐκβοσκήσηται τὴν ἰκμάδα πᾶσαν αὐτοῦ τὸ θερμὸν, ἄρχεται τοὐντεῦθεν ἤδη, φασὶ, καὶ αὐτὸ μαραίνεσθαι, μηκέτ’ εὐποροῦν τροφῆς, ὅθεν ἐξήπτετο. θαυμαστὸν οὖν οὐδὲν εἶναι νομίζουσι, καὶ κατ’ ἀρχὰς μὲν εὐθὺς ἐν τῇ πρώτῃ γενέσει τοῦ ζώου συνδραμεῖν εἰς ταὐτὸ ἢ τὸ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ πλέον, ἢ τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ. δυνατὸν δὲ κᾀν τῷ χρόνῳ προϊόντι γίνεσθαι τὴν τέως θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν κρᾶσιν αὖθις θερμὴν καὶ ξηρὰν, ὥσπερ γε καὶ αὖθις πάλιν τὴν ξηρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, ἀποσβεννυμένου τοῦ θερμοῦ, ψυχρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν ἀποτελεσθῆναι.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
But the second group maintains that there is nothing absurd in this, given that heat, being the most active of the four, acts not only upon the cold but also upon the moist, so that there can be a moist-and-hot mixture [krasis: mixture/temperament], whenever a great quantity of moisture and of heat comes together into the same subject at once, right at the animal’s first coming-to-be.

Their argument does not show that it could never happen in one and the same body that the moist is greater than the dry and the hot greater than the cold, but rather that such a condition would not endure forever. For since the moist is constantly being drained of its sap [ikmada: vital moisture] by the hot, in time it will render the body dry; and thus it would no longer be hot and moist, but hot and dry. And this very state again, the hot-and-dry, with time advancing will become dry and cold. For once the hot has grazed out [consumed] all its sap, from that point, they say, it too begins to wither, no longer having a supply of the nourishment from which it had been kindled.

Accordingly, they consider it no wonder if, at the outset, immediately in the animal’s first formation, either the moist outstrips the dry or the hot the cold, both converging into the same subject. And it is possible, as time goes on, for the mixture that was previously hot and moist to become hot and dry, just as, again, the
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the passage:

He [the proponent of the second view] says there is nothing absurd, given that heat is the most active of the four [elements/qualities], in that it acts not only upon the cold but also upon the wet, in there being a wet and hot mixture, whenever an abundance of wetness and heat come together at the same time immediately in the first generation of the animal. The argument of those others does not demonstrate that there could never exist in one and the same body both more wet than dry and more hot than cold, but rather that such a condition could not persist forever. For the wet, being constantly dried out by the heat over time, will render the body dry; and thus it would no longer be hot and wet, but hot and dry. And then again this very condition, the hot and dry, as time advances further, will become dry and cold. For when the heat has consumed all its moisture, from that point onwards, they say, it begins to waste away, no longer having an abundant source of nourishment from which it was kindled. Therefore they consider it nothing remarkable that at the beginning, immediately in the first generation of the animal, there might converge in the same place either more wet than dry, or more hot than cold. It is also possible that as time progresses, the mixture that was previously hot and wet might become hot and dry, just as again in turn the dry and hot mixture, when the heat is extinguished, might end up cold and dry.

[Note: The text appears to be discussing medical/philosophical theories about bodily temperaments and the interaction of fundamental qualities (hot, cold, wet, dry) in living organisms.]

paragraphs.content: ὅτι μὲν οὖν ἐγχωρεῖ καὶ θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὰν εἶναί τινα, καὶ ψυχρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν ἑτέραν τῆσδε κρᾶσιν, ἐκ τούτων ἀποδεικνύουσιν. ὅτι δὲ πλείους τῶν τεττάρων διαφορὰς κράσεων ἀδύνατον ὑπάρχειν, ἐκ τῶνδε πειρῶνται διδάσκειν.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, that it is possible for something to be at once both hot and moist, and that another mixture [krasis: combination/temperament] of this sort is cold and dry, they demonstrate from the following. And that it is impossible for there to be more than four differences of mixtures, they attempt to show from what follows.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation:

"Therefore, from these [arguments] they demonstrate that it is possible for a certain mixture [krasis] to be both hot and moist at the same time, and for another to be cold and dry. And from the following they attempt to teach that it is impossible for there to be more than four different types of mixtures [kraseis]."

[Note: "krasis/kraseis" refers to the medical/philosophical concept of bodily temperaments or mixtures of qualities, a key concept in ancient Greek medical theory]

The translation preserves the logical structure marked by μὲν οὖν... δὲ (therefore... and) and maintains the technical terminology while rendering it in clear English. The text appears to be discussing the theory of bodily temperaments or humoral theory, likely from a medical or philosophical treatise.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: From the preceding points, then, they demonstrate that it is possible for one mixture [krasis: temperament or mixture of qualities] to be at once hot and moist, and another cold and dry. But from the following points, they attempt to show that it is impossible for more than four varieties of mixtures to exist.

paragraphs.content: ὑποκειμένων γὰρ, φασὶ, τεττάρων ποιοτήτων, εἰς ἀλλήλας τε τὸ δρᾷν καὶ πάσχειν ἐχουσῶν, θερμότητός τε καὶ ψυχρότητος, καὶ ξηρότητος καὶ ὑγρότητος, ἀντιθέσεις γίνεσθαι δύο, τὴν μὲν ἑτέραν, ἐν ᾗ τὸ θερμὸν ἀντίκειται τῷ ψυχρῷ, τὴν δ’ ἑτέραν, ἐν ᾗ τὸ ξηρὸν τῷ ὑγρῷ, καὶ διὰ τοῦτο τέτταρας ἀποτελεῖσθαι τὰς πάσας συζυγίας. ἓξ μὲν γὰρ γίνεσθαι τῶν τεττάρων ἀλλήλαις ἐπιπλεκομένων τὰς συζεύξεις, ἀλλὰ τὰς δύο τούτων ἀδυνάτους ὑπάρχειν. οὔτε γὰρ ὑγρὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν, οὔτε ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ θερμὸν δύναται γενέσθαι σῶμα. λείπεται γοῦν τέτταρας εἶναι συζυγίας κράσεων, ὑγρὰς μὲν δύο, ξηρὰς δὲ δύο, θερμότητι καὶ ψυχρότητι διῃρημένας. ἃ μὲν οὖν οἱ χαριέστατοι τῶν πρὸ ἡμῶν ἰατρῶν τε καὶ φιλοσόφων εἰρήκασι, ταῦτά ἐστιν.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For, they say, since there are four underlying qualities, which have the capacity to act upon and to be acted upon by one another—namely heat and cold, and dryness and wetness—two oppositions arise: the one in which the hot is set against the cold, and the other in which the dry is set against the wet; and for this reason there result four total pairings. For while six couplings would arise from the interweaving of the four with one another, two of these turn out to be impossible. For a body cannot at the same time be wet and dry, nor at the same time cold and hot. What remains, then, is that there are four pairings of mixtures [kraseis: blendings], two moist and two dry, distinguished by heat and by cold. Such, then, are the things that the most refined of our predecessors among physicians and philosophers have said.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation:

"For they say that, given four qualities which can act upon and be affected by each other - heat and cold, and dryness and moisture - there arise two pairs of opposites: one in which hot is opposed to cold, and another in which dry is opposed to moist. And because of this, four combinations in total are produced. For while six combinations would arise from the four qualities being intertwined with each other, two of these are impossible. For no body can be simultaneously moist and dry, nor cold and hot at the same time. Therefore, there remain four possible combinations of mixtures [krasis]: two moist and two dry, distinguished by heat and cold. These, then, are the things that the most distinguished of the physicians and philosophers before us have said."

[Note: "krasis" (κράσεων) is a technical term referring to the mixing or blending of elemental qualities, particularly important in ancient medical theory]

The translation preserves the logical structure of the argument about the fundamental qualities and their possible combinations, which appears to be discussing basic principles of ancient medical and natural philosophical theory.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: For they say that, with four underlying qualities—heat and coldness, and dryness and wetness—which have the capacity to act and be acted upon by one another, two oppositions arise: one in which the hot is opposed to the cold, and the other in which the dry is opposed to the wet; and that for this reason, four combinations in total are brought about. For while six pairings come to be from the four being interwoven with one another, two of these are impossible. For a body cannot become wet and dry at the same time, nor cold and hot at the same time. Therefore, four combinations of mixtures [Greek: *kraseis*, or temperaments] are left: two wet and two dry, distinguished by heat and coldness. These, then, are the things which the most distinguished of the physicians and philosophers before us have said.

paragraphs.content: ἃ δ’ ἐγὼ παραλιπεῖν αὐτοὺς νομίζω, λέγειν ἤδη καιρός.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But it is now time to speak of what I think they have left out.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Translation:
"Now it is time to speak about what I think they have omitted."

Notes:
- The phrase "ἃ...παραλιπεῖν" is a substantive clause using the relative pronoun "ἃ" (what/the things which)
- "καιρός" here carries the sense of "the right moment/appropriate time"
- The infinitive "λέγειν" is used as a complement to "καιρός"
- "αὐτοὺς" refers to previous speakers or writers mentioned in earlier context
- The structure suggests this is a transitional sentence, likely introducing a new topic or criticism in a philosophical or argumentative work
paragraphs.gemini_translation: But what I believe they have omitted, it is now the opportune moment to state.

paragraphs.content: Ἕν μὲν δὴ καὶ πρῶτον, ὅτι τὴν εὔκρατον φύσιν, ὥσπερ οὐκ ἀρετῇ τε ἅμα καὶ δυνάμει προὔχουσαν, ἐπελάθοντό τε καὶ τελέως παρέλιπον, ὥσπερ μηδ’ ὅλως οὖσαν, καίτοι μηδὲ φθέγξασθαί τι χωρὶς ἐκείνης ὑπὲρ τῶν ἄλλων δυνάμενοι. τὸ γοῦν ἐν τῇ θερμῇ κράσει πλεονεκτεῖν τὸ θερμὸν, ἢ ἐν τῇ ψυχρᾷ τὸ ψυχρὸν, οὐδ’ ἐπινοῆσαι δυνατὸν ἄνευ τοῦ πρότερον ἐπιθέσθαι τὴν εὔκρατον. οὐδὲ γὰρ οὐδὲ τὴν ὑγιεινὴν δίαιταν εἰς ἄλλο τι βλέποντες ἐξευρίσκουσιν, ἢ τὴν εὔκρατον ἐκείνην φύσιν· τὸ μὲν θερμότερον τοῦ δέοντος σῶμα κελεύοντες ἐμψύχειν, τὸ δ’ αὖ ψυχρότερον θερμαίνειν· ὡσαύτως τὸ μὲν ὑγρότερον ξηραίνειν, τὸ δὲ ξηρότερον ὑγραίνειν, ἀντεισάγοντες ἀεὶ δηλονότι τῷ πλεονάζοντι τὸ λεῖπον, ὡς εὔκρατόν τινα καὶ μέσην ἐργάσασθαι κατάστασιν. ἣν οὖν ἀεὶ μεταδιώκουσιν, καὶ πρὸς ἣν ἀποβλέποντες ἐπανορθοῦνται τὰς δυσκράτους, ἐγὼ μὲν ἠξίουν ἁπασῶν πρῶτον λέγεσθαι πρὸς αὐτῶν. οἳ δ’ ἄρα τοσοῦτον ἀποδέουσι τοῦ μεμνῆσθαι ταύτης, ὥσθ’ ὅλως παραλείπουσιν αὐτήν. ἀλλ’ οὐ παραλέλειπται, φασὶν ἐξ αὐτῶν ἔνιοι, ἐν γὰρ τῇ θερμῇ καὶ ὑγρᾷ περιέχεται. καὶ πῶς οὐχὶ πέντε λέγετε τὰς πάσας εἶναι κράσεις, ἀλλὰ τέτταρας, εἴπερ τῆς ἀρίστης μέμνησθε; δυοῖν γὰρ θάτερον, ἢ τῶν δυσκράτων ἀνάγκη παραλελεῖφθαι μίαν, ἢ τὴν εὔκρατον. ἐγὼ μὲν δὴ σαφῶς οἶδα τὴν εὔκρατον αὐτοὺς παραλιπόντας, ἐξ ὧν ἀξιοῦσιν. ἐπειδὰν γὰρ θερμὴν καὶ ξηρὰν, καὶ ψυχρὰν καὶ ὑγρὰν, ἤ τινα ἄλλην λέγωσι κρᾶσιν, οὐ τῶν ἄκρων ἀκούειν ἡμᾶς χρῆναι ποιοτήτων, ἀλλὰ κατὰ τὴν πλεονεκτοῦσαν ἀεὶ γίνεσθαι προσηγορίαν. εἰ δ’ οὐ βούλονται τὴν εὔκρατον παραλελεῖφθαι, τῶν ἄλλων τινὰ δειχθήσονται παραλιπόντες. ἔστω γὰρ εὔκρατον εἶναι τὴν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, ὥσπερ αὐτοὶ βούλονται. παραλελοίπασιν ἄρα σαφῶς τὴν ἀντικειμένην τῇ ψυχρᾷ καὶ ξηρᾷ δυσκρασίᾳ, ἐν ᾗ τὸ ὑγρὸν πλεονεκτεῖ καὶ τὸ θερμόν.

paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the passage:

One point, and indeed the first, is that they both forgot and completely overlooked the well-balanced [eukratos] nature, as if it were not superior in both excellence and capability, as if it didn't exist at all - even though they couldn't say anything about the other powers without reference to it. Indeed, it's impossible even to conceive of an excess of heat in a hot mixture, or of cold in a cold mixture, without first establishing the well-balanced state as a reference. For even when discovering the healthy regimen, they look to nothing else but that well-balanced nature: prescribing cooling for a body that's warmer than it should be, and warming what's too cold; likewise, drying what's too moist, and moistening what's too dry - clearly always introducing what's lacking to counter what's excessive, so as to create a well-balanced and intermediate condition.

This state which they constantly pursue, and with reference to which they correct ill-balanced conditions, I maintained should have been discussed first of all by them. But they are so far from remembering it that they omit it entirely. But it hasn't been omitted, some of them say, for it's included in the hot and moist mixture. Then why don't you say there are five mixtures in total, rather than four, if you indeed remember the best one? For one of two things must be true: either one of the ill-balanced mixtures has been omitted, or the well-balanced one has.

I clearly know they've omitted the well-balanced mixture from their assertions. For when they speak of a hot and dry, or cold and moist, or some other mixture, they claim we shouldn't understand these as referring to extreme qualities, but that the terminology always follows what's predominant. But if they don't want to admit they've omitted the well-balanced mixture, they'll be shown to have omitted one of the others. For let's say the moist and hot mixture is the well-balanced one, as they themselves want: then they've clearly omitted the mixture opposite to the cold and dry imbalance, in which moisture and heat predominate.

[Note: "eukratos" (εὔκρατος) refers to a well-balanced or properly mixed state, a key concept in ancient medical theory]
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ αὐτὴ, φασὶν, ἐστὶν ἥδε. καὶ πῶς ἐνδέχεται καὶ πλεονεκτεῖν ἅμα τὸ θερμὸν καὶ μὴ πλεονεκτεῖν, καὶ κρατεῖσθαι καὶ μὴ κρατεῖσθαι τὸ ψυχρόν; εἰ μὲν γὰρ εὔκρατός ἐστιν, οὐδὲν οὐδενὸς ἀμέτρως ἐπικρατεῖ, εἰ δὲ δύσκρατος, ἀνάγκη πλεονεκτεῖν τι τῶν ἐκ τῆς ἀντιθέσεως. ἀλλ’ αὐτὸ τοῦτο, φασὶν, ἴδιόν ἐστι τῆς εὐκράτου, τὸ κρατεῖν ἐν αὐτῇ τὸ μὲν θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ, τὸ δ’ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ· κρατήσαντος γὰρ τοῦ ψυχροῦ, μετρίως μὲν, οὐκ ἀγαθὴν εἶναι τὴν κρᾶσιν, ἔτι δὲ μᾶλλον, νόσον ἤδη γίνεσθαι, καθάπερ, εἰ καὶ σφοδρῶς κρατήσειε, θάνατον· οὕτω δὲ κᾀπὶ τοῦ ξηροῦ συμπίπτειν ἐν ἀρχῇ μὲν δυσκρασίαν, ἐπὶ πλέον δὲ νόσον, ἐπὶ πλεῖστον δὲ κρατήσαντος, θάνατον· ὥσπερ οὐχὶ κᾀπὶ τῆς ὑγρᾶς καὶ θερμῆς ταῦτα συμπίπτοντα. τίς γὰρ ἂν οὐχ ὁμολογήσειεν, ὡς, ἐπειδὰν μὲν ἐπ’ ὀλίγον ἢ τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ τύχοι πλεονεκτῆσαν, ἢ τὸ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ, δυσκρασίαν οὕτως γιγνομένην· ἐπειδὰν δ’ ἐπὶ πλέον, νόσον· ἐπειδὰν δ’ ἐπὶ πλεῖστον, θάνατον.
paragraphs.openai_translation: “But this, they say, is the account. And how is it possible that at one and the same time the hot both have the advantage and not have it, and the cold be overmastered and not overmastered? For if the mixture is well-tempered [eukratos: well-balanced], then nothing dominates anything else beyond due measure; but if it is ill-tempered [dyskra tos: out of balance], something from among the contraries must have the upper hand. ‘But this very thing,’ they say, ‘is the peculiar mark of the well-tempered state: that in it the hot prevails over the cold, and the moist over the dry.’ For if the cold prevails—even moderately—the mixture [krâsis: temperament/constitution] is not good; if it prevails more, it already becomes a disease; and if it prevails violently, a death. And so too in the case of the dry, at the outset there is dyscrasia [bad mixture], with a greater excess disease, and with the greatest excess, when it has fully prevailed, death—as though these same outcomes did not also occur in the case of the moist and the hot! For who would not acknowledge that whenever, even to a small extent, either the hot happens to have the advantage over the cold or the moist over the dry, a dyscrasia thus arises; if to a greater extent, a disease; and if to the greatest extent, death?”
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation:

But this, they say, is the situation. And how is it possible for the hot to both predominate and not predominate simultaneously, and for the cold to be both dominated and not dominated? For if it is well-tempered [eukratos], nothing dominates anything else excessively, but if it is ill-tempered [dyskratos], something from the opposition must necessarily predominate. But this very thing, they say, is characteristic of the well-tempered state: that in it the hot dominates the cold, and the moist dominates the dry. For when the cold dominates, if moderately, the mixture [krasis] is not good, and if more so, illness now occurs, just as death results if it dominates severely. And similarly with the dry, at first producing bad temperament, then as it increases, illness, and when it dominates to the greatest extent, death. As if these same things don't also occur with the moist and hot conditions! For who would not agree that when either the hot happens to predominate over the cold by a little, or the moist over the dry, a bad temperament thus arises; and when it predominates more, illness occurs; and when it predominates to the greatest extent, death results?

[Note: krasis refers to the mixture or blending of elemental qualities in ancient medical theory]

paragraphs.content: ὁ γὰρ αὐτὸς ἐπ’ ἀμφοῖν λόγος. ἢ μηδὲ τὰς ἀμέτρως ὑγρὰς καὶ θερμὰς καταστάσεις αἰτιώμεθα, μηδ’ ὅσα μεθ’ ὑγρότητος ἀμέτρου νοσήματα συνίσταται θερμὰ, μηδὲ ταῦτ’ ὁμολογῶμεν εἶναι νοσήματα. πρὸς δὴ τοὺς τοιούτους λόγους ἀπομαχόμενοί τινες τῶν ἀπ’ Ἀθηναίου τοῦ Ἀτταλέως ὁμόσε χωροῦσιν, οὔτε κατάστασιν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν μέμφεσθαι λέγοντες, οὔθ’ εὑρεθῆναί τι νόσημα φάσκοντες ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν, ἀλλὰ πάντως ἢ θερμὸν καὶ ξηρὸν ὑπάρχειν, ὡς τὸν πυρετὸν, ἢ ψυχρὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν, ὡς τὸν ὕδερον, ἢ ψυχρὸν καὶ ξηρὸν, ὡς τὴν μελαγχολίαν. ἐπιμέμνηνται δ’ ἐνταῦθα καὶ τῶν ὡρῶν τοῦ ἔτους, ὑγρὸν μὲν καὶ ψυχρὸν εἶναι τὸν χειμῶνα φάσκοντες, ξηρὸν δὲ καὶ θερμὸν τὸ θέρος, καὶ ψυχρὸν καὶ ξηρὸν τὸ φθινόπωρον, εὔκρατον δ’ ἅμα καὶ θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν ὥραν καλοῦσι τὸ ἔαρ· οὕτω δὲ καὶ τῶν ἡλικιῶν τὴν παιδικὴν εὔκρατόν τε καὶ θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν εἶναί φασι. δηλοῦσθαι δὲ τὴν εὐκρασίαν αὐτῆς νομίζουσι κᾀκ τῶν ἐνεργειῶν τῆς φύσεως, ἐῤῥωμένων τηνικαῦτα μάλιστα. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ τὸν θάνατόν φασιν εἰς ξηρότητα καὶ ψύξιν ἄγειν τὰ τῶν ζώων σώματα. καλεῖσθαι γοῦν ἀλίβαντας τοὺς νεκροὺς, ὡς ἂν μηκέτι λιβάδα καὶ ὑγρότητα κεκτημένους οὐδεμίαν, ἐξατμισθέντας ἅμα διὰ τὴν ἀποχώρησιν τοῦ θερμοῦ, καὶ παγέντας ὑπὸ τῆς ψύξεως. ἀλλ’ εἴπερ ὁ θάνατος, φασὶ, τοιοῦτος, ἀναγκαῖον ἤδη τὴν ζωὴν, ὡς ἂν ἐναντίαν ὑπάρχουσαν αὐτῷ, θερμήν τε εἶναι καὶ ὑγράν· καὶ μὴν εἴπερ ἡ ζωὴ, φασὶ, θερμόν τι χρῆμα καὶ ὑγρόν ἐστιν, ἀνάγκη πᾶσα, καὶ τὴν ὁμοιοτάτην αὐτῇ κρᾶσιν ἀρίστην ὑπάρχειν, εἰ δὲ τοῦτο παντί που δῆλον, ὡς εὐκρατοτάτην, ὥστ’ εἰς ταὐτὸ συμβαίνειν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν φύσιν εὐκράτῳ, καὶ μηδὲν ἄλλο εἶναι τὴν εὐκρασίαν, ἢ τῆς ὑγρότητός τε καὶ θερμότητος ἐπικρατούσης. οἱ μὲν δὴ τῶν ἀμφὶ τὸν Ἀθήναιον λόγοι τοιοίδε. δοκεῖ δέ πως ἡ αὐτὴ δόξα καὶ Ἀριστοτέλους εἶναι τοῦ φιλοσόφου, καὶ Θεοφράστου γε μετ’ αὐτὸν, καὶ τῶν Στωϊκῶν, ὥστε καὶ τῷ πλήθει τῶν μαρτύρων ἡμᾶς δυσωποῦσιν. ἐγὼ δὲ περὶ μὲν Ἀριστοτέλους, ὅπως ἐγίνωσκεν ὑπὲρ θερμῆς καὶ ὑγρᾶς κράσεως, ἴσως ἂν, εἰ δεηθείη, ἐπὶ προήκοντι τῷ λόγῳ δείξαιμι· δοκοῦσι γάρ μοι παρακούειν αὐτοῦ.

paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the passage:

For the same argument applies to both cases. Otherwise, we should neither blame excessively wet and hot conditions, nor acknowledge as diseases those hot ailments that arise with excessive moisture. Some followers of Athenaeus of Attalia, fighting against such arguments, confront them directly, saying that they neither fault a wet and hot condition, nor claim that any disease can be found that is wet and hot, but rather that it must be either hot and dry, like fever, or cold and wet, like dropsy, or cold and dry, like melancholy.

They also mention here the seasons of the year, asserting that winter is wet and cold, summer is dry and hot, autumn is cold and dry, and they call spring a well-tempered season that is both hot and wet. Similarly, they say that childhood is well-tempered, hot, and wet. They believe its good temperament is demonstrated by the activities of nature, which are strongest at this time.

Moreover, they say that death leads animal bodies to dryness and coldness. Indeed, corpses are called "alibantes" [waterless ones], as they no longer possess any moisture or wetness, having been both evaporated due to the departure of heat and frozen by coldness. But if death, they say, is such, then life, being its opposite, must necessarily be hot and wet. And if life is something hot and wet, they say, it follows absolutely that the constitution most similar to it must be the best, and if this is clearly well-tempered to everyone, then a wet and hot nature coincides with a well-tempered one, and good temperament is nothing other than the predominance of wetness and heat.

Such are the arguments of Athenaeus's followers. This opinion seems somehow to be shared by Aristotle the philosopher, and after him by Theophrastus, and by the Stoics, so they intimidate us with the multitude of witnesses. Regarding Aristotle, however, I might perhaps show later in the discussion, if necessary, what he actually thought about hot and wet mixture; for they seem to me to misunderstand him.
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
For the same reasoning applies to both. Or else, let us not blame excessively wet and hot conditions, nor such hot diseases as are constituted with excessive wetness, nor even agree that these are diseases at all. Now, fighting back against such arguments, some of the school of Athenaeus of Attaleia engage directly, saying that one should not find fault with a wet and hot condition, and asserting that no disease is found to be wet and hot, but that it is in every case either hot and dry, like fever; or cold and wet, like dropsy; or cold and dry, like melancholy.

In this context, they also bring up the seasons of the year, asserting that winter is wet and cold, summer is dry and hot, and autumn is cold and dry; but spring they call

paragraphs.content: Τὸ δέ γε νῦν εἶναι, πειράσομαι πρῶτον ἐνδείξασθαι τοῖς λέγουσι ταῦτα, πῆ ποτε σοφίζονται σφᾶς αὐτοὺς, εἶτ’ ἐφεξῆς ἐπιδεῖξαι τὸν ἅπαντα λόγον, εἰς ἓν ἀθροίσας κεφάλαιον. ὅτι μὲν δὴ τὸ ἔαρ οἴονται θερμὸν εἶναι καὶ ὑγρὸν ἅμα καὶ εὔκρατον, ἐντεῦθεν σοφίζονται προφανῶς. οὔτε γὰρ ὑγρὸν ὡς χειμὼν, οὔτε θερμὸν ὡς τὸ θέρος, ὥστ’ οὐδέτερον ἀμέτρως.
paragraphs.openai_translation: As for the matter at hand, I shall first try to show those who say these things how they contrive their case, and then, in due order, set out the entire argument, gathering it into a single summary [kephalaion]. They plainly base their clever reasoning on the claim that spring is at once warm and moist and temperate [eukraton = well-balanced]. For it is neither moist as winter is, nor warm as summer, so that neither quality is excessive.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

"For the present moment, I shall first attempt to demonstrate to those who say these things in what way they deceive themselves, and then subsequently display the entire argument, having gathered it into a single main point. Indeed, they clearly deceive themselves when they suppose that spring is both warm and moist as well as well-tempered [εὔκρατον: well-balanced], starting from this premise. For it is neither moist as winter is, nor warm as summer is, so it is neither quality to an excessive degree."

[Note: εὔκρατον (eukraton) is a technical term in ancient medical theory referring to a balanced mixture or temperament of qualities]

The translation preserves the formal philosophical/medical argument structure while maintaining readability in English. The Greek uses precise technical terminology related to qualities and temperaments, which I've attempted to render accurately while keeping the natural flow of the argument.
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
As things stand, however, I will first attempt to show those who say these things how precisely they deceive themselves, and then, in turn, to present the entire argument, having gathered it into a single summary. Now, they are manifestly deceiving themselves in this: that they suppose spring to be hot and wet and at the same time well-tempered [εὔκρατον]. For it is neither wet like winter, nor hot like summer, so that neither quality is present in excess.

[εὔκρατον: well-tempered or well-mixed; a state of balance, particularly in humoral theory.]

paragraphs.content: ἀμετρίας δ’ ἦν ἕκαστον τῶν τοιούτων ὀνομάτων, καὶ κατ’ αὐτοὺς ἐκείνους, δηλωτικόν. διχῶς δ’ ἐσφάλησαν, πρῶτον μὲν ἐκ τοῦ βούλεσθαι πάντως ἐν ταῖς ὥραις εὑρεῖν τὴν τετάρτην συζυγίαν τῶν κράσεων, ἔπειτα δ’ ἐκ τοῦ καὶ θερμότερον ἢ κατὰ τὸν χειμῶνα, καὶ ὑγρότερον ἢ κατὰ τὸ θέρος ὑπάρχειν αὐτό. ἀλλ’ οὔτ’ ἀναγκαῖον ἐν ταῖς ὥραις ὑποτίθεσθαι τὴν τετάρτην συζυγίαν τῶν κράσεων, εἰ μὴ καὶ φαίνοιτο, καὶ τὸ παραβάλλειν αὐτὸ ταῖς ἑκατέρωθεν ὥραις οὐδὲν μᾶλλον ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν ἀποδείξει καὶ ξηρόν. εἰ μὲν γὰρ ἀμετρίας ἐστὶν ὀνόματα τὸ ὑγρὸν καὶ τὸ θερμὸν, οὐκ ἀληθεύεται κατ’ αὐτούς· σύμμετρον γὰρ ἐν ἅπασι τὸ ἔαρ. εἰ δ’, ὅτι θέρους μέν ἐστιν ὑγρότερον, χειμῶνος δὲ θερμότερον, ὑγρόν ἐστι καὶ θερμὸν, οὐδὲν ἦττον αὐτὸ ψυχρὸν καὶ ξηρὸν νομίζεσθαι προσήκει, διότι θέρους μέν ἐστι ψυχρότερον, χειμῶνος δὲ ξηρότερον. ἢ τίς ἀποκλήρωσις, ἓν μὲν τῶν ἐκ τῆς ἀντιθέσεως ἀπὸ τοῦ χειμῶνος, ἓν δὲ ἀπὸ τοῦ θέρους λαμβάνειν; ἐν ἑκατέραις γὰρ ἀμφοτέρων διαφέρον, οὐκ ἐξ ἡμίσεως ὀφείλει τὴν παραβολὴν, ἀλλ’ ὁλόκληρον ἴσχειν. καὶ μὴν εἴπερ οὕτως γίνοιτο, τἀναντία φήσομεν ὑπάρχειν αὐτῷ. θερμὸν μὲν γὰρ ἔσται καὶ ξηρὸν, εἰ τῷ χειμῶνι, ψυχρὸν δ’ αὖ καὶ ὑγρὸν, εἰ τῷ θέρει παραβάλλοιτο. κατ’ οὐδετέραν οὖν τῶν παραβολῶν ὁλοκλήρως γινομένην ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἔσται. εἰ δ’ ἔξεστιν ἐκείνοις ἐξ ἑκατέρας αὐτῶν ἥμισυ λαβοῦσιν ὑγρὸν ἀποφαίνειν αὐτὸ καὶ θερμὸν, ἐξέσται δήπου καὶ ἡμῖν ἐπὶ θάτερον ἥμισυ μετελθοῦσιν ξηρὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν ἀποφῇναι, ξηρὸν μὲν ὡς πρὸς, τὸν χειμῶνα, ψυχρὸν δὲ ὡς πρὸς τὸ θέρος.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Each of these names was, even by their own account, indicative of excess [ametria, “lack of due measure”]. They went wrong in two ways: first, by wanting at all costs to find in the seasons the fourth pairing of the mixtures [syzygy of kra­seis], and secondly, by asserting that it is both warmer than winter and wetter than summer. But it is not necessary to posit within the seasons a fourth conjunction of mixtures unless it actually appears; and comparing it with the seasons on either side will show it no more wet and warm than cold and dry. For if “wet” and “warm” are names denoting excess, then according to their own view they are not speaking truly, since spring is proportionate in all respects. But if, because it is wetter than summer and warmer than winter, it is called wet and warm, it ought no less to be considered cold and dry, because it is colder than summer and drier than winter. Or what kind of allotment is it, to take one of the contraries from winter and one from summer? Since in relation to each of them it differs in both respects, the comparison ought not to be made by halves, but to hold as a whole. And indeed, if one proceeds thus, we shall say that the opposites belong to it: for it will be warm and dry if compared with winter, but cold and wet if compared with summer. Therefore, on neither of the comparisons taken as a whole will it turn out to be wet and warm. And if it is permissible for them, taking half from each, to declare it wet and warm, it will surely be permissible for us, taking the other half, to declare it dry and cold—dry in relation to winter, and cold in relation to summer.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the passage:

Each of these terms indicated an imbalance, even according to them. But they erred in two ways: first, in wanting to find at all costs the fourth combination of temperaments in the seasons, and second, in claiming that it [spring] is both warmer than winter and moister than summer. However, it is neither necessary to assume the fourth combination of temperaments exists in the seasons unless it is actually apparent, nor will comparing it to the seasons on either side prove it to be any more moist and hot than cold and dry.

For if "moist" and "hot" are terms denoting imbalance, this is not true according to them, since spring is well-balanced [symmetron] in all respects. But if it is considered moist and hot because it is moister than summer and hotter than winter, it should no less be considered cold and dry, because it is colder than summer and drier than winter. What justification is there for taking one quality from the comparison with winter and another from the comparison with summer? For since it differs from both seasons in both qualities, the comparison should not be made halfway, but completely.

Indeed, if we proceed this way, we will say that opposite qualities belong to it. For it will be hot and dry when compared to winter, but cold and moist when compared to summer. Therefore, by neither comparison, when made completely, will it be moist and hot. If they are permitted to take half from each comparison to declare it moist and hot, surely we too are permitted to turn to the other half and declare it dry and cold - dry compared to winter and cold compared to summer.

[Note: This appears to be a medical or philosophical text discussing seasonal temperaments and the qualities of hot, cold, moist, and dry, likely from the Galenic tradition]
