paragraphs.content: ἅπαντα οὖν οὕτως ἔσται τὸ ἔαρ, ὑγρὸν, ξηρὸν, θερμὸν, ψυχρόν. ἀλλ’ οὐδὲ κατ’ αὐτοὺς ἐκείνους οἶόν τέ ἐστιν ἐν ἑνὶ καὶ ταὐτῷ πράγματι τὰς τέτταρας ἐπικρατῆσαι ποιότητας· οὔκουν οὔτε θέρει παραβαλεῖν· οὔτε χειμῶνι τὸ ἔαρ, ἀλλ’ αὐτὸ καθ’ αὑτὸ σκοπεῖσθαι δίκαιον. οὐδὲ γὰρ οὐδὲ τὸν χειμῶνα διὰ τοῦτο λέγομεν ὑγρὸν εἶναι καὶ ψυχρὸν, ὅτι τῶν ἄλλων ὡρῶν ἐστιν ὑγρότατος καὶ ψυχρότατος.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, spring would thus turn out to be all things at once—wet, dry, hot, and cold. But not even on their own principles is it possible for the four qualities [hot, cold, wet, dry] to predominate in one and the same subject. Therefore one ought not to compare spring either with summer or with winter, but it is just to consider it in itself. For we do not even call winter wet and cold for the reason that it is the wettest and coldest of the seasons.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

"Therefore, spring will be all things in this way - wet, dry, hot, and cold. But not even according to those people themselves is it possible for all four qualities to predominate in one and the same thing. Hence it is not right to compare spring either to summer or to winter, but rather it should be examined on its own terms. For we do not say that winter is wet and cold for the reason that it is the wettest and coldest of all the seasons."

[Note: "qualities" (ποιότητας) here refers to the fundamental properties or characteristics in ancient Greek natural philosophy]

The translation preserves the argumentative structure of what appears to be a medical or philosophical text discussing the nature of seasons and their qualities, likely from a work dealing with humoral theory or natural philosophy.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: According to this reasoning, then, spring will be all of these things: wet, dry, hot, and cold. But not even by their own account is it possible for the four qualities [Greek: *poiotētes*] to prevail in one and the same thing. Therefore, one must not compare the spring either with summer or with winter; rather, it is proper to examine it on its own terms. For we do not, in fact, call winter wet and cold because it is the wettest and coldest of the other seasons.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ τοῦτο μὲν καὶ ἄλλως αὐτῷ συμβέβηκεν· ὅτι δὲ πλεονεκτεῖ κατ’ αὐτὸν ἡ μὲν ὑγρότης τῆς ξηρότητος, ἡ δὲ ψυχρότης τῆς θερμότητος, διὰ τοῦτο ψυχρὸς εἶναι καὶ ὑγρὸς λέγεται. κατὰ ταὐτὸ δὲ καὶ τὸ θέρος, ὅτι κᾀν τούτῳ τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν ἀπολείπεται τοῠ ξηροῦ, τὸ δὲ ψυχρὸν τοῦ θερμοῦ, διὰ τοῦτο θερμὸν εἶναι λέγεται καὶ ξηρόν. καὶ γὰρ δίκαιον, ἐκ τῆς οἰκείας φύσεως ἑκάστην τῶν ὡρῶν ἐξεταζομένην, οὐ πρὸς ἄλλην τινὰ παραβαλλομένην, ἢ θερμὴν, ἢ ψυχρὰν, ἢ ξηρὰν, ἢ ὑγρὰν ὀνομάζεσθαι. καὶ δὴ καὶ σκοπουμένῳ σοι κατὰ τάδε φανεῖται τὸ ἔαρ ἀκριβῶς μέσων ἁπασῶν τῶν ὑπερβολῶν. οὔτε γὰρ ὡς ἐν χειμῶνι πλεονεκτεῖ τὸ ψυχρὸν ἐν αὐτῷ τοῦ θερμοῦ, οὔθ’ ὡς ἐν θέρει πλεονεκτεῖται. κατὰ ταὐτὰ δὲ καὶ ξηρότητός τε καὶ ὑγρότητος ἰσομοιρία τίς ἐστιν ἐν αὐτῷ, μήθ’ ὡς ἐν θέρει κρατοῦντος τοῦ ξηροῦ, μήθ’ ὡς ἐν χειμῶνι τοῦ ὑγροῦ. διὰ τοῦτο ὀρθῶς εἴρηται πρὸς Ἱπποκράτους, ἦρ δὲ ὑγιεινότατον καὶ ἥκιστα θανατῶδες. ἀλλὰ καὶ τὸ φθινόπωρον ἧττον μὲν ἢ τὸ θέρος θερμὸν, ἧττον δὲ ἢ ὁ χειμὼν ψυχρόν.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But this, too, has happened to it in another way: namely, because in it moisture has the advantage over dryness, and cold over heat, for this reason it is said to be cold and moist [primary “qualities”: hot/cold, dry/moist]. And likewise summer, because in it the moist falls short of the dry and the cold of the hot, is therefore said to be hot and dry. For it is right that each of the seasons, examined in accordance with its own nature and not by comparison with some other, should be called either hot or cold or dry or moist. And indeed, if you consider the matter on these lines, spring will appear to you to be exactly in the middle of all the extremes. For in it the cold does not prevail over the hot as in winter, nor is it itself prevailed over as in summer. Likewise, there is a sort of equality of dryness and moisture in it—neither with the dry dominating as in summer, nor the moist as in winter. For this reason it has been rightly said by Hippocrates: “Spring is the most healthful and least deadly.” But autumn, too, is less hot than summer and less cold than winter.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

But this has happened to it in other ways too. Because in it moistness exceeds dryness, and coldness exceeds warmth, for this reason it is said to be cold and moist. Similarly with summer, because in it the moist falls short of the dry, and the cold falls short of the hot, for this reason it is said to be hot and dry. For it is right that each season, when examined according to its own nature and not compared to any other, should be called either hot, or cold, or dry, or moist. And indeed, if you examine it according to these principles, spring will appear to be precisely in the middle of all extremes. For neither does the cold exceed the hot in it as in winter, nor is it exceeded as in summer. Similarly, there is a certain equality of dryness and moistness in it, with neither the dry dominating as in summer, nor the moist as in winter. For this reason it was correctly stated by Hippocrates that "spring is the most healthful and least deadly." But autumn is less hot than summer and less cold than winter.

[Note: This appears to be a medical/philosophical text discussing the qualities of the seasons, using the classical theory of the four qualities (hot, cold, wet, dry) that was fundamental to ancient Greek medicine and natural philosophy.]
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ὥστε ταύτῃ μὲν οὔτε θερμὸν ἁπλῶς, οὔτε ψυχρὸν, ἀμφότερα γάρ ἐστι, καὶ οὐδέτερον ἄκρως. ἕτερον δέ τι πρόσεστιν αὐτῷ κακὸν, ὅπερ ἐπεσημήνατο καὶ Ἱπποκράτης ἐν ἀφορισμοῖς λέγων· ὁκόταν τῆς αὐτῆς ἡμέρης, ὁτὲ μὲν θάλπος, ὁτὲ δὲ ψύχος γίγνηται, φθινοπωρινὰ τὰ νοσήματα προσδέχεσθαι χρή. καὶ τοῦτό ἐστι τὸ μάλιστα νοσῶδες ἐργαζόμενον τὸ φθινόπωρον, ἡ ἀνωμαλία τῆς κράσεως. οὐκ ὀρθῶς οὖν εἴρηται ψυχρὸν καὶ ξηρὸν, οὐ γάρ ἐστι ψυχρὸν αὐτὸ καθ’ αὑτὸ θεωρούμενον, ὥσπερ ὁ χειμὼν, ἀλλὰ τῷ θέρει παραβαλλόμενον, ἐκείνου ψυχρότερον. οὐ μὴν οὐδ’ ὁμαλῶς εὔκρατον, ὡς τὸ ἔαρ, ἀλλ’ ὅτι μάλιστα τούτῳ διενήνοχεν ἐκείνης τῆς ὥρας, ὅτι τὴν εὐκρασίαν τε καὶ τὴν ὁμαλότητα διὰ παντὸς ἴσην οὐ κέκτηται. πολὺ γὰρ θερμότερόν ἐστι κατὰ τὴν μεσημβρίαν, ἢ κατὰ τὴν ἕω τε καὶ τὴν ἑσπέραν. ὑγρότητι δὲ καὶ ξηρότητι μέσον μὲν οὐκ ἔστιν ἀκριβῶς, ὡς τὸ ἔαρ, ἀλλ’ ἐπὶ τὸ ξηρότερον ῥέπει. λείπεται δὲ κᾀν τούτῳ τοῦ θέρους, οὐ μὴν τοσοῦτόν γε, ὅσον θερμότητι. δῆλον οὖν, ὡς οὐδὲ τὸ φθινόπωρον ἁπλῶς οὕτως ῥητέον, ὡς ἐκεῖνοι λέγουσι, ψυχρόν τε εἶναι καὶ ξηρόν.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
So in this respect it is neither simply hot nor simply cold—for it is both, and neither in an extreme. But there is another bad feature attached to it, the very thing Hippocrates marked in the Aphorisms when he said: whenever on the same day now heat, now cold occurs, one must expect autumnal diseases. And this is what makes autumn especially productive of sickness: the irregularity of its mixture [krâsis, “constitution”].

It has not, then, been rightly called “cold and dry.” For it is not cold when considered in itself, like winter, but only in comparison with summer—colder than that season. Nor is it evenly temperate, like spring; rather, it differs from that season as much as possible in that it does not possess temperateness and uniformity [eukrasia and homalotēs] equal throughout. For it is much hotter at midday than in the morning and evening.

In respect of moisture and dryness it is not precisely in the middle, like spring, but inclines toward the drier. In this, too, it falls short of summer, though not so much as in heat.

It is clear, then, that autumn too is not to be described simply—as those people say—as being cold and dry.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

Therefore, in this way it is neither simply hot nor cold, for it is both and neither in the extreme. But there is another harmful quality present in it, which Hippocrates also noted in his Aphorisms, saying: "When during the same day there occurs at times heat and at times cold, one must expect autumnal diseases." And this is what makes autumn especially prone to causing illness: the irregularity of its temperature mixture [krasis]. Thus it has not been correctly described as cold and dry, for it is not cold when considered in itself, like winter is, but only appears colder when compared to summer. Nor indeed is it uniformly well-tempered like spring, but differs most significantly from that season in that it does not maintain an equal good temperature [eukrasia] and uniformity throughout. For it is much warmer at midday than in the morning and evening. Regarding moisture and dryness, it is not precisely in the middle like spring, but tends toward the drier side. In this respect too it falls short of summer, though not by as much as it does in warmth. It is clear, therefore, that autumn should not be described simply, as they do, as being cold and dry.

[Notes: 
- krasis: mixture or temperament, especially of qualities
- eukrasia: good temperature/good mixture, a state of balance]
paragraphs.gemini_translation: Accordingly, in this respect, it is neither simply hot nor cold,

paragraphs.content: ἄκρως μὲν γὰρ οὐδέτερόν ἐστιν, ἐπικρατεῖ δ’ ἐν αὐτῷ τὸ ξηρὸν τοῦ ὑγροῦ. καὶ δικαίως ἂν λεχθείη ταύτῃ μὲν ξηρὸν, ἐν δὲ τῇ κατὰ θερμότητα καὶ ψυχρότητα διαφορᾷ μικτὸν ἐξ ἀμφοῖν καὶ ἀνώμαλον. ὥστ’ εἴπερ τὰς τέσσαρας συζυγίας τῶν κράσεων εἰς τὰς τέσσαρας ὥρας διανεῖμαι σπεύδουσιν, ἴστωσαν οὐ μόνον ἦρι κακῶς προσάψαντες ὑγρότητα καὶ θερμότητα κράσεως, ἀλλὰ καὶ φθινοπώρῳ ψυχρότητα καὶ ξηρότητα. καίτοι γε, εἰ καὶ τοῦτο συνεχωρεῖτο ξηρὸν εἶναι καὶ ψυχρὸν, οὐκ ἦν ἀναγκαῖον εὐθέως, ὑγρὸν εἶναι καὶ θερμὸν τὸ ἔαρ. οὐ γὰρ, εἰ τέτταρες αἱ πᾶσαι συζυγίαι τῶν ἀμέτρων κράσεων εἰσὶν, ἤδη πάσας ἀναγκαῖον εἰς τὰς τέσσαρας ὥρας νενεμῆσθαι.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For it is not absolutely neutral; rather, in it the dry prevails over the moist. And it could rightly be called dry in this respect, while in the distinction according to heat and cold it is mixed from both and irregular. Therefore, if people are keen to distribute the four pairings [syzygies] of mixtures [kraseis = temperaments] among the four seasons, let them recognize that they have wrongly assigned to spring a moist-and-hot temperament, and likewise to autumn a cold-and-dry one. And yet, even if this too were granted to be dry and cold, it would not immediately follow of necessity that spring is moist and hot. For it does not follow that, if there are four total pairings of disproportionate mixtures, all of them must already be apportioned to the four seasons.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

For it is not entirely either one, but in it the dry predominates over the wet. And it would be justly called dry in this respect, while in terms of the distinction between hot and cold it is mixed from both and irregular. Therefore, if they are eager to distribute the four combinations of temperaments [krasis] among the four seasons, let them know that they are not only wrongly attributing wetness and warmth of temperament to spring, but also coldness and dryness to autumn. And yet, even if it were granted that this [autumn] is dry and cold, it would not necessarily follow immediately that spring is wet and warm. For even if there are four total combinations of immoderate temperaments, it is not necessary that all of them must be distributed among the four seasons.

[Notes: 
- "krasis" (κράσις) refers to the mixture or temperament in ancient medical theory
- "combinations" (συζυγίαι) literally means "pairs" or "yokings"
- The text appears to be discussing seasonal qualities and their relationship to the classical theory of four temperaments]
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
For it is not extremely one or the other, but in it the dry prevails over the wet. And so it might justly be called dry in this respect, while in the distinction between hot and cold, it is a mixture of both and irregular. Therefore, if they are eager to assign the four pairings [syzygiai] of the temperaments [kraseis] to the four seasons, let them know that they have wrongly assigned not only the wet and hot temperament to spring, but also the cold and dry one to autumn. And yet, even if it were conceded that this season is dry and cold, it would not immediately be necessary for spring to be wet and hot. For it does not follow that, just because there are four pairings in total of the imbalanced temperaments, it is necessary for all of them to be assigned to the four seasons.

[syzygiai]: Literally "yokings together" or "conjunctions." In this medical and philosophical context, it refers to the four possible pairings of the primary qualities: hot and wet, hot and dry, cold and wet, cold and dry.

[kraseis]: The plural of *krasis*, meaning "mixture," "blending," or "temperament." It refers to the specific balance of the four primary qualities (hot, cold, wet, dry) that constitutes the nature

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ εἴπερ ἄρα τάξις τίς ἐστιν ἐν τῷ κόσμῳ, καὶ κατὰ τὸ βέλτιον, οὐ κατὰ τὸ χεῖρον ἅπαντα κεκόσμηται, πιθανώτερον ἦν, εὐκράτους μὲν τὰς πλείους ὥρας γεγενῆσθαι, μίαν δὲ ἐξ αὐτῶν, εἴπερ ἄρα, τὴν δύσκρατον. οἱ δέ γε τοὐναντίον ἀποδεῖξαι σπεύδουσιν, ὡς οὐδεμία τῶν ὡρῶν ἐστιν εὔκρατος, ἀλλ’ ἐξ ἀνάγκης ἐν αὐταῖς ἐπικρατεῖ νῦν μὲν τὸ θερμὸν, αὖθις δὲ τὸ ψυχρὸν, καὶ νῦν μὲν, εἰ τύχῃ, τὸ ξηρὸν, αὖθις δὲ τὸ ὑγρόν. ἐγὼ δὲ τοσοῦτον ἀποδέω τοῦ ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἀποφαίνειν τὸ ἔαρ, ἢ, ὅ τί περ ἂν εὔκρατον ᾖ, θερμὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν εἶναι συγχωρεῖν, ὥστε πᾶν τοὐναντίον ἀποφαίνομαι, χειρίστην εἶναι κατάστασιν κράσεως τοῦ περιέχοντος ἀέρος τὴν θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν, ἣν ἐν μὲν ταῖς ὥραις οὐκ ἂν εὕροις ὅλως, ἐν δὲ ταῖς νοσώδεσί τε καὶ λοιμώδεσι καταστάσεσιν ἐνίοτε συμπίπτει, καθάπερ που καὶ ὁ Ἱπποκράτης ἐμνημόνευσε, λέγων· ὗεν ἐν καύμασιν ὕδατι λάβρῳ δι’ ὅλου. τοῦτο γάρ ἐστιν ἴδιον ὑγρᾶς καὶ θερμῆς καταστάσεως, ὕειν συνεχῶς ἐν καύμασιν. εἰ δ’ ἤτοι μόνον εἴη καῦμα, καθάπερ ἐπὶ τοῦ κατὰ φύσιν ἔχοντος θέρους, ἢ ὕει μὲν, ἀλλ’ ἐν κρύει, καθάπερ ἐν χειμῶνι, θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν οὐχ οἶόν τε τὴν τοιαύτην εἶναι κατάστασιν. ἆρ’ οὖν ἄνοσον ἐκεῖνο τὸ θέρος, ἐν ᾧ, φησὶν, ὗεν ἐν καύμασιν ὕδατι λάβρῳ δι’ ὅλου; καὶ μὴν ἄνθρακας ἐν αὐτῷ γενέσθαι διηγεῖται, σαπέντων δηλονότι τῶν ἐν τῷ σώματι περιττωμάτων, καί τινας ἰχῶρας θερμοὺς καὶ ὑγροὺς ἀμέτρως γεννησάντων. εἴσῃ δὲ ἐξ αὐτῆς τῆς ῥήσεως, εἰ πᾶσαν αὐτήν σοι παραγράψαιμι, τόνδε τὸν τρόπον ἔχουσαν.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But if indeed there is some order in the cosmos, and all things have been arranged according to the better and not the worse, it would be more plausible that most of the seasons have come to be well-balanced [eukratos], and that one of them, if any, is ill-balanced [dyskrasic]. But they, on the contrary, are eager to prove that none of the seasons is well-balanced, but that of necessity now heat prevails in them, then cold, and now, if it so happens, dryness, and then again moisture. For my part, I am so far from declaring spring to be moist and hot, or from conceding that whatever is well-balanced is hot and moist, that I assert quite the opposite: the worst condition of the mixture [krāsis] of the surrounding air [to periechon] is the hot-and-moist one, which you would not find at all among the seasons, but which sometimes occurs in diseased and pestilential conditions, as Hippocrates, I suppose, also mentioned somewhere, saying: “It rained in periods of heat with scalding water throughout.” For this is characteristic of a moist and hot condition: that it rains continually during heats. But if there were only heat, as in summer when it is in its natural state, or if it rained but in cold, as in winter, such a hot-and-moist condition would not be possible. Was that summer, then, free from disease, in which, he says, “it rained in heats with scalding water throughout”? And indeed he recounts that carbuncles [anthrakes] arose in it, plainly because the superfluities in the body were rotting and produced certain hot and moist ichors in excessive measure. And you will learn from the very passage itself, if I were to transcribe it for
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the passage:

But if indeed there is any order in the cosmos, and all things are arranged according to what is better rather than what is worse, it would have been more plausible that most seasons would be well-tempered, and only one of them, if any, would be ill-tempered. Yet some hasten to demonstrate the opposite, that none of the seasons is well-tempered, but that necessarily in them now heat predominates, then cold, and now, as it happens, dryness, then moisture. I am so far from declaring spring to be moist and hot, or conceding that whatever is well-tempered must be hot and moist, that I declare quite the opposite: that the worst condition of mixture in the surrounding air is that which is hot and moist, which you would not find at all among the seasons, but which sometimes occurs in diseased and pestilential conditions, as Hippocrates somewhere mentioned, saying: "It rained heavily throughout during the heat." For this is characteristic of a hot and moist condition, to rain continuously during heat. If there should be either heat alone, as in natural summer, or if it rains but in cold weather, as in winter, such a condition cannot be both hot and moist. Was that summer then free from disease, in which, he says, "it rained heavily throughout during the heat"? Indeed, he relates that carbuncles [severe skin infections] occurred during it, clearly because the waste products in the body had putrefied and generated certain excessively hot and moist humors. You will know from the passage itself, if I write it out for you in full, which goes as follows.

[Note: The text appears to be a medical-philosophical discussion, likely from Galen, discussing seasonal temperaments and their effects on health, with reference to Hippocratic teachings.]
paragraphs.gemini_translation: But if indeed there is some order in the world, and all things have been arranged for the better and not for the worse, it would have been more plausible for most of the seasons to have been well-tempered [εὐκράτους], and only one of them, if any, ill-tempered. They, however, are eager to demonstrate the contrary: that no season is well-tempered, but of necessity in them now the hot prevails, and then the cold, and now, as it may happen, the dry, and then the wet. I, however, am so far from declaring spring to be hot and wet, or from conceding that whatever is well-tempered must be hot and wet, that I assert the very opposite: that the worst state of temperament [κράσεως] of the surrounding air is the hot and wet one. This is a condition you would not find in the seasons at all, but which sometimes occurs in diseased and pestilential states, just as Hippocrates also mentioned somewhere, saying: “it rained amid heatwaves with torrential water throughout.” For this is the peculiar characteristic of a hot and wet state: to rain continuously amid heatwaves. But if there should be either only a heatwave, as occurs in a natural summer, or if it rains, but in the cold, as in winter, it is not possible for such a state to be hot and wet. Was that summer, then, free from disease, in which, he says, “it rained amid heatwaves with torrential water throughout”? And yet he relates that carbuncles [ἄνθρακας] arose during it, evidently from the putrefaction of the superfluities [περιττωμάτων] in the body, which generated certain hot and wet ichors to an excessive degree. You will understand this from the passage itself, which runs as follows, if I were to write it out for you in its entirety.

paragraphs.content: ἄνθρακες ἐν Κρανῶνι θερινοί. ὗεν ἐν καύμασιν ὕδατι λάβρῳ δι’ ὅλου. ἐγίνοντο δὲ μᾶλλον Νότῳ· καὶ ὑπεγίνοντο μὲν ὑπὸ τὸ δέρμα ἰχῶρες· ἐγκαταλαμβανόμενοι δὲ ἐθερμαίνοντο, καὶ κνησμὸν ἐνεποίεον· εἶτα φλύκταιναι ὥσπερ πυρίκαυστοι ἐπανίσταντο, καὶ ὑπὸ τὸ δέρμα καίεσθαι ἐδόκεον.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Carbuncles at Cranon in summertime. It rained during the heat with torrential water throughout. They appeared rather with a south wind; and ichors [serous discharges] formed beneath the skin. When confined, they grew hot and produced itching; then blisters [phlyktainai] rose up as if from a fire-burn, and they seemed to be burning under the skin.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek passage:

"Carbuncles [skin lesions] occurred in Cranon during summer. It rained heavily throughout the heat waves. They occurred more frequently during the South Wind; and ichorous fluid [watery discharge] formed under the skin; when trapped, it became hot and caused itching; then blisters like burns rose up, and there was a sensation of burning under the skin."

[Note: This appears to be a medical observation, likely from the Hippocratic Corpus, describing an outbreak of skin lesions (ἄνθρακες/carbuncles) and their symptoms in the town of Cranon, with specific attention to weather conditions and clinical presentation.]

The translation aims to preserve the clinical, observational tone of the original Greek while making the medical terminology clear to modern readers.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: Summer carbuncles [literally 'coals'] in Cranon. During periods of great heat, it rained violently and continuously. They occurred more often with the South Wind. Serous fluids [or ichors] would form under the skin; when trapped, they became inflamed and produced itching. Then, blisters like those from a burn would break out, and there was a sensation of burning under the skin.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἐνταῦθα μὲν, ὡς ἂν μιᾶς ὥρας μετακοσμηθείσης, ἧττον τὸ κακόν· εἰ δὲ δύο ἢ τρεῖς ὑπαλλαχθεῖεν, ἢ καὶ σύμπαν τὸ ἔτος ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν γένοιτο, μέγιστον ἀνάγκη συμπεσεῖν οὕτω λοιμὸν, οἶον ἐν τῷ τρίτῳ τῶν ἐπιδημιῶν διηγεῖται. παραγράψω δὲ πρῶτον μὲν ἅ περὶ τῆς τῶν ὡρῶν ἀκοσμίας εἶπεν, ἐφεξῆς δὲ καὶ τὰ περὶ τῆς ἐπιγινομένης φθορᾶς τῶν ἀνθρώπων. ἐν ἅπασι δ’ αὐτοῖς προσέχειν σε τὸν νοῦν ἀκριβῶς ἀξιῶ καὶ σκοπεῖσθαι, πρῶτον μὲν, ὁποῖόν τι πρᾶγμα θερμὴ καὶ ὑγρὰ κρᾶσίς ἐστιν, ὡς οὐδὲν ἦρι παρόμοιον, εὐκράτῳ χρήματι· δεύτερον δὲ, ὡς ἀναγκαῖον ἐν αὐτῇ σήπεσθαι πάντα. ἄρχεται μὲν οὖν ὁ Ἱπποκράτης τῆς διηγήσεως ὧδε. ἔτος νότιον, ἔπομβρον, ἄπνοια διὰ τέλεος. εἶτα τούτοις ἐπιφέρει τὰ κατὰ μέρος ἁπάσης τῆς καταστάσεως, ὄμβρους πολλοὺς ἐν θερμῇ καὶ νοτίᾳ καταστάσει γενέσθαι γράφων, εἶτ’ αὖθις τὸν σύμπαντα λόγον εἰς ἕν ἐπὶ τέλει κεφάλαιον ἀγαγὼν οὕτως. γενομένου δὲ τοῦ ἔτεος ὅλου, φησὶ, νοτίου, καὶ ὑγροῦ, καὶ μαλακοῦ, τάδε καὶ τάδε συνέπεσεν, ἃ ξύμπαντα μὲν ἀναγράφειν ἐν τῷδε τῷ λόγῳ μακρόν· ἔνεστι δὲ τῷ βουλομένῳ, λαβόντι τὸ τρίτον τῶν ἐπιδημιῶν, ἀναγινώσκειν τὰ κατὰ μέρος, εἰς ἕν ἅπαντα κεφάλαιον ἀναγόμενα, σηπεδόνα μεγίστην, ἧς καὶ αὐτῆς ὀνομαστὶ πολλάκις ὁ Ἱπποκράτης ἐπιμέμνηται, ποτὲ μὲν ὡδί πως λέγων· ἦν δὲ καὶ τὸ ῥεῦμα τὸ συνιστάμενον οὐ πύῳ ἴκελον, ἀλλὰ σηπεδών τις ἄλλη, καὶ ῥεῦμα πολὺ καὶ ποικίλον· ὁτὲ δὲ πάλιν ὡδί· καὶ ἐν αἰδοίοισιν ἄνθρακες οἱ κατὰ θέρος, καὶ ἄλλα, ἃ σῆψις καλέεται, καὶ ὡς ἐκ τῆς σήψεως ταύτης πολλοῖσι μὲν βραχίων καὶ πῆχυς ὅλως ἀπεῤῥύη, πολλοῖσι δὲ μηρὸς ἢ τὰ περὶ τὴν κνήμην ἀπεψιλοῦτο, καὶ ποῦς ὅλος.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
But here, since only one season has been rearranged, the harm is less; but if two or three were altered, or if the whole year should turn out moist and hot, it is necessary that in this way the greatest plague occur, such as he recounts in the third book of the Epidemics. I shall first set down what he said about the disorder of the seasons, and next in order the matters concerning the destruction that comes upon human beings. And in all these I ask you to pay close attention and consider: first, what sort of thing a hot and moist mixture [krāsis: bodily “temperament” or blend of qualities] is, as being in no way like spring, which is a well-balanced condition [eukratos: “temperate”]; second, how it is necessary that in it everything putrefy.

Hippocrates begins his account thus: “A year southerly, rainy, windless throughout.” Then to these he adds the particulars of the whole condition, writing that many showers occurred in a warm and damp state;
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek passage:

But in this case, when only one season is disturbed, the harm is less. However, if two or three seasons should be altered, or if the entire year should become wet and hot, it becomes necessary that a very great plague occurs, such as he describes in the third book of the Epidemics. I shall first write down what he said about the disorder of the seasons, and then in sequence, about the resulting destruction of people. I ask you to pay careful attention to all these matters and to consider, first, what sort of thing a hot and wet mixture is, how it is nothing like spring, which is a well-tempered thing; and second, how in such conditions everything necessarily putrefies. 

Hippocrates begins his account thus: "The year was southerly [characterized by south winds], rainy, and completely windless." Then he adds to these the particular details of the entire condition, writing that many rains occurred during a hot and southerly state, and then again bringing the whole account together into one final summary thus: "The whole year," he says, "being southerly, wet, and mild, the following things occurred..." – to write all of these things in this account would be lengthy. But it is possible for anyone who wishes, taking the third book of the Epidemics, to read the particulars, all of which lead to one main point: the greatest putrefaction, which Hippocrates himself mentions by name many times, sometimes speaking thus: "And the fluid that collected was not like pus, but was some other kind of putrefaction, and the discharge was abundant and varied." And again elsewhere thus: "And there were carbuncles in the private parts during summer, and other conditions which are called putrefaction," and how from this putrefaction, for many people the arm and forearm completely fell away, and for many the thigh or the parts around the shin were stripped bare, and the entire foot.

[Note: "Epidemics" refers to Hippocrates' work describing diseases occurring in particular places and times, not necessarily what we would call epidemics today]
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ καὶ ὀστῶν, καὶ σαρκῶν, καὶ νεύρων, καὶ ἄρθρων ἐκπτώσεις ἐγίγνοντο μεγάλαι. καὶ ὅλως οὐδέν ἐστιν εὑρεῖν ὧν ἔγραψε παθημάτων, ὃ μὴ σηπεδόνος ἔγγονον ὑπάρχει, δεόντως. οὔτε γὰρ ὑπὸ τοῦ ξηροῦ τι σήπεσθαι πέφυκεν, οὔθ’ ὑπὸ τοῦ ψυχροῦ. μάθοις δ’ ἂν, εἰ θεάσαιο τά τε κρέα καὶ τὰ ἄλλα σύμπαντα τὰ πρὸς τῶν ἀνθρώπων ταριχευόμενα, τὰ μὲν ἁλσὶ, τὰ δ’ ἅλμῃ, τὰ δ’ ὄξει, τὰ δ’ ἄλλῳ τινὶ τῶν ξηραινόντων σκευαζόμενα καλῶς. μάθοις δὲ καὶ ὡς ἐν τῷ βοῤῥᾷ, ξηρῷ καὶ ψυχρῷ τὴν φύσιν ὑπάρχοντι, ἄσηπτα μέχρι πλεῖστον διαμένει πάντα· σήπεται δ’ ἑτοίμως ταῖς νοτίαις καταστάσεσιν. ἔστι γὰρ οὖν καὶ οὗτος ὁ ἄνεμος ὑγρὸς καὶ θερμός. ὥστε πᾶν τοὐναντίον ἡμεῖς ἀποφαινόμεθα τοῖς ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ὑπολαμβάνουσιν εἶναι τὸ ἔαρ. οὔτε γὰρ τοιοῦτό ἐστιν, οὔθ’ ὑγιεινὸν ἂν ἦν, εἴπερ ἦν τοιοῦτο. οἱ δὲ καὶ τοιοῦτο εἶναί φασιν αὐτὸ, καὶ διὰ τοῦθ’ ὑγιεινὸν ὑπάρχειν, ἐν ἀμφοτέροις ἁμαρτάνοντες, ὅσα τε ταῖς αἰσθήσεσιν ἔνεστι διαγνῶναι, καὶ ὅσα τῷ λόγῳ διασκέψασθαι. ταῖς μὲν γὰρ αἰσθήσεσιν ἔνεστιν ἐναργῶς μαθεῖν εὔκρατον ἀκριβῶς αὐτὸ, τῷ λόγῳ δ’ ἐξευρεῖν, ὡς διὰ τοῦτ’ ἔστιν ὑγιεινὸν, διότι μηδὲν ἐν αὐτῷ τῶν τεττάρων ἐπικρατεῖ. εἰ δέ γ’ ἤτοι τὸ θερμὸν ἐπεκράτει πολλῷ τοῦ ψυχροῦ, ἢ τὸ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ, σηπεδόνων τε ἂν ἦν εὔφορον οὕτω καὶ πασῶν τῶν ὡρῶν νοσωδέστατον.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But there also occurred great dislocations of bones, and of flesh, and of sinews, and of joints. And in general there is nothing to be found among the ailments he described that is not, properly speaking, a child of putrefaction [σήπεδον: decay/putrefaction]. For nothing is by nature wont to rot because of dryness, nor because of cold. You would learn this, if you looked at meats and all other things that people preserve [ταριχεύειν: cure/embalm], some with dry salt, some with brine, some with vinegar, and others prepared well with some other drying agents. You would also learn how, in the north [Βορέας: the north wind/quarter], where the nature of the air is dry and cold, all things remain unspoiled for the longest time; whereas they rot readily under south-wind conditions. For this wind too is moist and warm. Accordingly we maintain the exact opposite of those who suppose that spring is moist and warm. For it is neither such as that, nor would it be healthful if it were. Yet they say it is such, and on that account healthful—thus erring in both respects: both in what can be determined by the senses and in what can be examined by reasoning. For by the senses one can plainly learn that it is precisely well-tempered [εὔκρατον: balanced in qualities], and by reasoning discover that it is for this reason healthful: because in it none of the four [qualities—hot, cold, moist, dry] predominates. If, however, either the hot greatly prevailed over the cold, or the moist over the dry, it would thus be a fertile season for putrefactions and the most disease-ridden of all the seasons.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

But there were also severe separations of bones, flesh, sinews, and joints. And in general, one cannot find among the afflictions he described any that is not a product of putrefaction, and rightfully so. For nothing naturally putrefies due to dryness, nor due to cold. You might learn this if you were to observe meats and all other things that are preserved by humans - some with salt, some in brine, some in vinegar, and some prepared well with other drying agents. You might also learn how in the north wind, which is by nature dry and cold, all things remain unspoiled for the longest time; but they readily putrefy in southerly conditions. For indeed this wind [the south wind] is moist and warm. Therefore, we declare the complete opposite to those who suppose that spring is moist and warm. For it is neither such, nor would it be healthy if it were such. But they claim both that it is such and that it is healthy for this reason, erring in both respects - both in what can be discerned by the senses and what can be examined by reason. For by the senses one can clearly learn that it [spring] is precisely well-tempered [eukraton], and by reason one can discover that it is healthy because none of the four [qualities/elements] predominates in it. If either the hot greatly predominated over the cold, or the moist over the dry, it would thus be conducive to putrefaction and the most disease-prone of all seasons.

[Notes:
- "eukraton" refers to a balanced or well-tempered state
- "the four" refers to the classical four qualities (hot, cold, wet, dry) or elements]

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἡ τῆς τῶν τεττάρων κράσεων ἰσομοιρία τῆς τε εὐκρασίας αὐτοῦ καὶ τῆς ὑγιείας αἰτία. πόθεν οὖν ἐπῆλθέ τισιν ἰατροῖς τε καὶ φιλοσόφοις ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἀποφῄνασθαι τὸ ἔαρ; ἐκ τοῦ βουληθῆναι δηλονότι τὰς τέτταρας συζυγίας τῶν κράσεων εἰς τὰς τέτταρας ὥρας διανεῖμαι. τοῦτο δ’ αὐτὸ πάλιν ἐκ τοῦ παραλιπεῖν τὴν πρώτην ἁπασῶν, τὴν εὔκρατον, ἐγένετο. καὶ γὰρ οὖν καὶ διαιτημάτων, καὶ φαρμάκων, ἁπάντων τε τῶν ὄντων, εἰς τὰς τέτταρας ταύτας συζυγίας ἀνάγουσι τὰς διαφοράς.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But the equal apportionment of the four mixtures is the cause both of its well-tempered state [eukrasia, “good mixture”] and of health. How then did it occur to certain physicians and philosophers to declare that spring is moist and warm? From their manifest wish to distribute the four pairings [syzygies] of the mixtures among the four seasons. And this, in turn, came about from their having left out the first of all—the well-tempered one. For they even refer the differences of regimens [diaitēmata], and of drugs, and indeed of all existing things, to these four pairings.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

But the equal distribution of the four temperaments [kraseis] is the cause of both its good temperament and health. So how did it occur to certain doctors and philosophers to declare spring as wet and hot? Clearly from their wish to distribute the four pairs of temperaments among the four seasons. And this itself, in turn, came about from their omitting the first of all temperaments - the well-balanced one. And indeed, they reduce the differences of regimens, medicines, and all existing things to these four pairs.

[Notes: 
- krasis/kraseis refers to the medical theory of bodily temperaments or mixtures
- "well-balanced" (eukraton) refers to the ideal balanced temperament
- "pairs" (suzugias) refers to paired combinations of qualities (hot/cold, wet/dry)]

The translation maintains the argumentative structure of the original while preserving technical medical terminology familiar from Hippocratic and Galenic texts.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: But the equal proportion of the four temperaments is the cause of both its well-tempered state [eukrasia] and its health. How then did it occur to some physicians and philosophers to declare spring to be wet and hot? Clearly, from their wish to distribute the four pairings [syzygies] of the temperaments among the four seasons. And this, in turn, came about from their omitting the first of all [temperaments], the well-tempered one. And so, in fact, they reduce the differences of regimens, of drugs, and of all existing things to these four pairings.

paragraphs.content: Ὧι καὶ δῆλον, εἰς ὅσον οἱ περὶ φύσεως ἀνθρώπου λογισμοὶ, σφαλέντες τῆς ἀληθείας, εἰς τὰς ἰάσεις βλάπτουσι, καὶ βέλτιόν ἐστι δυοῖν θάτερον, ἢ μηδ’ ὅλως ἅπτεσθαι τῶν τοιούτων λόγων, ἀλλ’ ἐπιτρέψαι τῇ πείρᾳ τὸ πᾶν, ἢ πρότερον ἐν τῇ λογικῇ θεωρίᾳ γυμνάσασθαι. τὸ δὲ μήτε τῇ πείρᾳ προσέχειν τὸν νοῦν, ἐπιχειρεῖν τε θεωρίᾳ φυσικῇ πρὸ τοῦ τὸν λογισμὸν, ᾧ μέλλοιμεν εὑρίσκειν αὐτὴν, ἀσκῆσαι πρεπόντως, ἀναγκαῖον ἀπάγειν εἰς τὰ τοιαῦτα σοφίσματα, καὶ περί γε τῶν φαινομένων ὡς ἀναισθήτους ἀναγκάζει διαλέγεσθαι, μάρτυρά τε καλεῖν Ἀριστοτέλη, παρακούοντας ὧν διδάσκει. πολλαχῶς γὰρ ἐκεῖνος οἶδε καὶ τὸ θερμὸν λεγόμενον, καὶ τὸ ψυχρὸν, καὶ τὸ ξηρὸν, καὶ τὸ ὑγρόν· οἱ δ’ οὐκ ἀκούουσιν αὐτοῦ πολλαχῶς, ἀλλ’ ὡσαύτως ἀεί. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ ὡς οὐ ταὐτό ἐστιν, ἢ οἰκείῳ τινὶ καὶ συμφύτῳ θερμῷ θερμὸν ὑπάρχειν, ἢ ἐπικτήτῳ καὶ ἀλλοτρίῳ, διῆλθεν Ἀριστοτέλης· οἱ δέ γε καὶ τούτου παρακούουσιν. ἔτι τε πρὸς τούτοις ὁ μὲν Ἀριστοτέλης, ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ ὁ Θεόφραστος, ἐς ὅ τι χρὴ βλέποντας ἢ εὔκρατον ἢ δύσκρατον ὑπολαμβάνειν εἶναι τὴν φύσιν, ἀκριβῶς εἰρήκασιν. οἱ δ’ οὐδὲ τοῦτο γινώσκουσιν, ἀλλ’ ὅταν ἀκούσωσι λεγόντων αὐτῶν, ὑγρὸν εἶναι καὶ θερμὸν τὸ ζῶον, ἢ τὴν τοῦ παιδὸς κρᾶσιν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, οὔθ’ ὅπως εἴρηται ταῦτα συνίασιν, ἐμπλήκτως τε μεταφέρουσι τὸν λόγον ἐπὶ τὰς ὥρας, ὥσπερ ταὐτὸ ὂν, ἀλλ’ οὐ μακρῷ διαφέρον, ἢ τὴν οἰκείαν κρᾶσιν ὑγρὰν εἶναι καὶ θερμὴν, ἢ τὴν τοῦ περιέχοντος ἡμᾶς ἀέρος. οὔτε γὰρ ταὐτό ἐστιν οὔθ’ ὁμοίως ὑγρὰ καὶ θερμὴ ζώου κρᾶσις ἀέρος ὑγρᾷ καὶ θερμῇ κράσει λέγεται. τί δ’ ἦν τὸ τούτων ἁπάντων αἴτιον, ἤδη διηγήσομαι, καὶ δείξω σαφῶς τοῖς προσέχειν τὸν νοῦν βουλομένοις, ὡς μικρὰ πταίσματα τῶν ἐν ἀρχῇ τῆς λογικῆς θεωρίας διδασκομένων αἴτια μεγίστων ἁμαρτημάτων γίνεται, καὶ κινδυνεύει πάντα τὰ κακῶς πραττόμενα κατά τε τὰς τέχνας ἁπάσας καὶ μέντοι καὶ κατὰ τὰς ἐν τῷ βίῳ πράξεις ἕπεσθαι σοφίσμασιν. ἕπεται τοιγαροῦν καὶ τάδε τὰ σοφίσματα τῷ μὴ διελέσθαι περὶ τῶν σημαινομένων ὀρθῶς. ἀλλ’ οἰηθῆναι τὸ θερμὸν λέγεσθαι διχῶς, τὸ μὲν ὡς ἄκρατον καὶ ἄμικτον καὶ ἁπλοῦν, τὸ δὲ ὡς ἐν τῇ πρὸς τὸ ἐναντίον ἐπιμιξίᾳ πλεονεκτοῦν.

paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is my translation of the Greek paragraph:

From this it is clear how theories about human nature, when they stray from truth, cause harm in medical treatments, and it is better to choose one of two options: either to not engage with such theories at all but entrust everything to experience, or to first train oneself in logical theory. For to neither pay attention to experience nor properly train the reasoning by which we might discover natural theory before attempting it, necessarily leads to such sophistries, and compels one to discuss apparent phenomena as if senseless, and to call upon Aristotle as witness while misinterpreting what he teaches. For he recognizes many different ways of speaking about the hot, the cold, the dry, and the wet; but they do not understand his multiple meanings, instead taking them always in the same way. Indeed, Aristotle explained how being hot through some innate and natural heat is not the same as being hot through acquired and foreign heat; but they misinterpret this too. Furthermore, both Aristotle and likewise Theophrastus have precisely explained what one must look to when considering whether a nature is well-tempered or poorly-tempered. But they don't understand even this; rather, when they hear them saying that an animal is wet and hot, or that a child's temperament is wet and hot, they neither comprehend how these things are meant, and foolishly transfer the discussion to the seasons, as if it were the same thing and not vastly different whether one's own temperament is wet and hot or whether the air surrounding us is. For it is neither the same nor similarly meant when an animal's temperament is called wet and hot as when air's temperament is called wet and hot. And now I shall explain what was the cause of all these errors, and clearly show to those willing to pay attention how small mistakes in what is taught at the beginning of logical theory become causes of the greatest errors, and it appears that all things done badly, both in all the arts and indeed in life's activities, follow from sophistries. These sophistries therefore follow from not correctly distinguishing between different meanings, but thinking that "hot" is spoken of in only two ways: either as unmixed and pure and simple, or as predominating in mixture with its opposite.

[Note: Technical terms like "temperament" (κρᾶσις) and "sophistries" (σοφίσματα) are preserved as they represent specific philosophical/medical concepts in ancient Greek thought]

paragraphs.content: ὅτι δὲ καὶ παραβάλλοντες ἑτέρᾳ κράσει πολλάκις ἑτέραν ἀποφαινόμεθα τὴν ἑτέραν αὐτῶν εἶναι θερμὴν, ἐπιλανθάνονται καὶ τοῦδε. καὶ μὴν οὕτω τὰ ζῶα θερμὰ καὶ ὑγρὰ λέγεται πρὸς τῶν παλαιῶν, οὐ κατὰ τὴν ἰδίαν κρᾶσιν ἁπλῶς, ἀλλὰ τοῖς γε φυτοῖς καὶ τοῖς τεθνεῶσι παραβαλλόμενα. καὶ γὰρ τῶν τεθνεώτων ζῶα καὶ τῶν φυτῶν ἐστι θερμότερα καὶ ὑγρότερα. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ τῶν ζώων αὐτῶν ἀλλήλοις κατ’ εἴδη παραβαλλομένων, ξηρότερον μὲν ὁ κύων, ὑγρότερον δὲ ὁ ἄνθρωπος. εἰ δὲ μύρμηκι καὶ μελίττῃ παραβάλλοις τὸν κύνα, ξηρότερα μὲν ἐκεῖνα, τὸν κύνα δ’ ὑγρότερον εὑρήσεις. ὥστε ταὐτὸ ζῶον ξηρὸν μὲν ὡς πρὸς ἄνθρωπον ὑπάρχειν, ὑγρὸν δ’ ὡς πρὸς μέλιτταν· οὕτω δὲ καὶ θερμὸν μὲν, ὡς πρὸς ἄνθρωπον, ψυχρὸν δ’, ὡς πρὸς λέοντα. καὶ θαυμαστὸν οὐδὲν, εἰ τὸ πρὸς ἕτερόν τι λεγόμενον τὰς ἐναντίας ἅμα κατηγορίας ἐπιδέχεται. οὐ γὰρ τοῦτ’ ἄτοπον, εἰ ταὐτὸ σῶμα θερμὸν ἅμα λέγεται καὶ ψυχρὸν, ἀλλ’ εἰ καὶ πρὸς ταὐτό. οὐ γὰρ, ὅτι δεξιὸς ἅμα καὶ ἀριστερὸς ὁ αὐτὸς ἄνθρωπος, ἄτοπον· εἰ δέ γε πρὸς ἄλλον μὲν δεξιὸς, πρὸς ἄλλον δὲ ἀριστερὸς, οὐδὲν ἄτοπον. οὕτως οὖν καὶ κύων ὑγρὸς ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸς, καὶ θερμὸς ἅμα καὶ ψυχρὸς ἀλλ’ οὐ πρὸς ταὐτό· πρὸς μὲν γὰρ ἄνθρωπον ξηρὸς, ὑγρὸς δ’ ὡς πρὸς μύρμηκα, καὶ πρὸς μὲν ἄνθρωπον θερμὸς, ψυχρὸς δ’ ὡς πρὸς λέοντα. καὶ γὰρ δὴ καὶ θερμὸς μὲν, ὡς ζῶν· εἰ γάρ τι τέθνηκεν, οὐ θερμόν· οὐ θερμὸς δ’ ὡς πρὸς ἕτερον, εἰ οὕτως ἔτυχε, κύνα. ταυτὶ μὲν οὖν ἅπαντα πρὸς ἄλληλα ἐκ παραβολῆς λέγεται, τὰ δ’ ὡς ἐν ζώων γένει καθ’ ἕτερον τρόπον, ὥσπερ αὖ καὶ κατ’ εἶδος ζώου. κύων γὰρ, ὡς πρὸς μὲν μύρμηκα καὶ μέλιτταν, ὑγρὸς, ὡς δ’ ἐν ζώων γένει, ξηρός. αὐτῶν δὲ τῶν κυνῶν κατ’ εἶδος, ὁδὶ μὲν ξηρὸς, ὁδὶ δὲ ὑγρὸς, ἄλλος δέ τις, ὡς κύων, εὔκρατος.
paragraphs.openai_translation: That they also, when comparing by reference to a different “mixture” [krâsis: the composite balance of qualities], often declare one of a pair to be hot, they forget this as well. Indeed, the ancients call living creatures hot and moist, not simply in accordance with their own intrinsic mixture, but in comparison with plants and with the dead. For animals are hotter and moister than both corpses and plants. And again, if among animals themselves you compare them with one another by kinds, the dog is drier, while the human being is moister. But if you compare the dog with an ant or a bee, you will find those to be drier and the dog to be moister. Hence the same animal is dry in relation to a human being, but moist in relation to a bee; and likewise hot in relation to a human being, but cold in relation to a lion. There is nothing surprising if what is said in relation to something else admits opposite predicates at once. It is not absurd that the same body should be called both hot and cold at the same time—what would be absurd is if it were so in relation to the same thing. For it is not absurd that the same person is both right and left; but if he is right in relation to one person and left in relation to another, there is nothing absurd in that. So too a dog is at once moist and dry, and at once hot and cold—but not in relation to the same thing: in relation to a human being he is dry, but moist in relation to an ant; and hot in relation to a human being, but cold in relation to a lion. For indeed he is hot, insofar as he is living—for if something is dead, it is not hot—but he is not hot in relation to another, if it so happens, say in relation to a dog. All such statements are made comparatively, in relation to one another; whereas those made “as within the genus of animals” are made in a different way, just as also at the level of a species of animal. For a dog, in relation to an ant and a bee, is moist, but as within the genus of animals he is dry. And among dogs themselves, by species, this one is dry, that one is moist, while another, as a dog, is well-mixed [eúkrasos: balanced in temperament].
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the passage:

They also forget this point: that when comparing one mixture [krasis] to another, we often declare one of them to be hot in relation to the other. Indeed, this is how animals are called hot and moist by the ancients - not simply according to their own mixture, but when compared to plants and dead things. For animals are both hotter and moister than dead things and plants. Moreover, when comparing different species of animals to each other, the dog is drier, while the human is moister. But if you compare a dog to an ant or a bee, you will find those creatures drier, and the dog moister. Thus the same animal can be dry in relation to a human, but moist in relation to a bee; similarly, it can be hot compared to a human, but cold compared to a lion.

And there is nothing surprising if something described in relation to something else can simultaneously accept opposite predicates. For it is not absurd that the same body is called both hot and cold at the same time, but only if it were so in relation to the same thing. Just as it is not absurd that the same person is both right and left - if one is right in relation to one person and left in relation to another, there is nothing absurd in this. Thus a dog is simultaneously moist and dry, and hot and cold, but not in relation to the same thing: it is dry compared to a human, but moist compared to an ant, and hot compared to a human, but cold compared to a lion.

Indeed, it is hot insofar as it is living (for if something is dead, it is not hot), but not hot compared to another dog, if that happens to be the case. All these qualities are thus spoken of in relation to each other by comparison, while others are spoken of differently within the genus of animals, and again according to the species of animal. For a dog, compared to an ant or bee, is moist, but within the genus of animals, it is dry. And among dogs themselves according to species, this one is dry, that one is moist, and another, as a dog, is well-balanced [eukratos].

[Note: krasis refers to the mixture or temperament of qualities in ancient medical theory]

paragraphs.content: Λέλεκται μὲν οὖν ἐπὶ πλεῖστον ἡμῖν ὑπὲρ ἁπάσης τῆς τοιαύτης χρήσεως τῶν ὀνομάτων ἐν δευτέρῳ περὶ διαγνώσεως σφυγμῶν. ἀνάγκη δὲ, ὡς ἔοικεν, εἰπεῖν τι καὶ νῦν ὑπὲρ αὐτῶν διὰ κεφαλαίων, ὅσον εἰς τὰ παρόντα χρήσιμον. τὸ μὲν ἁπλῶς ξηρὸν, ὃ πρὸς μηδὲν ἕτερον λέγεται, μόνοις τοῖς στοιχείοις ὑπάρχει, πυρί τε καὶ γῇ· καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ τὸ ὑγρὸν ὕδατι καὶ ἀέρι. κατὰ ταὐτὰ δὲ καὶ περὶ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ χρὴ νοεῖν. οὐδὲν γὰρ τῶν ἄλλων σωμάτων ἀκριβῶς οὔτε θερμὸν οὔτε ψυχρόν ἐστιν, ἀλλ’ ἢ τὰ στοιχεῖα μόνον.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, we have for the most part discussed the whole of this kind of usage of the terms in the second [book] On the Diagnosis of Pulses. Yet, as it seems, it is necessary to say something about them now as well, in outline [i.e., briefly and by headings], so far as is useful for the present. What is “dry” in the absolute sense—said not in relation to anything else—belongs only to the elements [stoicheia], namely to fire and earth; and likewise “wet” to water and air. One must think in the same way about “hot” and “cold.” For none of the other bodies is precisely either hot or cold—only the elements are.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

We have already discussed at length the entire matter of such usage of terms in the second book on the diagnosis of pulses. But it seems necessary to say something about them now too, in summary form, as much as is useful for the present discussion. That which is simply dry, which is not spoken of in relation to anything else, belongs only to the elements, to fire and earth; and indeed likewise, wetness belongs to water and air. And in the same way one must think about hot and cold. For none of the other bodies is precisely either hot or cold, but only the elements are.

[Notes on technical terms:
- "diagnosis of pulses" (διαγνώσεως σφυγμῶν) refers to the medical practice of pulse examination
- "elements" (στοιχεῖα) refers to the classical four elements: fire, earth, water, and air]

The translation preserves the medical-philosophical context of the passage, which appears to be discussing the fundamental qualities of elements and their relationship to temperature and moisture, a common topic in ancient medical and natural philosophical texts.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: Now, we have discussed at greatest length all such use of these terms in the second book of *On the Diagnosis of Pulses*. However, it seems necessary to say something about them now as well, in summary, to the extent that it is useful for our present purpose. That which is absolutely dry, which is so called not in relation to anything else, belongs only to the elements [στοιχεῖα: the fundamental components of matter, i.e., fire, earth, water, and air], to fire and to earth; and likewise, that which is wet belongs to water and air. And one must think in the same way concerning the hot and the cold. For none of the other bodies is, in the strict sense, either hot or cold; only the elements are.

paragraphs.content: ὅ τι δ’ ἂν τῶν ἄλλων λάβῃς, ἐκ τούτων κέκραται, καὶ διὰ τοῦτο τὸ δεύτερον σημαινόμενον οὐκ ἔθ’ ἁπλῶς θερμὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν, ὡς ἄμικτόν τε καὶ εἰλικρινὲς, ἀλλ’ ὡς ἤτοι πλέονος μὲν τοῦ θερμοῦ, τοῦ ψυχροῦ δ’ ἐλάττονος, ἢ τοῦ μὲν ψυχροῦ πλέονος, ἐλάττονος δὲ τοῦ θερμοῦ μετέχον, ἕκαστον τῶν ἄλλων ἢ θερμὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν λέγεται. δύο μὲν δὴ ταῦτα σημαινόμενα τοῦ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ, καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ· τὸ μὲν, ἁπλῶς λεγόντων ἡμῶν, ἄμικτόν τε καὶ εἰλικρινές· ἕτερον δὲ, μικτὸν μὲν ἐκ τῶν ἐναντίων, ἀλλὰ τῷ τοῦ πλεονεκτοῦντος ὀνόματι προσαγορευόμενον. οὕτως μὲν οὖν ὑγρὸν αἷμα, καὶ φλέγμα, καὶ πιμελὴ, καὶ οἶνος, ἔλαιόν τε καὶ μέλι, καὶ τῶν ἄλλων τῶν τοιούτων ἕκαστον λέγεται. ὀστᾶ δὲ καὶ χόνδροι, καὶ ὄνυχες, καὶ ὁπλαὶ, καὶ κέρατα, καὶ τρίχες, καὶ λίθοι, καὶ ξύλα, καὶ ψάμμος, καὶ κέραμος, ἐλάττονα μὲν ὑγροῦ μοῖραν ἕχει, πλείονα δὲ ξηροῦ, καὶ διὰ τοῦτο πάλιν ἅπαντα τὰ τοιαῦτα ξηρὰ προσαγορεύεται. μύρμηξ δὲ ξηρὸν, καὶ σκώληξ ὑγρὸν, ὡς ζῶα. καὶ πάλιν ἐν αὐτοῖς τοῖς σκώληξιν ὁδὶ μὲν ξηρότερος, ὁδὶ δὲ ὑγρότερος, ἢ ἁπλῶς ὡς σκώληξ, ἢ τῷδέ τινι παραβαλλόμενος ἑτέρῳ. αὐτὸ δὲ τοῦτο τί δή ποτέ ἐστιν, ὅταν οὕτως λέγωμεν, ὡς σκώληξ ξηρὸς, ὡς ἄνθρωπος θερμὸς, ὡς κύων ψυχρὸς, εἰ μή τις ἀκριβῶς ἀκούσειέ τε καὶ νοήσειε πρότερον, ἀνάγκη συγκεχύσθαι τὸν λόγον ἅπαντα. τὸ δ’ ἀκριβῶς ἐστιν, ὃ κᾀν τῷ δευτέρῳ περὶ τῆς τῶν σφυγμῶν διαγνώσεως λέγεται, τὸ κατὰ γένος ἢ εἶδος ὀνομάζεσθαι τηνικαῦθ’ ἕκαστον, οὐ θερμὸν μόνον, ἢ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ξηρὸν, ἢ ὑγρὸν, ἀλλὰ καὶ μέγα, καὶ μικρὸν, καὶ βραδὺ, καὶ ταχὺ, καὶ τῶν τοιούτων ἕκαστον, ὅταν ὑπὲρ τὸ σύμμετρόν τε καὶ μέσον ᾖ, ἢ ζῶον θερμὸν, ὅταν ὑπὲρ τὸ μέσον ᾖ τῇ κράσει ζῶον, ἢ ἵππος θερμὸς, ὅταν ὑπὲρ τὸν μέσον ἵππον ᾖ. τὰ δ’ ἐν ἑκάστῳ γένει τε καὶ εἴδει μέσα τὰ σύμμετρά ἐστιν.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
Whatever else you take, it is compounded out of these, and for this reason the second way of signifying [i.e., of predication] no longer calls a thing simply hot or cold, as though unmixed and pure, but as sharing either in a greater portion of the hot and a lesser of the cold, or in a greater of the cold and a lesser of the hot; in this way, each of the other things is called either hot or cold. Thus there are two modes of signifying hot and cold, and dry and moist: the one, when we speak simply, [means] unmixed and pure; the other, [means] mixed from the contraries, yet designated by the name of that which predominates.

In this way, then, blood is called moist, and phlegm, and fat, and wine, and oil and honey, and each of the other things of that sort. But bones and cartilages, nails, hooves, horns, hairs, stones, woods, sand, and potsherd have a lesser portion of the moist and a greater of the dry, and for this reason again all such things are designated “dry.” An ant is dry, and a worm moist, as living things. And again, among the worms themselves, this one is drier, that one moister—either absolutely as a worm, or when compared with some other. But what exactly is meant when we speak in this way—“a dry worm,” “a hot human being,” “a cold dog”—unless one first hears and understands accurately, it is inevitable that the whole discussion be confused. And what “accurately” means is what is also said in the second [book] On the Diagnosis of Pulses: that each thing is to be named then according to genus or species—not only as hot, or cold, or dry, or moist, but also as large, small, slow, fast, and each of such [qualitative] terms—whenever it is beyond the proportionate and mean; or “a hot animal,” whenever the animal is beyond the mean in its mixture [krasis, i.e., temperament]; or “a hot horse,” whenever it is beyond the mean horse. For in every genus and species, the means are the proportionate things.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is my translation of the Greek paragraph:

Whatever else you take is mixed from these, and for this reason the second meaning is no longer simply hot or cold, as unmixed and pure, but rather as participating in either more of the hot and less of the cold, or more of the cold and less of the hot - each of the other things is called either hot or cold. These then are two meanings of hot and cold, and of dry and wet: the first, when we speak simply, refers to the unmixed and pure; the second to what is mixed from opposites but named after the predominant quality.

Thus blood, phlegm, fat, wine, oil, honey, and each of such other things are called wet. But bones, cartilage, nails, hooves, horns, hair, stones, wood, sand, and pottery contain a lesser portion of wet and a greater portion of dry, and therefore all such things are called dry. An ant is dry and a worm is wet, as animals. And again among worms themselves, this one is drier and that one wetter, either simply as a worm or when compared to some other.

But what exactly does it mean when we say "dry as a worm," "hot as a human," or "cold as a dog"? Unless one understands and comprehends this precisely, the whole discussion necessarily becomes confused. The precise meaning, as is also stated in the second book On the Diagnosis of Pulses, is that each thing is named according to its genus or species at that time - not just hot or cold or dry or wet, but also large and small and slow and fast and each such quality - whenever it exceeds the symmetrical and middle state. So an animal is hot when it exceeds the middle state in its temperament as an animal, or a horse is hot when it exceeds the middle state for a horse. The middle states in each genus and species are the symmetrical ones.

[Note: "temperament" translates krasis, referring to the mixture or balance of qualities]
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
But whatever else you take is a mixture of these [primary qualities], and for this reason, in the second sense of the term, a thing is no longer called simply hot or cold—in the sense of being unmixed and pure—but rather, each of the other things is called hot or cold on the grounds that it partakes either of more of the hot and less of the cold, or of more of the cold and less of the hot.

There are, then, these two senses of the terms hot and cold, and dry and moist: the one, when we speak of them in an absolute sense, is unmixed and pure; the other is a mixture of the opposites, but is named after the quality that predomin

paragraphs.content: ἴσον γὰρ ἀπέχει τῶν ἄκρων ἐν ἐκείνῳ τῷ γένει τε καὶ εἴδει. γένος μὲν οὖν τὸ ζῶον, ἵππος δὲ καὶ βοῦς καὶ κύων εἴδη. καὶ δὴ καὶ μέσον μέν ἐστι τῇ κράσει καθ’ ὅλον τὸ γένος τῶν ζώων ὁ ἄνθρωπος· ἐν γὰρ τοῖς ἐφεξῆς τοῦτο δειχθήσεται. μέσος δ’ ὡς ἐν ἀνθρώποις κατ’ εἶδος ὁ καλούμενος εὔσαρκος. οὗτος δ’ ἐστὶν, ὃν οὔτε λεπτὸν, οὔτε παχὺν ἔχομεν εἰπεῖν, οὔτε θερμὸν, οὔτε ψυχρὸν, οὔτ’ ἄλλῳ τινὶ τῶν τὴν ἀμετρίαν ἐνδεικνυμένων ὀνομάτων προσαγορεῦσαι. ὅστις δ’ ἂν ὑπὲρ τοῦτον ᾖ, πάντως οὗτος ἢ θερμότερός ἐστιν, ἢ ψυχρότερος, ἢ ξηρότερος, ἢ ὑγρότερος.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For it is at an equal distance from the extremes within that genus and species. Genus, then, is “animal,” while horse, ox, and dog are species. And indeed, as regards the krasis [mixture/temperament], the human being is the mean throughout the whole genus of animals; for this will be shown in what follows. As for the mean within humans considered as a species, it is the so‑called “well‑fleshed” [eúsarkos]. This is the person whom we cannot call thin or thick, nor hot or cold, nor designate by any of the other names that indicate disproportion. And whoever exceeds this person is in any case either hotter or colder, or drier, or wetter.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

"For it is equally distant from the extremes in that genus and species. Now, 'animal' is the genus, while horse, ox, and dog are species. And indeed, human is the mean in temperament throughout the whole genus of animals; for this will be demonstrated in what follows. And within the human species, the mean is what we call the 'well-fleshed' [eusarkos]. This is one whom we can describe as neither thin nor thick, neither hot nor cold, nor can we apply any other terms that indicate immoderation. Whoever exceeds this condition is certainly either hotter, colder, drier, or moister."

[Note: 'eusarkos' (εὔσαρκος) is a technical medical term referring to someone with good, balanced bodily constitution]

The translation preserves the technical philosophical and medical terminology while maintaining the logical structure of the argument about classification and mean states in living beings.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: For it is equidistant from the extremes within that genus and species. The genus, then, is 'animal,' while horse, ox, and dog are species. And so, man is the mean in his temperament [krasis, the mixture of bodily humors] throughout the whole genus of animals; for this will be shown in what follows. And the mean within the human species is the so-called 'well-fleshed' man [eusarkos]. This is the person whom we can call neither thin nor fat, neither hot nor cold, nor address by any other of the names that indicate immoderation. But whoever deviates from this state is necessarily either hotter, or colder, or drier, or wetter.

paragraphs.content: ὀνομάζεται δὲ πῇ μὲν ἁπλῶς ὁ τοιοῦτος, πῇ δ’ οὐχ ἁπλῶς. ἁπλῶς μὲν, ὅτι θερμὸς ἢ ψυχρὸς, ἢ ξηρὸς ἢ ὑγρὸς εἶναι λέγεται, μηκέτι παραβαλλόμενος ἀφωρισμένως ἑνὶ τῷδε. καθ’ ἕτερον δὲ τρόπον οὐχ ἁπλῶς, ὅτι τῷ συμμέτρῳ τε καὶ μέσῳ παντὸς τοῦ εἴδους παραβάλλεται. οὕτω δὲ καὶ κύων ζῶον ξηρὸν ἁπλῶς μὲν, ὡς ἄν τῳ δόξειε, λέγεται, μηκέτι παραβαλλόμενος, εἰ τύχῃ, μύρμηκι, καθ’ ἕτερον δὲ τρόπον οὐχ ἁπλῶς, ὅτι τῷ συμμέτρῳ τε καὶ μέσῳ τῇ κράσει παντὸς τοῦ εἴδους τῶν ζώων ἁπάντων, ὅ τί ποτ’ ἂν ᾖ τοῦτο, παραβάλλεται. πρόδηλον οὖν ἤδη γέγονεν, ὡς ἕκαστον τῶν οὕτω λεγομένων ἢ ἑνὶ παραβάλλοντες ὅτῳ δήποτε θερμὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ξηρὸν ἢ ὑγρὸν πρὸς ἐκεῖνο λέγομεν, ἢ τῷ μέσῳ, καθ’ ὅπερ ἂν εἶδος ἢ γένος ᾖ τὸ λεγόμενον· οἷον εἶδος μὲν ἵππον, καὶ βοῦν, καὶ κύνα, καὶ πλάτανον, καὶ κυπάριττον, καὶ συκῆν, γένος δὲ ζῶον, ἢ φυτόν. ἐπὶ τούτοις τρίτον ἄλλο σημαινόμενον ἦν τῶν ἁπλῶς λεγομένων, ἃ δὴ καὶ τὰς ἀμίκτους τε καὶ ἄκρας ἔφαμεν ἔχειν ποιότητας, ὀνομάζεσθαί τε στοιχεῖα. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ τὰς ποιότητας αὐτὰς ὀνομάζομεν ἐνίοτε τοῖς ποιοῖς σώμασιν ὁμωνύμως.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
In one respect such a thing is named simply [i.e., absolutely], and in another not simply. Simply, in that it is said to be hot or cold, or dry or moist, no longer being set in comparison exclusively to some one particular thing. But in another way, not simply, because it is compared with what is proportionate and the mean [meson] of the whole species [eidos].

Thus too a dog is called a dry animal simply, as someone might think, no longer being compared, say, to an ant; but in another way, not simply, because it is compared to the proportionate and the mean with respect to the mixture [krasis] of the entire species of animals as a whole—whatever that may be.

It has therefore by now become clear that, in speaking in this way, we call each of the things so named hot or cold, or dry or moist, either by comparing it to some particular single thing, or to the mean, according as the thing spoken of is a species or a genus: for example, as species—horse, ox, dog, plane tree, cypress, fig tree; as genera—animal or plant.

In addition to these, there was a third meaning signified among what are called “simply”: namely, the things which we said possess unmixed and extreme qualities, and are called elements [stoicheia]. And indeed we sometimes even name the qualities themselves by the same names as the qualified bodies [i.e., homonymously].
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

Such a thing is sometimes called absolute and sometimes not absolute. It is absolute when it is said to be hot or cold, or dry or wet, without being specifically compared to any one thing. But in another way it is not absolute, when it is compared to what is proportionate and median for the entire kind. Thus a dog is called absolutely a dry animal in one sense, as one might think, when it is no longer being compared to, say, an ant; but in another way it is not absolute, because it is compared to whatever might be the proportionate and median temperament of the entire kind of all animals. It has now become clear that when we speak of each of these things in this way, we call it hot or cold, or dry or wet, either by comparing it to some particular thing or to the median within whatever species or genus is being discussed - for example, as species: horse, ox, dog, plane tree, cypress, and fig tree; as genus: animal or plant. In addition to these, there was a third meaning of things spoken of as absolute, namely those which we said possess unmixed and extreme qualities, and are called elements. Indeed, we sometimes give the same names to the qualities themselves as to the qualified bodies.

[Note: The text appears to be discussing classification and comparison of natural properties, likely from a medical or philosophical treatise, possibly Galen.]
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ περὶ μὲν τούτου μετ’ ὀλίγον ἐροῦμεν. εἰς δὲ τὰ παρόντα, τῶν ποιῶν σωμάτων τριχῶς λεγομένων, ἐπισκοπεῖσθαι προσήκει, πῶς ἐν ἑκάστῃ ῥήσει κέχρηταί τις τῇ προσηγορίᾳ, πότερον ὡς ἁπλοῦν τι καὶ ἄμικτον δηλῶν, ἢ ὡς πρὸς τὸ σύμμετρον ὁμογενὲς ἢ ὁμοειδὲς παραβάλλων, ἢ πρὸς ὁτιοῦν τὸ ἐπιτυχόν· οἷον ὅταν ὀστοῦν εἴπῃ τις ξηρὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν, ἁπλῶς οὑτωσὶ μόνον ὀνομάσας, ἄνευ τοῦ προσθεῖναι λέοντος, ἢ κυνὸς, ἢ ἀνθρώπου. δῆλον γὰρ, ὡς πρὸς τὴν ὅλην φύσιν ἀποβλέπων ἁπάντων τῶν ἐν τῷ κόσμῳ σωμάτων ἐπινοεῖ τι μέσον, ᾧ παραβάλλων αὐτὸ ξηρὸν εἶναί φησι. ἂν δέ γε τὸ τοῦ λέοντος, ἢ τὸ τοῦ κυνὸς, ἢ τὸ τοῦ ἀνθρώπου ὀστοῦν εἴπῃ ξηρὸν εἶναι, δῆλον ὡς ἐν αὐτοῖς πάλιν τοῖς τῶν ζώων ὀστοῖς τῷ μέσῳ παραβάλλει. καὶ χρὴ κᾀνταῦθά τι νοῆσαι πάντων τῶν ζώων, τῶν μὲν μᾶλλον, τῶν δὲ ἧττον ἐχόντων ὀστᾶ ξηρὰ, μέσον εἶναι τὴν κρᾶσιν ὀστοῦν ἔν τινι γένει ζώων, οἷον ἀνθρώπου, εἰ τύχοι, καὶ τούτῳ τἄλλα παραβαλλόμενα, τὰ μὲν ὑγρὰ, τὰ δὲ ξηρὰ προσαγορεύεσθαι. καὶ μὲν δὴ κᾀν τοῖς ἀνθρώποις αὐτοῖς πάλιν ὁ μέν τις ξηρὸν, ὁ δ’ ὑγρὸν ὀστοῦν ἔχειν λεχθήσεται, τῷ μέσῳ παραβαλλόμενος ὡς ἐν ἀνθρώποις.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But about this we will speak a little later. For the present, since “qualified bodies” are spoken of in three ways, it is proper to examine how in each statement someone uses the appellation—whether by indicating something simple and unmixed, or by making a comparison relative to a proportionate standard among things that are homogeneous or of the same kind, or relative to whatever chance comparator occurs. For example, when someone says that bone is dry or cold, naming it thus simply, without adding “of a lion” or “of a dog” or “of a human,” it is clear that, looking to the entire nature of all the bodies in the cosmos, he conceives some mean [meson], and by comparing it to this he declares it to be dry. But if he says that the bone of a lion, or of a dog, or of a human is dry, it is clear that he is again comparing it to the mean among the bones of the animals themselves. And one must in this case too conceive that, among all animals—some having bones that are drier, others less so—there is a mean in the mixture [krasis] of bone within some genus of animals, say humans, if it should be so; and by comparison with this, the others are called “moist” or “dry.” And indeed even among humans themselves, one person will be said to have dry bone, another moist bone, by comparison with the mean as it obtains among humans.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is my translation of the Greek paragraph:

But concerning this we shall speak shortly. For the present, since qualitative bodies are spoken of in three ways, it is appropriate to examine how one uses the term in each expression: whether to indicate something simple and unmixed, or in comparison to what is proportionate within the same genus or species, or in relation to whatever happens to be at hand. For example, when someone calls a bone dry or cold, simply naming it thus alone, without adding whether it's of a lion, or dog, or human. For it is clear that, looking to the whole nature of all bodies in the cosmos, one conceives of some mean, in comparison to which one says it is dry. But if one speaks of the bone of a lion, or of a dog, or of a human as being dry, it is clear that one is again comparing it to the mean within the bones of animals themselves. And here too one must understand that among all animals, some having drier bones and others less dry, there exists a middle state of bone mixture [krasis] in some genus of animals, such as humans, for instance, and when others are compared to this, some are called moist and others dry. And indeed among humans themselves again, one person will be said to have dry bones, another moist bones, when compared to what is middle as regards humans.

[Note: "krasis" refers to the mixture or blending of qualities, a technical term in ancient medical theory]
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
But about this we will speak shortly. For the present, however, since qualitative bodies are spoken of in three ways, it is necessary to investigate how in each expression one uses the term: whether as indicating something simple and unmixed, or as comparing it to the mean of the same genus or species, or to anything at random.

For example, when someone says a bone is dry or cold, simply naming it thus, without adding ‘of a lion,’ or ‘of a dog,’ or ‘of a man.’ For it is clear that, with a view to the whole nature of all bodies in the cosmos, he conceives of some mean, by comparison with which he says it is dry. But if he should say that the bone of a lion, or of a dog, or of a man is dry, it is clear that he is again comparing it to the mean among the bones of animals themselves. And here too, one must understand that, since among all animals some have drier bones and others less so, there exists a bone of mean temperament [κρᾶσις] in some kind of animal—of man, for instance—and that the other bones, when compared to this one, are called moist or dry. And indeed, even among men themselves, again, one man will be said to have a dry bone, and another a moist one, being compared to the mean as it is found among men.

paragraphs.content: ὅτι δ’ ἐν ἅπασι τοῖς οὖσι τὸ μέσον τῶν ἄκρων ἐστὶ τὸ σύμμετρον καὶ κατ’ ἐκεῖνο τὸ γένος ἢ εἶδος εὔκρατον, ἀεὶ χρὴ προσυπακούειν ἐν ἅπαντι τῷ λόγῳ, κᾂν παρελθόντες ποτὲ τῇ λέξει τύχωμεν αὐτῇ. καὶ μὲν δὴ τούτων οὕτως ἐχόντων, ὅταν ὑγρὰν εἶναί τις εἴπῃ τήνδε τὴν κρᾶσιν, ἢ θερμὴν, ἐρωτᾷν, ὅπως εἴρηκεν, ἆρά γε τῷδέ τινι παραβάλλων ἀφωρισμένως ἑνὶ, καθάπερ, εἰ τύχοι, τῷ Πλάτωνι τὸν Θεόφραστον, ἢ κατὰ γένος ὁτιοῦν, ἢ εἶδος. ἢ γὰρ ὡς ἄνθρωπον, ἢ ὡς ζῶον, ἢ ὡς οὐσίαν ἁπλῶς. τὸ γὰρ δὴ τρίτον σημαινόμενον ἑκάστῳ τῶν τοιούτων ὀνομάτων, ὅπερ ἁπλοῦν ἐλέγομεν εἶναι καὶ ἄμικτον, οὐκ ἔστιν ἐν τοῖς κεκραμένοις, ἀλλ’ ἐν αὐτοῖς τοῖς πρώτοις, ἃ δὴ καὶ στοιχεῖα προσαγορεύομεν. ὥστε, τριχῶς ἑκάστου τῶν ποιῶν σωμάτων λεγομένου, τῶν δύο μόνων ἡμᾶς χρήζειν εἰς τὴν περὶ κράσεων πραγματείαν, ἢ πρὸς τὸ τυχὸν ὁτιοῦν παραβάλλοντας, ἢ πρὸς τὸ σύμμετρον ὁμογενές. ἐπεὶ δὲ πολλὰ τὰ γένη, καθάπερ οὖν καὶ τὰ ἄτομα, δυνήσεται ταὐτὸ σῶμα καὶ θερμὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν, καὶ ξηρὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν εἶναι κατὰ πολλοὺς τοὺς τρόπους.
paragraphs.openai_translation: That in all existing things the mean between the extremes is what is commensurate and, with respect to that genus or species, well-tempered [eukraton], one must always tacitly understand throughout the whole discussion, even if at times we should happen to pass it over in our wording. And since this is so, whenever someone says that such-and-such a mixture [krasis] is moist or hot, ask in what way he has said it: is it by comparing it to some one determinate thing, as, if it should happen, Theophrastus to Plato, or according to some genus or species? For example, as a man, or as an animal, or as substance simply. For the third signification implied by each of such names—the one we said is simple and unmixed—is not found in mixed things, but in the primary things themselves, which we also call elements. Therefore, since each of the qualitative bodies is spoken of in three ways, we need only two for the treatise on mixtures: either by comparing to some chance particular, or to the commensurate homogeneous standard [i.e., the mean within the same kind]. Since the genera are many, as indeed are the individuals, the same body will be able to be both hot and cold, and dry and moist, in many ways.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is my translation of the Greek paragraph:

That in all existing things the mean between extremes is the symmetrical and well-tempered according to that genus or species, we must always keep in mind throughout the entire discussion, even if we happen to sometimes pass over expressing it explicitly. And indeed, with these things being so, whenever someone says that this particular mixture is moist or hot, we must ask in what sense they mean it - whether comparing it specifically to some one thing, as for instance comparing Theophrastus to Plato, or according to any genus or species. For one might mean it as compared to a human, or as compared to an animal, or simply as compared to substance itself. For indeed the third meaning of each such term, which we said was simple and unmixed, does not exist in mixed things, but in the primary things themselves, which we call elements. Therefore, since each of the qualified bodies can be spoken of in three ways, we need only two of these for our treatise on mixtures - either comparing to any chance thing, or to the symmetrical thing of the same genus. And since there are many genera, just as there are many individuals, the same body will be capable of being both hot and cold, and dry and moist in many ways.

[Note: Technical terms:
- κρᾶσις (krasis) = mixture/temperament
- σύμμετρον (symmetron) = symmetrical/proportionate
- εὔκρατον (eukraton) = well-tempered/balanced]
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ὅταν μὲν ἑνὶ τῷ τυχόντι παραβάλληται, πάνυ σαφές ἐστιν, ὡς ἐγχωρεῖ τἀναντία λέγεσθαι ταὐτὸν, οἷον Δίωνα Θέωνος μὲν καὶ Μέμνονος ξηρότερον, Ἀρίστωνος δὲ καὶ Γλαύκωνος ὑγρότερον. ὅταν δὲ πρὸς τὸ σύμμετρον, ὁμογενὲς ἢ ὁμοειδὲς, ἐνταῦθ’ ἤδη συγχεῖσθαί τε καὶ ταράττεσθαι συμβαίνει τοὺς ἀγυμνάστους.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But when it is compared with any chance individual, it is quite clear that opposites can be predicated of the same thing—for example, that Dion is drier than Theon and Memnon, but wetter than Ariston and Glaucon. When, however, the comparison is made with what is commensurate [σύμμετρον: proportionate standard], homogeneous [ὁμογενές: of the same genus], or of the same form [ὁμοειδές: of the same species/kind], then the untrained are already liable to become confused and disturbed.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation:

"But whenever something is compared to any single random thing, it is entirely clear that opposites can be predicated of the same thing - for instance, that Dion is drier than Theon and Memnon, but moister than Ariston and Glaucon. However, when comparison is made to what is proportionate, of the same genus or species, at this point those who are unpracticed become confused and disturbed."

[Notes: 
- "σύμμετρον" (symmetron) refers to what is proportionate or well-measured
- "ὁμογενὲς" and "ὁμοειδὲς" are technical philosophical terms meaning "of the same genus" and "of the same species" respectively
- The passage appears to be discussing relative predication and logical comparison]

The translation preserves the argumentative structure of the original Greek while rendering it in clear English, maintaining both the philosophical precision and the illustrative example using proper names.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ὁ γὰρ αὐτὸς ἄνθρωπός ὑγρὸς ἅμα καὶ θερμὸς εἷναι δύναται, καὶ ξηρὸς καὶ ψυχρός· ξηρὸς μὲν καὶ ψυχρὸς, ὡς πρὸς τὸν σύμμετρον ἄνθρωπον παραβαλλόμενος, ὑγρὸς δὲ καὶ θερμὸς, ὡς πρὸς ἄλλο τι ζῶον, ἢ φυτὸν, ἢ οὐσίαν ἡντιναοῦν· οἷον ὡς πρὸς μὲν ζῶον, εἰ τύχοι, μέλιττάν τε καὶ μύρμηκα, πρὸς δὲ φυτὸν, ἐλαίαν, ἢ συκῆν, ἢ δάφνην, πρὸς οὐσίαν δὲ τινα ἑτέραν, ἣ μήτε ζῶόν ἐστι, μήτε φυτὸν, οἷον λίθον, ἢ σίδηρον, ἢ χαλκόν ἐν τούτοις δὲ τὸ μὲν πρὸς ἄνθρωπον παραβάλλειν, πρὸς ὁμοειδές ἐστιν ἡ παραβολὴ, τὸ δὲ πρὸς μέλιτταν ἢ μύρμηκα πρὸς ὁμογενὲς, ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ πρὸς φυτὸν ὁτιοῦν. ἔστι γὰρ ἀνωτέρω τοῦ ζώου τοῦτο τὸ γένος, ὥσπερ οὖν καὶ αὐτοῦ τούτου λίθος καὶ σίδηρος καὶ χαλκὸς ἐκ τῶν ἄνωθεν γενῶν. καλείσθω γοῦν ὁμογενὲς ἕνεκα συντόμου διδασκαλίας ἡ τοιαύτη σύμπασα παραβολή· τοσόνδε μόνον ἐν αὐτῇ διελομένων ἡμῶν, ὡς, ἐπειδὴ μὲν ἁπλῶς οὐσία τις εὔκρατος λέλεκται, καὶ ταύτης δέ τις ἑτέρα ξηροτέρα καὶ θερμοτέρα, καὶ ψυχροτέρα καὶ ὑγροτέρα, τὴν μὲν εὔκρατον ἐνταῦθα τὴν ἐκ τῶν ἐναντίων ἀκριβῶς ἴσων συνελθόντων ὀνομάζομεν, ὅσον δ’ ἀπολείπεται τῆσδε καὶ πλεονεκτεῖ κατά τι, τῷ τοῦ πλεονεκτοῦντος ὀνόματι προσαγορεύομεν· ἐπειδὰν δ’ ἤτοι φυτὸν ἢ ζῶον εὔκρατον ὁτιοῦν εἴπωμεν, οὐκ ἔθ’ ἁπλῶς ἐν τῇ τοιαύτῃ τάξει τἀναντία παραβάλλομεν ἀλλήλοις, ἀλλὰ πρὸς τὴν τοῦ φυτοῦ φύσιν ἢ τὴν τοῦ ζώου τὴν ἀναφορὰν ποιούμεθα, συκῆν μὲν εὔκρατον, εἰ τύχοι, λέγοντες, ὅταν, οἵαν μάλιστα πρέπει τὴν φύσιν ὑπάρχειν συκῇ, τοιαύτη τις ᾖ, κύνα δ’ αὖ, καὶ σῦν, καὶ ἵππον, καὶ ἄνθρωπον, ἐπειδὰν καὶ τούτων ἕκαστον ἄριστα τῆς οἰκείας ἔχῃ φύσεως. αὐτὸ δὴ τοῦτο, τὸ τῆς οἰκείας φύσεως ἔχειν ἄριστα, ταῖς ἐνεργείαις κρίνεται, καὶ γὰρ καὶ φυτὸν καὶ ζῶον ὁτιοῦν ἄριστα διακεῖσθαι τηνικαῦτά φαμεν, ὅταν ἐνεργῇ κάλλιστα. συκῆς μὲν γὰρ ἀρετὴ βέλτιστά τε καὶ πλεῖστα τελεσφορεῖν σῦκα· κατὰ ταὐτὰ δὲ καὶ τῆς ἀμπέλου, τὸ πλείστας τε καὶ καλλίστας εὐφορεῖν σταφυλὰς, ἵππου δὲ, τὸ θεῖν ὠκύτατα, καὶ κυνὸς, πρὸς μὲν θήρας καὶ φυλακὰς ἄκρως εἶναι θυμοειδῆ, πρὸς δὲ τοὺς οἰκείους πραότατον. ἅπαντα οὖν ταῦτα, τά τε ζῶα λέγω καὶ τὰ φυτὰ, τὴν ἀρίστην τε καὶ μέσην ἐν τῷ σφετέρῳ γένει κρᾶσιν ἔχειν ἐροῦμεν οὐχ ἁπλῶς, ὅταν ἰσότης ἀκριβῶς ᾖ τῶν ἐναντίων, ἀλλ’ ὅταν ἡ κατὰ δύναμιν αὐτῆς ὑπάρχῃ συμμετρία. τοιοῦτο δέ τι καὶ τὴν δικαιοσύνην εἶναί φαμεν, οὐ σταθμῷ καὶ μέτρῳ τὸ ἴσον, ἀλλὰ τῷ προσήκοντί γε καὶ κατὰ τὴν ἀξίαν ἐξετάζοντες.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For the very same man can at once be moist and hot, and dry and cold: dry and cold when he is compared with the proportionate man, but moist and hot when compared with some other animal, or a plant, or any sort of substance; for example, compared with an animal, say, a bee or an ant; with a plant, an
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the passage:

For the same person can be both moist and hot, and dry and cold: dry and cold when compared to a well-balanced person, but moist and hot when compared to some other animal, plant, or any other substance - for instance, compared to animals like a bee or an ant, or to plants like an olive tree, fig tree, or laurel, or to some other substance that is neither animal nor plant, such as stone, iron, or bronze. In these comparisons, comparing to a human is a comparison to something of the same species, while comparing to a bee or ant is to something of the same genus, as is likewise comparing to any plant. For this genus is higher than that of animals, just as stone, iron, and bronze are from higher genera. Let us call all such comparison "generic comparison" for the sake of brief instruction, making only this distinction within it: when we speak of something simply as being well-tempered substance, and of another as being drier and hotter, or colder and moister, we name the well-tempered one as that which is formed from an exact balance of opposites coming together, and whatever falls short of or exceeds this in any way, we name after the quality that predominates.

But when we speak of any well-tempered plant or animal, we no longer simply compare opposites to each other in such an arrangement, but rather make reference to the nature of the plant or animal, speaking of a well-tempered fig tree, for instance, when it has the nature most fitting for a fig tree, and likewise of a dog, pig, horse, or human when each of these possesses the best state of its own nature. Indeed, this very thing - having the best state of one's own nature - is judged by activities, for we say that any plant or animal is in its best condition when it performs its functions most excellently. The excellence of a fig tree is to produce the best and most numerous figs; similarly for a vine, to bear the most and finest grapes; for a horse, to run most swiftly; and for a dog, to be extremely spirited in hunting and guarding, yet most gentle toward household members. Therefore, we will say that all these - both animals and plants - have the best and middle mixture in their own genus not simply when there is an exact equality of opposites, but when there exists the proper proportion according to their capacity. We say that justice is something like this too, examining equality not by weight and measure, but by what is fitting and according to merit.

[Note: Technical terms like "well-tempered" (εὔκρατος) and "mixture" (κρᾶσις) are medical/philosophical terms relating to the theory of bodily humors and temperaments.]

paragraphs.content: ἰσότης οὖν κράσεως ἐν ἅπασι τοῖς εὐκράτοις ζώοις τε καὶ φυτοῖς ἐστιν, οὐχ ἡ κατὰ τῶν κερασθέντων στοιχείων ὄγκον, ἀλλ’ ἡ τῇ φύσει τοῦ τε ζώου καὶ τοῦ φυτοῦ πρέπουσα. πρέπει δ’ ἔσθ’ ὅτε, τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ, τὸ δὲ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ πλέον ὑπάρχειν. οὐ γὰρ ὁμοίαν χρὴ κρᾶσιν ἔχειν ἄνθρωπον, καὶ λέοντα, καὶ μέλιτταν, καὶ κύνα. πρὸς δὲ τὸν ἐρόμενον, ἧστινός ἐστι κράσεως ἄνθρωπος, ἢ ἵππος, ἢ βοῦς, ἢ κύων, ἢ ὁτιοῦν ἄλλο τῶν πάντων, οὐχ ἁπλῶς ἀποκριτέον. οὐ γὰρ ἐγχωρεῖ τὰ πολλαχῶς λεγόμενά τε καὶ κρινόμενα, καθ’ ἕνα τρόπον ἀποκρινάμενον, ἀνέγκλητον εἶναι. χρὴ τοίνυν δυοῖν θάτερον, ἢ πάσας ἐπεξέρχεσθαι τὰς διαφορὰς, ἢ, περὶ τίνος ἤρετο, πυθόμενον, ἐκείνην μόνην εἰπεῖν. εἰ μὲν γὰρ ὡς ἐν ζώοις ἐπυνθάνετο, τίνος εἴη κράσεως, ἐπὶ τὸ μέσον ἁπάντων ζώων τῇ κράσει βλέποντα, τὴν ἀπόκρισιν αὐτὴν ποιητέον· εἰ δ’ ἁπλῶς τε καὶ ὡς πρὸς ἅπασαν οὐσίαν, οὕτως ἤδη παραβάλλειν τὰ ἐναντία τῶν ἐν αὐτῷ πρὸς ἄλληλα, καὶ σκοπεῖσθαι, μηκέτι πρὸς τὰς ἐνεργείας ἀναφέροντα τὴν κρᾶσιν, ἀλλὰ πρὸς τοὺς ὄγκους τῶν στοιχείων. εἰ δ’ ἀφωρισμένως τῷδέ τινι παραβάλλων ἤρετο, πρὸς ἐκεῖνο μόνον παραβλητέον. ἔτι δὲ μᾶλλον, εἴ τινος τῶν ἀτόμων οὐσιῶν, οἷον, εἰ τύχοι, Δίωνος, ἢ τοῦδέ τινος τοῦ κυνὸς, ἐρωτηθείημεν ὁποία τις ἡ κρᾶσίς ἐστιν, οὐχ ἁπλῶς ἀποκριτέον. ἀφορμὴ γὰρ οὐ σμικρὰ τοῖς σοφισταῖς ἐντεῦθεν εἰς τὸ συκοφαντεῖν. εἰ γὰρ εἴποις, θερμῆς καὶ ξηρᾶς κράσεως εἶναι τὸν Δίων, ῥᾷστον αὐτῷ, προχειρισαμένῳ τῶν ξηροτέρων καὶ θερμοτέρων ἐκείνου τὴν κρᾶσιν ἄνθρωπον ὁντιναοῦν, ὑγρὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν ὡς πρὸς ἐκεῖνον ἀποφῇναι τὸν Δίωνα· τοῦτο δ’ ἄλλο τι ζῶον ἢ φυτὸν, οἷον, εἰ τύχοι, λέοντά τε καὶ κύνα, καὶ τούτων ὑγρότερόν τινα καὶ ξηρότερον ἀποδεῖξαι τὸν Δίωνα. χρὴ τοίνυν, ὃς μήθ’ ἑαυτὸν ἐξαπατῆσαι βούλεται, μήθ’ ὑπ’ ἄλλου σοφισθῆναι, τοῦτον ἀπὸ τῶν ἁπλῶς λεγομένων θερμῶν, καὶ ψυχρῶν, καὶ ξηρῶν, καὶ ὑγρῶν οὐσιῶν ἀρξάμενον, οὕτως ἐπὶ τὰς ἄλλας μετιέναι, καὶ πρῶτον μὲν αὐτὸ δὴ τοῦτο ἐπ’ αὐτῶν διορίσασθαι, τὸ μηδὲ ταύτας, εἰ καὶ ὅτι μάλιστα δοκοῦσιν ἁπλῶς λέγεσθαι, πεφευγέναι τὴν πρὸς τὸ σύμμετρον ὁμογενὲς παραβολήν.
