paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the passage:

There is an equality of mixture in all well-tempered animals and plants, not according to the bulk of the mixed elements, but according to what is fitting for the nature of the animal or plant. Sometimes it is fitting that the moist exceeds the dry, and the hot exceeds the cold. For a human, a lion, a bee, and a dog should not have the same mixture.

When someone asks about the mixture of a human, or horse, or ox, or dog, or any other being, one should not answer simply. For it is not possible to give a single type of answer to matters that are spoken of and judged in many ways without being subject to criticism. Therefore, one must do one of two things: either go through all the differences, or, after learning which specific aspect they're asking about, speak only about that.

If one inquires about the mixture as it relates to animals, the answer must be made with reference to the mean [average] mixture of all animals. But if the question is asked simply and in relation to all substance, then one must compare the opposites within it to each other, examining the mixture not with reference to functions but to the bulk of the elements. If the question was asked in comparison to some specific thing, then the comparison should be made only to that thing.

Even more so, if we were asked about the mixture of some individual substance - for instance, of Dion or of this particular dog - we should not answer simply. For this gives no small opportunity to sophists for making false accusations. If you say that Dion has a hot and dry mixture, it is very easy for someone to produce any person who is drier and hotter than him, and thus show that Dion is moist and cold in comparison. Or they might do this with some other animal or plant, such as a lion or dog, demonstrating that Dion is moister or drier than these.

Therefore, whoever wishes neither to deceive himself nor to be deceived by another sophist must begin from substances that are called simply hot, cold, dry, or moist, and then proceed to others, first establishing this very point about them: that even these, though they seem to be spoken of in the most absolute sense, do not escape comparison with what is proportionate within their own kind.

[Note: "mixture" (krasis) is a technical term referring to the balance of fundamental qualities in ancient medical and philosophical theory]

paragraphs.content: ὥσπερ γὰρ κύνα μέσον ἁπάντων κυνῶν τῇ κράσει λέγομεν, ὅταν ἴσον ἀπέχῃ τῶν ἄκρων, οὕτω καὶ οὐσίαν ἐροῦμεν εἶναι μέσην τῇ κράσει τὴν ἴσον ἀπέχουσαν τῶν ἄκρων, ἅ δὴ καὶ πρῶτά τέ εἰσι πάντων καὶ στοιχεῖα. ἴσον δ’ ἀφέξει δηλονότι τῶν ἄκρων, ἐξ ἴσου κερασθέντων ἁπάντων. τὴν οὖν ὑπερβάλλουσαν, ἢ ἐλλείπουσαν τῆσδε, θερμὴν, ἢ ψυχρὰν, ἢ ξηρὰν, ἢ ὑγρὰν εἶναι φήσομεν, ἅμα μὲν τῇ μέσῃ παραβάλλοντες, ἅμα δὲ καὶ τῶν ἐναντίων στοιχείων ἐξέτασιν ἐπ’ αὐτῆς ποιούμενοι. καὶ δὴ καὶ κατὰ τοῦτο μὲν ἁπλῶς ἐροῦμεν αὐτὴν ἢ θερμὴν, ἢ ξηρὰν, ἢ ψυχρὰν, ἢ ὑγράν ὑπάρχειν. ἐπειδὰν δὲ τῇ μέσῃ κράσει παραβάλλωμεν, οὐχ ἁπλῶς, ἀλλ’ ὅτι πρὸς τὸ σύμμετρον ὁμογενὲς οὕτως ἔχει. γένος δ’ ἦν αὐτῶν ἡ οὐσία. πάντα γὰρ ὑπ’ αὐτὴν πέπτωκεν, ὡς ἀνώτατον τὸ γένος, ἔμψυχά τε καὶ ἄψυχα, καὶ κοινόν ἐστιν ἥδε, καὶ ἀνθρώπου, καὶ κυνὸς, καὶ πλατάνου, καὶ συκῆς, καὶ χαλκοῦ, καὶ σιδήρου, καὶ τῶν ἄλλων ἁπάντων γένος.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Just as we call a dog the “mean” among all dogs in respect of krasis [mixture], when it is equally distant from the extremes, so too we shall say that the ousia [substance] is the mean in its krasis that stands at an equal remove from the extremes—these being, indeed, first of all things and the elements. And it will, plainly, be equally distant from the extremes when all the constituents have been mixed in equal measure. Accordingly, whatever exceeds or falls short of this we shall declare to be hot, or cold, or dry, or moist—both by comparing it with the mean and by conducting upon it an examination with reference to the opposing elements. Thus in this respect we shall say simply that it is hot, or dry, or cold, or moist. But whenever we compare it to the mean krasis, we shall not speak simply, but say that it is thus disposed in relation to the proportionate, homogeneous standard [i.e., the commensurate mean mixture]. And the genus of these was ousia. For everything falls under it as the highest genus, both ensouled and soulless; and this is common—the genus of human being, dog, plane tree, fig tree, bronze, iron, and all the rest.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation:

Just as we say a dog is median in temperament among all dogs when it is equally distant from the extremes, so too shall we say that a substance is median in its mixture when it is equally distant from the extremes, which are indeed both the primary elements of all things. It will clearly be equally distant from the extremes when all elements are mixed in equal measure. Therefore, we shall say that anything exceeding or falling short of this median is hot, cold, dry, or moist, both by comparing it to the median and by examining the opposing elements within it. And indeed, in this respect we shall speak of it simply as being hot, dry, cold, or moist. But when we compare it to the median mixture, we shall speak not simply, but rather in terms of how it stands in relation to the symmetrical [balanced] member of its own kind. Their genus was substance, for everything falls under it as the highest genus - both animate and inanimate things - and it is the common genus of human, dog, plane tree, fig tree, bronze, iron, and all other things.

[Notes: 
- κρᾶσις (mixture/temperament) refers to the blend of elemental qualities
- σύμμετρον refers to proper proportion or balance
- οὐσία (substance) is a key philosophical term referring to fundamental being or essence]
paragraphs.gemini_translation: For just as we speak of a dog as a mean among all dogs with respect to its temperament [krasis] when it is equally distant from the extremes, so too will we say that a substance is a mean with respect to its temperament when it is equally distant from the extremes, which are indeed the first of all things and the elements. And it will clearly be equally distant from the extremes when all of them have been mixed in equal measure. Therefore, we will say that a substance which exceeds or falls short of this [mean] is hot, or cold, or dry, or wet, comparing it at once to the mean and also undertaking an examination of the contrary elements within it. And so, in this respect, we will say simply that it is either hot, or dry, or cold, or wet. When, however, we compare it to the mean temperament, we do not say this in an absolute sense, but rather that it is in such a state relative to the well-proportioned standard of its own kind [genos]. For substance was their genus. For all things, both ensouled and soulless, fall under it as the highest genus, and this [substance] is the common genus of man, dog, plane tree, fig tree, bronze, iron, and all other things.

paragraphs.content: ὑπ’ αὐτῇ δ’ ἐστὶν ἕτερα γένη πολλά· τὸ μὲν ζῶον ὄρνιθός τε καὶ ἰχθύος, τὸ δὲ φυτὸν δένδρου τε καὶ βοτάνης· ἀετοῦ δὲ καὶ κόρακος ὄρνις, καὶ λάβρακος καὶ φωκίδος ἰχθύς. ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ τὸ μὲν δένδρον ἐλαίας τε καὶ συκῆς γένος· ἡ βοτάνη δὲ ἀναγαλλίδος τε καὶ παιονίας. ἔσχατα δ’ ἤδη γένη ταῦτα· καὶ διὰ τοῦτο καὶ εἴδη προσαγορεύεται, κόραξ, καὶ φωκὶς, καὶ συκῆ, καὶ ἀναγαλλίς· οὕτω δὲ καὶ ἄνθρωπος, καὶ βοῦς, καὶ κύων.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Under it there are many other genera: living thing is the genus of bird and fish, and plant is the genus of tree and herb. Bird, in turn, is the genus of eagle and raven, and fish of labrax [sea-bass] and phokis [a kind of fish]. Likewise, tree is the genus of the olive and the fig tree, and herb of the anagallis [pimpernel] and the peony. These are already ultimate genera, and for this reason they are also called species: raven, and phokis, and fig tree, and anagallis—and so too man, ox, and dog.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation:

Under this there are many other genera: animal includes both bird and fish, while plant includes both tree and herb. Bird is the genus of eagle and raven, and fish is the genus of sea bass and phocid [a type of fish]. Similarly too, tree is the genus of both olive and fig, while herb is the genus of both pimpernel and peony. These are now the lowest genera, and for this reason they are also called species - raven, phocid, fig tree, and pimpernel. And so too with human, ox, and dog.

[Note: This appears to be a philosophical text discussing biological classification and the relationship between genera and species. The Greek terms γένη (genera) and εἴδη (species) are technical terms in ancient taxonomic and logical works.]

The translation aims to preserve the parallel structure and logical progression of the original while using appropriate taxonomic terminology that would be recognizable to modern readers.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: And under this are many other genera: animal is the genus of bird and fish, and plant is the genus of tree and herb. Bird, in turn, is the genus of eagle and raven, and fish of sea bass and seal. Likewise, tree is the genus of olive and fig; and herb of pimpernel and peony. These, then, are

paragraphs.content: ἄνωθεν μὲν οὖν κατιόντων, ἔσχατα γένη ταῦτα, καὶ διὰ τοῦτο καὶ εἴδη προσαγορεύεται· κάτωθεν δ’ ἀνιόντων ἀπὸ τῶν ἀτόμων οὐσιῶν, πρῶτα. καὶ δέδεικται πρὸς ἑτέρου γράμματος, ὡς εὐλόγως οἱ παλαιοὶ ταῦτα ξύμπαντα τὰ μεταξὺ τῶν ἀτόμων τε καὶ τῶν πρώτων γενῶν εἴδη τε ἅμα καὶ γένη προσαγορεύουσιν.
paragraphs.openai_translation: So, when one descends from above, these are the lowest genera, and for this reason they are also called species; but when one ascends from below, starting from the individual substances [particulars], they are first. And it has been shown in another treatise that the ancients quite reasonably call all the things intermediate between the individuals and the primary genera both species and genera at the same time.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation:

"When proceeding downward from above, these are the lowest genera, and for this reason they are also called species; but when ascending from below, starting from individual substances, they are the first. And it has been shown in another text how the ancients reasonably call all these intermediates between the individuals and the primary genera both species and genera simultaneously."

[Notes:
- "genera" (γένη) and "species" (εἴδη) are technical philosophical terms from classification theory
- "individual substances" (ἀτόμων οὐσιῶν) literally means "indivisible substances" or "atomic substances"
- "intermediates" (μεταξὺ) refers to categories that fall between the highest and lowest classifications]

The translation preserves the philosophical terminology while maintaining readability in English. The passage appears to be discussing logical classification and the relationship between general categories and specific instances.
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
Therefore, when descending from above, these are the ultimate genera [γένη], and for this reason are also called species [εἴδη]; but when ascending from below, from the individual substances [ἄτομοι οὐσίαι], they are the first. And it has been demonstrated in another treatise that the ancients reasonably call all these things that are between the individuals and the highest genera both species and genera at the same time.

---
**Explanatory Notes:**
*   **[γένη / εἴδη]**: *Genera* and *species*. This passage describes the logical hierarchy (like the Tree of Porphyry) where a single category (e.g., 'Animal') can be a species relative to a higher category ('Living Thing') but a genus relative to a lower one ('Human').
*   **[ἄτομοι οὐσίαι]**: Literally 'indivisible substances.' This technical term refers to particular individuals, such as Socrates or a specific horse, which cannot be logically divided

paragraphs.content: Ὁπότ’ οὖν διῄρηται τὰ σημαινόμενα, καὶ ὡς οὐχ ἁπλῶς ἀποφαίνεσθαι χρὴ θερμόν τε καὶ ψυχρὸν, καὶ ξηρὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν σῶμα, σαφῶς ἀποδέδεικται, ζητητέον ἐφεξῆς αὐτῶν τὰ γνωρίσματα. καίτοι κᾷνταῦθα χρὴ πρότερον ὑπὲρ τῶν ὀνομάτων διελέσθαι τῶν ἐμπίπτειν ἐξ ἀνάγκης μελλόντων εἰς τὸν ἐφεξῆς λόγον, ἐξαπλῶσαί τέ τι πρᾶγμα, δυνάμει μὲν ἤδη προαποδεδειγμένον, οὐ μὴν ἐναργῶς γε πᾶσι τοῖς ἐντυγχάνουσι τῷδε τῷ γράμματι νοηθῆναι δυνάμενον. ὑπὲρ τῶν ὀνομάτων οὖν πρῶτον εἰπὼν, οὕτως ἐπάνειμι ἐπὶ τὸ πρᾶγμα. τὸ θερμὸν, καὶ τὸ ψυχρὸν, καὶ τὸ ξηρὸν, καὶ τὸ ὑγρὸν, ὅτι μὲν οὐχ ἕν τι σημαίνει, ἐπειδὰν ἐπὶ σωμάτων λέγηται, δέδεικται πρόσθεν· ὅτι δὲ καὶ τὰς ἐν τοῖς σώμασι ποιότητας αὐτὰς μόνας, ἄνευ τῶν δεδεγμένων αὐτὰς οὐσιῶν, οὕτως ὀνομάζουσιν ἐνίοτε, τοῦτο μὲν οὔπω εἴρηται πρόσθεν, ἤδη δὲ αὐτὸ λέγεσθαι καιρός.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
Whenever, then, the things signified have been distinguished, and it has been clearly shown that one ought not simply to assert “hot and cold” and “dry and moist” of a body, next we must inquire into their distinguishing marks. And yet, even here it is necessary first to discuss the terms that will of necessity occur in the ensuing argument, and to unfold a certain point which has already been established in principle [potentially], though it cannot be clearly grasped by everyone who encounters this writing. Having spoken first about the terms, then, I shall so proceed back to the matter itself.

That “the hot,” “the cold,” “the dry,” and “the moist” do not signify one single thing when they are said of bodies has been shown above; but that they sometimes also use these words to name the very qualities [poiotētes] that are in bodies, apart from the substances that have received them, this has not yet been stated before—now, however, it is time to say it.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the passage:

Therefore, now that the meanings have been distinguished, and it has been clearly demonstrated that one must not make simple declarations about a body being hot, cold, dry, or wet, we must next investigate their identifying characteristics. However, here too we must first make distinctions concerning the terms that will necessarily enter into the subsequent discussion, and explain a matter that has already been demonstrated in principle, though it may not be clearly understood by all who encounter this text. So, having first spoken about the terms, I will then return to the matter itself. That "hot," "cold," "dry," and "wet," when spoken of in relation to bodies, do not each signify one single thing has been shown before; but that they sometimes use these terms to refer to the qualities themselves in bodies, apart from the substances that receive them - this has not yet been stated before, and now is the time to discuss it.

[Note: The terms "hot" (thermon), "cold" (psychron), "dry" (xēron), and "wet" (hygron) are fundamental qualities in ancient Greek natural philosophy and medicine, particularly important in humoral theory]

The translation maintains the formal, analytical style of what appears to be a philosophical-medical text, likely discussing the nature of basic physical qualities. I've preserved the complex sentence structure while ensuring readability in English.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: Since, therefore, the meanings have been distinguished, and it has been clearly demonstrated that one must not declare a body to be hot and cold, and dry and wet, without qualification, we must next investigate their characteristics. And yet, in this case also, it is first necessary to make distinctions concerning the terms that will necessarily be used in the subsequent discussion, and to explain a certain matter which, though already demonstrated in potentiality [δυνάμει, i.e., implicitly or in principle], cannot be understood with clarity by all who encounter this text. Therefore, after first speaking about the terms, I shall then return to the matter itself. That ‘the hot,’ ‘the cold,’ ‘the dry,’ and ‘the wet’ do not signify one single thing when spoken of in relation to bodies has been shown previously; but that they also sometimes use these names for the qualities themselves in bodies, alone and without the substances that have received them—this has not yet been stated before, but now is the time for it to be said.

paragraphs.content: ὥσπερ οὖν τὸ, λευκὸν, ὄνομα, κατά τε τοῦ χρώματος ἐπιφέρουσιν, ἐπειδὰν οὕτω λέγωσιν, ἐναντίον ἐστὶ τὸ λευκὸν χρῶμα τῷ μέλανι, κατά τε τοῦ δεδεγμένου τὸ χρῶμα σώματος, ἐπειδὰν τὸ τοῦ κύκνου σῶμα λευκὸν εἶναι φάσκωσιν, οὕτω καὶ τὸ, θερμὸν, ὄνομα, κατά τε τῆς ποιότητος ἐπιφέρουσιν, ὡς εἰ καὶ θερμότητα προσηγόρευον, ἀλλὰ καὶ κατὰ τοῦ σώματος, ὅ τὴν θερμότητα δέδεκται. τὴν γὰρ δὴ ποιότητα παρὰ τὸ δεδεγμένον αὐτὴν σῶμα ἑτέραν χρὴ νομίζειν εἶναί τινα φύσιν ἔχουσαν ἰδίαν, ὡς ἐν τοῖς περὶ τῶν στοιχείων λόγοις δείκνυται. θερμότης μὲν οὖν ποιότης· ἡ δ’ αὐτὴ καὶ θερμὸν ὀνομάζεται, καθάπερ λευκότης καὶ λευκόν. αὐτὸ δὲ σῶμα τὸ θερμὸν ἓν τοῦτο μόνον ὄνομα κέκτηται, τὸ θερμὸν, ὥσπερ τὸ λευκόν· οὐ μὴν οὔτε θερμότης, οὔτε λευκότης αὐτὸ τὸ σῶμά ποτε προσαγορεύεται. κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον καὶ ξηρὸν, καὶ ψυχρὸν, καὶ ὑγρὸν ὀνομάζεται αὐτό τε τὸ σῶμα καὶ ἡ ποιότης. οὐ μὴν ἡ ψυχρότης, ἢ ξηρότης, ἢ ὑγρότης ἔτι τὸ σῶμα καλεῖται, καθάπερ ἡ ἐν αὐτῷ ποιότης. τούτων δ’ οὕτως ἐχόντων, εὔλογον, ἐπειδὰν μὲν ἤτοι θερμότητά τις ἢ ψυχρότητα διαλεγόμενος εἴπῃ, μηδὲν γίνεσθαι σόφισμα· μόναι γὰρ ἐκ τῶν τοιούτων ὀνομάτων αἱ ποιότητες δηλοῦνται· θερμὸν δ’ εἰπόντος, ἢ ψυχρὸν, ἐπειδὴ καὶ ἡ ποιότης οὕτω καὶ τὸ σῶμα τὸ δεδεγμένον αὐτὴν ὀνομάζεται, πρόχειρον γίνεσθαι τῷ κακουργεῖν ἐθέλοντι, τὸ μὴ δηλούμενον ὑπὸ τοῦ λέγοντος ἀκούειν, ἵν’ ἔχῃ σοφίζεσθαι. τοιοῦτο γάρ τοι δρῶσι καὶ πρὸς τὸν ἀφορισμὸν ἀντιλέγοντες, ἐν ᾧ φησιν Ἱπποκράτης· τὰ αὐξανόμενα πλεῖστον ἔχει τὸ ἔμφυτον θερμόν. οὐ γὰρ σῶμά τι θερμὸν τὸ ἔμφυτον τῷ ζώῳ λέγεσθαι πρὸς Ἱπποκράτους ἀκούσαντες, οὐδὲ ζητήσαντες, ὅ τί ποτέ ἐστι τοῦτο, κατὰ τῆς ποιότητος μόνης, ἣν δὴ καὶ θερμότητα καλοῦμεν, εἰρῆσθαι τοὔνομα δεξάμενοι, τὴν ἀντιλογίαν οὕτω ποιοῦνται. καίτοι φαίνεται σμικρὸν ὂν τὸ διαστέλλεσθαι τὰς ὁμωνυμίας, ἐν τῇ χρείᾳ τῶν πραγμάτων ἱκανῶς ἀξιόλογον ὑπάρχον.
paragraphs.openai_translation: ERROR: Empty translation returned from OpenAI
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the passage:

Just as they apply the term 'white' both to the color, when they say "white color is opposite to black," and to the body that has received the color, when they say "the swan's body is white," so too they apply the term 'hot' both to the quality, as if they were speaking of heat itself, and to the body that has received the heat. For indeed one must consider the quality to be a different nature, having its own distinct character, separate from the body that has received it, as is demonstrated in discussions concerning the elements. Heat, then, is a quality; and this same thing is also named 'hot', just as whiteness and white. But the hot body itself possesses only this one name, 'hot', just as 'white'; certainly the body itself is never called either heat or whiteness. In the same way, both the body itself and the quality are named 'dry', 'cold', and 'moist'. However, the body is not called coldness, dryness, or moistness, as the quality in it is.

With these matters being so, it is reasonable that when someone in discussion speaks of either heat [thermotēs] or cold [psychrotēs], no sophistry arises, for from such terms only the qualities are indicated. But when someone says 'hot' or 'cold', since both the quality and the body that has received it are named thus, it becomes easy for one wishing to argue dishonestly to interpret what is not being indicated by the speaker, in order to engage in sophistry. Indeed, this is exactly what they do when arguing against the aphorism in which Hippocrates says: "Growing things have the most innate heat." For they hear Hippocrates speaking of the innate [heat] in living creatures not as some hot body, nor do they investigate what this might be, but accepting the term as referring only to the quality, which we indeed call heat, they make their counter-argument thus. And yet the distinction of homonyms, while appearing small, proves quite significant in the practical application of matters.

[Note: I've preserved key Greek terms in brackets where they are particularly significant for understanding the philosophical distinction being made between the quality and the substance.]

paragraphs.content: Ἀλλ’ ἐπειδὴ καὶ τοῦτο σαφῶς ἤδη διώρισται, ἐπὶ τὸ ὑπόλοιπον αὖθις ἐπανιτέον. οὔσης γάρ τινος ἀκράτου καὶ ἀμίκτου ποιότητος, ὑγρότητός τε καὶ ξηρότητος, καὶ θερμότητος καὶ ψυχρότητος, ὅσα ταύτας διεδέξαντο σώματα, θερμὰ δηλονότι καὶ ψυχρὰ καὶ ξηρὰ καὶ ὑγρὰ τελέως τε καὶ ἀκριβῶς ἔσται. ταυτὶ μὲν οὖν μοι νόει τὰ τῶν γινομένων τε καὶ φθειρομένων στοιχεῖα· τὰ δ’ ἄλλα σώματα, τά τε τῶν ζώων, καὶ τὰ τῶν φυτῶν, καὶ τὰ τῶν ἀψύχων ἁπάντων, οἷον χαλκοῦ, καὶ σιδήρου, καὶ λίθων, καὶ ξύλων, ἐν τῷ μεταξὺ τῶν πρώτων ἐκείνων τετάχθαι. οὐδὲν γὰρ αὐτῶν οὔτ’ ἄκρως θερμὸν, οὔτ’ ἄκρως ψυχρὸν, οὔτ’ ἄκρως ὑγρὸν, οὔτ’ ἄκρως ξηρόν ἐστιν. ἀλλ’ ἤτοι μέσον ἀκριβῶς ὑπάρχει τῶν ἐναντίων, ὡς μηδὲν μᾶλλον εἶναι θερμὸν, ἢ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ξηρὸν, ἢ ὑγρὸν, ἢ θατέρῳ τῶν ἄκρων προσκεχώρηκεν, ὡς μᾶλλον εἶναι θερμὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν, ἢ μᾶλλον ὑγρὸν ἢ ξηρόν. εἰ μὲν δὴ μέσον ἀκριβῶς εἴη καθ’ ἑκατέραν τῶν ἐναντιώσεων, ὡς μηδὲν μᾶλλον εἶναι θερμὸν, ἢ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ξηρὸν, ἢ ὑγρὸν, εὔκρατον ἁπλῶς τοῦτο λεχθήσεται. θατέρου δὲ πλεονεκτήσαντος, ἤτοι κατὰ τὴν ἑτέραν ἀντίθεσιν, ἢ κατ’ ἀμφοτέραν, οὐκ ἔτ’ εὔκρατον. εἰ μὲν δὴ θερμὸν εἴη μᾶλλον, ἢ ψυχρὸν, ὃ μᾶλλόν ἐστι, τοῦτο λεχθήσεται· ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ ξηρὸν καὶ ὑγρόν· κατὰ ταὐτὰ δὲ καὶ εἰ ψυχρὸν εἴη μᾶλλον, ὀνομασθήσεται ψυχρόν. εἰ δ’ ἐξ ἑκατέρας τῆς ἀντιθέσεως ἐπικρατοίη θάτερον, ἤτοι θερμὸν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὸν, ἢ θερμὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν, ἢ ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὸν, ἢ ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν, ὀνομασθήσεται τὸ σῶμα κατὰ τὸ ἐπικρατοῦν. ταύτας μὲν οὖν τὰς τέτταρας δυσκρασίας, ὡς καὶ πρόσθεν εἴπομεν, οἱ πλεῖστοι γινώσκουσιν ἰατροί τε καὶ φιλόσοφοι. τὰς δ’ ἄλλας τέτταρας ἐξ ἡμίσεως τούτων γιγνομένας οὐκ οἶδ’ ὅπως παραλείπουσιν, ὥσπερ καὶ τὴν πρώτην ἁπασῶν κρᾶσιν, τὴν ἀρίστην.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But since this too has now been clearly defined, we must return again to what remains. For since there exists a certain pure and unmixed quality—of moisture and dryness, and of heat and cold—whatever bodies have received these will be completely and precisely hot and cold and dry and moist. Understand these, then, as the elements of things that come to be and perish; while the other bodies—the bodies of animals, of plants, and of all inanimate things, such as bronze, iron, stones, and woods—are set in the interval between those first ones. For none of them is in the extreme—neither utterly hot nor utterly cold nor utterly moist nor utterly dry. Rather, either it occupies exactly the middle between the contraries, so as to be no more hot than cold or dry than moist; or else it has inclined to one of the extremes, so as to be more hot than cold, or more moist than dry. If, then, it were exactly in the middle with respect to each pair of opposites, so as to be no more hot than cold or dry than moist, this will be called simply well-balanced [eukraton, “temperate mixture”]. But if one of the contraries has the advantage—either with respect to one opposition or to both—it is no longer well-balanced. If, then, it be more hot than cold, it will be named by what it is more; and likewise with dry and moist; and likewise, if it be more cold, it will be called cold. And if from each of the oppositions one or the other should prevail—either hot together with moist, or hot together with dry, or cold together with moist, or cold together with dry—the body will be named according to what predominates. These four dyscrasias [“bad mixtures,” imbalances], as we said before, most physicians and philosophers recognize. But the other four that arise from the halves of these, as well as the very first mixture of all—the best—I do not know how they overlook.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the passage:

But since this has now been clearly defined, we must return again to what remains. Since there exists a pure and unmixed quality of wetness and dryness, and of heat and coldness, those bodies that receive these qualities will evidently be completely and precisely hot, cold, dry, and wet. Consider these, then, as the elements of things that come to be and pass away. But all other bodies - those of animals, plants, and all inanimate things such as bronze, iron, stones, and wood - are arranged between these primary elements. For none of them is extremely hot, nor extremely cold, nor extremely wet, nor extremely dry. Rather, each is either precisely in the middle of the opposites, so that it is no more hot than cold, or dry than wet, or it inclines toward one of the extremes, so that it is more hot than cold, or more wet than dry.

If indeed something should be precisely in the middle regarding each pair of opposites, so that it is no more hot than cold, or dry than wet, this will be called simply well-tempered [eukraton]. But when one quality predominates, either in one opposition or in both, it is no longer well-tempered. If something should be more hot than cold, it will be called by whichever quality is stronger; likewise with dry and wet. Similarly, if something should be colder, it will be named cold.

If in each opposition one quality should predominate - either hot and wet together, or hot and dry together, or cold and wet together, or cold and dry together - the body will be named according to its predominant qualities. These four bad mixtures [dyskrasiai], as we said before, most physicians and philosophers recognize. But the other four that arise from half of these, I know not how they overlook, just as they overlook the first and best mixture of all.

[Notes: 
- "eukraton" refers to a well-balanced mixture or temperament
- "dyskrasiai" refers to imbalanced mixtures or poor temperaments
- The text appears to be discussing medical/philosophical theory of elements and qualities]

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ὅτι γε δυνατὸν, ἐπικρατοῦντος τοῦ θερμοῦ, μηδὲν μᾶλλον ὑγρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν εἶναι τὴν κρᾶσιν, ὅσον ἐπὶ ταύτῃ τῇ συζυγίᾳ, πρόδηλον μὲν οἶμαι κᾀκ τῶν ἤδη προειρημένων εἶναι. ῥᾷστον δὲ, κᾂν εἰ μηδὲν προείρητο, συλλογίσασθαι, συγχωρησάντων γε ἅπαξ αὐτῶν, ἑτέραν μὲν εἶναι κρᾶσιν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, ἑτέραν δὲ ξηρὰν καὶ θερμήν. εἰ γὰρ οὐκ ἀναγκαῖόν ἐστι πάντως εἶναι ξηρὰν τὴν θερμὴν, ἀλλ’ ἐγχωρεῖ καὶ ὑγρὰν ὑπάρχειν αὐτὴν, ἐγχωρήσει δηλονότι καὶ μέσην· ἐγγυτέρω γάρ ἐστιν ἡ μέση τῆς ξηρᾶς κράσεως, ἤπερ ἡ ὑγρά. κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον ἐστί τις ἑτέρα ψυχρὰ κρᾶσις, ἐφ’ ἧς ἐστιν ἰσχυρότερον τὸ ψυχρόν· οὐ μὴν οὔθ’ ὑγρὰν, οὔτε ξηρὰν ὑπάρχειν αὐτὴν ἀνάγκη, ἀλλ’ ἐγχωρεῖ καὶ μέσην γενέσθαι· πάλιν γὰρ κᾀνταῦθα τὸν αὐτὸν ἐπάξεις λόγον. ὥστ’, εἴπερ οὐκ ἀναγκαῖόν ἐστιν ὑγρὰν εἶναι τὴν ψυχρὰν, ἀλλ’ , χωρεῖ καὶ ξηρὰν γενέσθαι, πρόδηλον, ὡς καὶ τὴν μέσην ἐγχωρήσει, ἐγγυτέρω γάρ ἐστιν αὕτη τῆς ὑγρᾶς, ἤπερ ἡ ξηρά.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
But that it is indeed possible, when the hot is predominant, for the mixture [krasis: the qualitative “mixture/temperament”] to be no more moist than dry, so far as this pairing [syzygia: the pair moist/dry] is concerned, is, I think, evident even from what has already been said. And even if nothing had been said beforehand, it would be easiest to infer, once they at least grant that one mixture is moist and hot and another dry and hot. For if it is not at all necessary that what is hot be dry, but it is also admissible for it to be moist, then plainly it will be admissible for it to be intermediate as well; for the intermediate mixture is nearer to the dry mixture than the moist is. 

In the same way there is another cold mixture, in which the cold is stronger; yet it is not necessary that it be either moist or dry, but it is admissible for it to be intermediate as well, for here again you will employ the same argument. Therefore, since it is not necessary for what is cold to be moist, but it can also be dry, it is evident that the intermediate will likewise be admissible; for this intermediate is nearer to the moist than the dry is.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the passage:

But that it is possible, when heat predominates, for the mixture [krasis] to be neither more moist nor dry, as far as this combination is concerned, I think is clear even from what has already been said. And it is very easy to deduce, even if nothing had been said before, once they have conceded that there is one mixture that is moist and hot, and another that is dry and hot. For if it is not entirely necessary for what is hot to be dry, but it can also be moist, it will clearly also be possible for it to be intermediate; for the intermediate state is closer to the dry mixture than the moist one is. And in the same way there is another cold mixture, in which the cold is stronger; however, it need not be either moist or dry, but can also be intermediate; for here again you will apply the same reasoning. Therefore, if it is not necessary for what is cold to be moist, but it can also become dry, it is evident that it can also be intermediate, for this is closer to the moist state than the dry one is.

[Notes: 
- "krasis" refers to the medical/philosophical concept of mixture or temperament
- The text appears to be discussing the theory of qualities (hot/cold, wet/dry) common in ancient medical and philosophical writings]
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ὡς οὖν αὗται αἱ δύο δυσκρασίαι κατὰ τὴν ἑτέραν ἀντίθεσιν ἐδείχθησαν, ἡ μὲν θερμὴ μόνον, ἡ δὲ ψυχρά· κατὰ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον ἕτεραι δύο γενήσονται κατὰ τὴν ἑτέραν ἀντίθεσιν, ἡ μὲν ξηρὰ μόνον, ἡ δ’ ὑγρὰ, συμμέτρως ἐχόντων πρὸς ἄλληλα τοῦ θερμοῦ καὶ τοῦ ψυχροῦ. πάλιν γὰρ κᾀνταῦθα φήσομεν, ὥσπερ οὐκ ἔστιν ἀναγκαῖον, ἥ τίς ἐστι ξηρὰ κρᾶσις, εὐθὺς ταύτην εἶναι καὶ θερμὴν, ἀλλ’ ἐνδέχεται καὶ ψυχρὰν ὑπάρχειν, οὐκ ἀδύνατον ἔσται καὶ τὸ μήτε ψυχρὰν εἶναί τινα, μήτε θερμὴν, ἀλλ’ εὔκρατον μὲν κατὰ τοῦτο, ξηρὰν δὲ κατὰ τὴν ἑτέραν ἀντίθεσιν. ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ τὴν ὑγρὰν κρᾶσιν οὐκ ἀναγκαῖον οὔτε θερμὴν, οὔτε ψυχρὰν ὑπάρχειν, ἀλλ’ ἐνδέχεται μέσην ἀμφοῖν εἶναι κατά γε ταύτην τὴν ἀντίθεσιν. εἰ τοίνυν οὐκ ἀναγκαῖον, οὔτε τῇ κατὰ τὸ ψυχρὸν καὶ θερμὸν δυσκρασίᾳ τὴν ἐκ τῆς ἑτέρας ἀντιθέσεως ἕπεσθαι, οὔτ’ ἐκείνῃ τὴν ἐκ ταύτης, ἐνδέχεταί ποτε καὶ τὴν εὔκρατον ὅσον ἐπὶ θερμότητι καὶ ψυχρότητι φύσιν ἤτοι ξηρὰν ἢ ὑγρὰν γενέσθαι, καὶ τὴν ἐν τούτοις πάλιν εὔκρατον ἤτοι θερμὴν ἢ ψυχράν.
paragraphs.openai_translation: So then, just as those two dyscrasias [imbalances] were shown according to the one opposition—the one solely hot, the other cold—so in the same way there will arise another two according to the other opposition, the one solely dry, the other wet, with hot and cold standing in due proportion to one another. For again here too we shall say that, just as it is not necessary that whatever mixture [krâsis: blend/constitution] is dry be immediately also hot, but it may be cold, so it will not be impossible that something be neither cold nor hot, but well-balanced [eúkraton: in equilibrium] in this respect, yet dry according to the other opposition. Likewise, it is not necessary that a wet mixture be either hot or cold; rather, it may be intermediate between both, at least with respect to this opposition. If, then, it is not necessary that the dyscrasia according to cold and hot be accompanied by the one arising from the other opposition, nor that that one be accompanied by the one arising from this, it is sometimes possible that a nature [physis] well-balanced so far as heat and cold are concerned become either dry or wet, and that the one well-balanced in these [i.e., in dryness and wetness] be either hot or cold.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

Just as these two dyscrases [imbalanced conditions] have been shown according to one opposition - one being only hot, the other cold - in the same way, two others will arise according to the other opposition: one being only dry, the other moist, while the hot and cold elements remain in proper proportion to each other. For here again we will say, just as it is not necessary that a constitution which is dry must also immediately be hot, but it can also be cold, so too it will not be impossible for something to be neither cold nor hot, but well-tempered in this respect, while being dry according to the other opposition. Similarly, a moist constitution need not be either hot or cold, but can be intermediate between both, at least according to this opposition. Therefore, if it is not necessary for the dyscrasia of cold and hot to be accompanied by that from the other opposition, nor for that one to be accompanied by this, it is possible sometimes for a nature that is well-tempered in terms of heat and cold to become either dry or moist, and conversely for one that is well-tempered in these qualities to become either hot or cold.

[Note: "dyscrasia/dyscrasis" (δυσκρασία) is a technical medical term referring to an imbalanced mixture or condition of bodily qualities]
paragraphs.gemini_translation: Therefore, just as these two dyscrasias [imbalances] according to the one opposition have been shown—the one being hot only, and the other cold—in the same way two others will arise according to the other opposition—the one being dry only, and the other moist—when the hot and the cold are in due proportion to one another. For here again we will state that, just as it is not necessary that any temperament which is dry must also be hot (for it is possible for it to be cold as well), so it will not be impossible for a temperament to be neither cold nor hot—but rather well-tempered [eucratic] in this respect—while being dry with respect to the other opposition. And in the same way, it is not necessary for the moist temperament to be either hot or cold, but it is possible for it to be intermediate between both, at least with respect to this opposition. If, therefore, it is not necessary either for an imbalance in respect to cold and hot to be accompanied by one from the other opposition, or for the latter to be accompanied by the former, then it is possible for a nature that is well-tempered with respect to heat and coldness to become either dry or moist, and, conversely, for a nature that is well-tempered in these latter qualities to become either hot or cold.

paragraphs.content: ὥστ’ εἶναι καὶ ταύτας τέτταρας ἑτέρας ἐκείνων δυσκρασίας, ὡς οἱ πρόσθεν ἰατροί τε καὶ φιλόσοφοι παρέδοσαν ἡμῖν, καὶ μέσας γε ταύτας τετάχθαι τῶν εὐκράτων ἕξεων καὶ τῶν κατ’ ἀμφοτέρας τὰς ἀντιθέσεις δυσκράτων. ἡ μὲν γὰρ ἄκρως εὔκρατος οὐδετέραν ἀντίθεσιν ἔχει πλεονεκτοῦσαν, ἡ δ’ ἐξ ὑπεναντίου τῆσδε δύσκρατος ἀμφοτέρας μοχθηράς. ἐν μέσῳ δ’ ἐστὶν ἡ κατὰ μὲν τὴν ἑτέραν εὔκρατος, κατὰ δὲ τὴν ἑτέραν δύσκρατος ὑπάρχουσα, ἥτις ἐξ ἡμίσεως μὲν εὔκρατος, ἐξ ἡμίσεως δὲ δύσκρατος οὖσα, μέση δεόντως ἂν εἶναι λέγοιτο τῆς ὅλης εὐκράτου τε καὶ δυσκράτου. καὶ εἴπερ ταῦθ’ οὕτως ἔχει, ὥσπερ οὖν καὶ ἔχει, θαῤῥούντως ἤδη λέγομεν, ἐννέα τὰς πάσας εἶναι τῶν κράσεων διαφορὰς, εὔκρατον μὲν μίαν, οὐκ εὐκράτους δὲ τὰς ὀκτὼ, τέτταρας μὲν ἁπλᾶς, ὑγρὰν, καὶ ξηρὰν, καὶ θερμὴν, καὶ ψυχρὰν, ἄλλας δὲ τέτταρας συνθέτους, ὑγρὰν ἅμα καὶ θερμὴν, καὶ ξηρὰν ἅμα καὶ θερμὴν, καὶ ψυχρὰν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὰν, καὶ ψυχρὰν ἅμα καὶ ξηράν.
paragraphs.openai_translation: So then, there are also these four other imbalances [dyskrasiai: ill-proportioned mixtures] distinct from those, as the earlier physicians and philosophers have handed down to us; and these are set in the middle between the well-balanced conditions [eukrasiai: well-proportioned mixtures] and the ill-balanced ones according to both oppositions. For the condition that is perfectly well-balanced has neither opposition in excess, whereas the ill-balanced condition that is the contrary of this has both in a bad way. In between is the condition which is, with respect to the one opposition, well-balanced, but with respect to the other, ill-balanced—being half well-balanced and half ill-balanced—so that it might rightly be called intermediate between the wholly well-balanced and the ill-balanced. And if these things are so—as indeed they are—we may now confidently say that there are, in all, nine kinds of mixtures [kraseis]: one that is well-balanced, and eight that are not well-balanced—four simple (moist, dry, hot, cold) and four composite (moist together with hot, dry together with hot, cold together with moist, and cold together with dry).
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation:

So there are these other four dyscrases [imbalanced conditions] distinct from those previously mentioned, as the earlier physicians and philosophers have handed down to us, and these are positioned between the well-balanced states and those that are imbalanced in both opposing qualities. For the perfectly well-balanced state has neither opposition predominating, while its complete opposite, the dyscrastic state, has both qualities in a poor condition. In between is the state that is well-balanced in one opposition but dyscrastic in the other, which, being half well-balanced and half dyscrastic, would properly be called intermediate between the completely well-balanced and completely dyscrastic states. And if these things are so, as indeed they are, we can now confidently say that there are nine different types of temperaments in total: one well-balanced, and eight not well-balanced - four simple ones (moist, dry, hot, and cold), and four composite ones (moist and hot together, dry and hot together, cold and moist together, and cold and dry together).

[Note: "krasis/dyscrasis" refers to the medical theory of bodily temperaments or mixtures of qualities, fundamental to ancient Greek medicine]
paragraphs.gemini_translation: So that there are these four imbalances [dyskrasiai], different from the others, as the physicians and philosophers of old have handed down to us; and that these are ranked as intermediate between the well-balanced states and those that are imbalanced with respect to both oppositions. For the perfectly balanced state has neither opposition predominating, whereas the imbalanced state at the opposite extreme to this has both oppositions faulty. In the middle is the state that is balanced with respect to one opposition but imbalanced with respect to the other; and since this state is half balanced and half imbalanced, it would rightly be called intermediate between the wholly balanced and the wholly imbalanced. And if these things are so—as indeed they are—we may now state with confidence that there are nine variations of the temperaments [krāseis] in all: one balanced, and eight unbalanced. Of these, four are simple—the wet, the dry, the hot, and the cold—and the other four are compound: the wet and hot, the dry and hot, the cold and wet, and the cold and dry.

paragraphs.content: Ἐν ἑκάστῃ δὲ τῶν εἰρημένων κράσεων τὸ μᾶλλόν τε καὶ τὸ ἦττον πάμπολυ, κατά τε τὰς ἁπλᾶς λεγομένας κράσεις, ἐπί τε τῆς ὅλης οὐσίας, ἤδη δὲ καὶ καθ’ ἕν ὁτιοῦν γένος. εἰ δή τις βούλεται διαγνωστικὸς εἶναι κράσεων, ἄρχεσθαι τούτῳ προσήκει τῆς γυμνασίας ἀπὸ τῶν καθ’ ἕκαστον γένος εὐκράτων τε καὶ μέσων φύσεων. ἐκείναις γὰρ τὰς ἄλλας παραβάλλων, ῥᾳδίως ἐξευρήσει τὸ πλεονάζον ἢ τὸ λεῖπον ἐν ἑκάστῃ. περὶ πρώτων οὖν ῥητέον τῶν ἁπλῶς λεγομένων εὐκράτων τε καὶ δυσκράτων, ἅς ἐπὶ πάσης οὐσίας γεννητῆς, οὐκ ἐπὶ ζώων μόνον, ἢ φυτῶν, ἔφαμεν ἐξετάζεσθαι. πάλιν δὲ κᾀνταῦθα τό γε τοσοῦτο χρὴ διαστείλασθαι περὶ ὀνομάτων, ὡς θερμὴ κρᾶσις ἄλλη μέν ἐστιν ἐνεργείᾳ, δυνάμει δ’ ἄλλη, καὶ ὡς δυνάμει ταῦτ’ εἶναι λέγομεν, ὅσα μήπω μέν ἐστιν ὃ λέγεται, ῥᾷστον δ’ αὐτοῖς γενέσθαι, φυσικήν τινα ἐπιτηδειότητα κεκτημένοις εἰς τὸ γενέσθαι. περὶ πρώτων οὖν διέλθωμεν τῶν ἐνεργείᾳ θερμῶν καὶ ψυχρῶν, καὶ ξηρῶν καὶ ὑγρῶν, ἀπὸ τῆς συμπάσης οὐσίας ἀρξάμενοι, κᾄπειτα μεταβῶμεν ἐπί τε τὰ ζῶα καὶ τὰ φυτά. τελέως γὰρ ἂν οὕτως ἡμῖν ἀπειργασμένον εἴη τὸ προτεθέν. ἐπειδὴ τοίνυν τὸ μέσον ἐν ἅπαντι γένει, καὶ μάλιστα κατὰ τὰς συμπάσας οὐσίας, ἐκ τῆς τῶν ἄκρων μίξεως γίνεται, χρὴ καὶ τὴν νόησιν αὐτοῦ καὶ τὴν διάγνωσιν ἐξ ἐκείνων συνίστασθαι. τὸ μὲν δὴ τῆς νοήσεως ῥᾶστον. ἀπὸ γὰρ τοῦ θερμοτάτου πάντων τῶν εἰς αἴσθησιν ἡκόντων, οἷον ἤτοι πυρὸς, ἤ τινος ὕδατος ἄκρως ζέοντος, ἐπὶ τὸ ψυχρότατον κατελθόντες ἁπάντων ὧν ἴσμεν, οἶον κρύσταλλον, ἢ χιόνα, νοήσαντές τι διάστημα, μέσον ἀκριβῶς τοῦτο τέμνομεν. οὕτω γὰρ ἐξευρήσομεν τῇ νοήσει τὸ σύμμετρον, ὅπερ ἑκατέρου τῶν ἄκρων ἴσον ἀπέχει.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
In each of the mixtures mentioned, the “more” and the “less” admit of great variety, both with respect to the so‑called simple mixtures and with respect to the whole substance, and indeed even within each particular kind whatsoever. If, then, someone wishes to be a discerner of mixtures [kraseis], it is fitting that he begin his training from the well‑balanced [eukratai] and middle natures in each several kind. For by comparing the others to these, he will easily discover, in each case, what exceeds or what is lacking.

We must therefore first speak about those that are called simply well‑balanced and ill‑balanced [dyskratai], which we said are to be examined in every generated substance, not only in animals or in plants. Again, even here one must at least make this distinction concerning terms: that a “hot mixture” is one thing in actuality, and another in potentiality; and that we say things are such “in potentiality” when they are not yet what is predicated, but it is easiest for them to become so, since they possess some natural suitability for coming to be.

Let us then first go through what are hot and cold, and dry and moist, in actuality, beginning from total substance, and thereafter pass on to animals and plants. For in this way our proposed undertaking would be brought to completion.

Since, then, the mean in every kind—and most of all with respect to total substances—arises from the blending of extremes, our conception of it and our diagnosis must be constituted from those extremes. The conceptual part is easiest. For, starting from the hottest of all things that come within perception, such as fire or some water at an extreme boil, and descending to the coldest of all we know, such as crystal or snow, after conceiving some interval, we divide it exactly in the middle. For thus, by thought, we shall discover the proportionate mean [to symmetron], which is equally distant from each of the extremes.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the passage:

In each of the aforementioned mixtures [temperaments/kraseis], there exists a great variety of degree, both more and less, regarding the so-called simple mixtures, in relation to the whole substance, and indeed also in each particular kind. If someone wishes to become skilled in diagnosing temperaments, it is fitting for them to begin their practice with the well-tempered and median natures in each category. For by comparing others to these, one will easily discover what is excessive or deficient in each case.

We must first discuss those simply called well-tempered and poorly-tempered, which we said are examined in all generated substance, not only in animals or plants. Again, here we must make this much distinction concerning terms: that one thermal mixture [krasis] exists in actuality, and another in potentiality, and we say things exist in potentiality when they are not yet what they are said to be, but can most easily become so, having acquired some natural fitness for becoming such.

Let us first discuss things that are hot, cold, dry, and moist in actuality, beginning from substance as a whole, and then proceed to animals and plants. For thus our proposed task would be completely accomplished. Since the mean in every kind, and especially regarding substances as a whole, comes about from the mixture of extremes, both its conception and diagnosis must be established from these. The matter of conception is quite simple: starting from the hottest of all things that come to perception, such as fire or extremely boiling water, and descending to the coldest of all things we know, such as ice or snow, we conceive of an interval and divide this precisely in the middle. For thus we will discover through conception the symmetrical mean, which is equally distant from each extreme.

[Note: "krasis" (κρᾶσις) refers to a mixture or temperament, a key concept in ancient medical and philosophical theory]
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
In each of the aforementioned temperaments [kraseis], there is a very great variation of degree, both in the so-called simple temperaments and in the substance as a whole, and indeed also within any single kind. If, then, anyone wishes to be skilled in discerning temperaments, it is proper for him to begin his training with the well-tempered and intermediate natures within each kind. For by comparing the others to these, he will easily discover the excess or deficiency in each one.

Therefore, we must speak first of the temperaments that are simply called well-tempered and ill-tempered, which, as we said, are to be examined in every generated substance, not only in animals or plants. And here again, it is necessary to make at least this much of a distinction concerning terms: that a hot temperament in actuality [energeia] is one thing, and in potentiality [dynamis] another; and that we say things exist in potentiality which are not yet what they are called, but can very easily become so, possessing a certain natural aptitude for this

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ καὶ κατασκευάσαι πως αὐτὸ δυνάμεθα, τὸν ἴσον ὄγκον κρυστάλλου μίξαντες ὕδατι ζέοντι. τὸ γὰρ ἐξ ἀμφοῖν κραθὲν ἴσον ἑκατέρου τῶν ἄκρων ἀφέξει, τοῦ τε καίοντος καὶ τοῦ ναρκοῦντος διὰ ψύξιν. οὔκουν οὐδὲν ἔτι χαλεπόν ἐστι, τοῦ κραθέντος οὕτως ἁψαμένους, ἔχειν τὸ μέσον ἁπάσης οὐσίας ἐν τῇ κατὰ τὸ θερμόν τε καὶ ψυχρὸν ἀντιθέσει, καὶ μεμνῆσθαι τούτου, καὶ κρίνειν ἅπαντα τἄλλα καθάπερ τινὶ κανόνι παραβάλλοντας. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ ξηρὰν γῆν, ἢ τέφραν, ἤ τι τοιοῦτο ἕτερον ἀκριβῶς αὐχμηρὸν ἀναδεύσας ὕδατι κατὰ τὸν ὄγκον ἴσῳ, τὸ μέσον ἐργάσῃ σῶμα τῆς κατὰ τὸν ξηρόν τε καὶ ὑγρὸν ἀντιθέσεως. οὔκουν οὐδὲ ἐνταῦθα χαλεπὸν οὐδὲν, ὄψει τε ἅμα καὶ ἁφῇ τὸ τοιοῦτο σῶμα διαγνόντας, παραθέσθαι τῇ μνήμῃ, καὶ τούτῳ κανόνι τε καὶ κριτηρίῳ χρῆσθαι πρὸς τὴν τῶν ἐλλειπόντων ἢ πλεοναζόντων ὑγρῶν καὶ ξηρῶν διάγνωσιν. ἔστω δὲ δηλονότι τὸ κρινόμενον σῶμα συμμέτρως θερμόν. εἰ γὰρ εἰς ἄκρον ἤτοι θερμότητος ἢ ψύξεως ἄγοιτο, τουτὶ τὸ μέσον ὑγροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ σῶμα φαντασίαν ἐνίοτε παρέξει ψευδῆ, καὶ δόξει ποτὲ μὲν ὑγρότερον εἶναι τοῦ συμμέτρου, ποτὲ δὲ ξηρότερον. εἰ μὲν γὰρ θερμανθείη πλέον, ἢ δεῖ, τηκόμενόν τε καὶ ῥέον, ὑγροτέρου φαντασίαν ἑαυτοῦ παρέξει. ψυχόμενον δὲ περαιτέρω τοῦ προσήκοντος, ἵσταταί τε καὶ πήγνυται, καὶ ἀκίνητον γίνεται, καὶ σκληρὸν ἁπτομένοις φαίνεται, κᾀκ τούτου φαντασίαν προβάλλει ψευδῆ ξηρότητος. εἰ δ’, ὥσπερ ὑγροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ μετέσχεν ἴσον, οὕτω καὶ θερμότητός τε καὶ ψύξεως εἴη μέσον, οὔτε σκληρὸν, οὔτε μαλακὸν ἁπτομένῳ φαίνεται τὸ τοιοῦτο σῶμα. τὸ μὲν οὖν ὅλα δι’ ὅλων αὐτὰ κεράσαι, τὸ θερμὸν λέγω καὶ τὸ ψυχρὸν, καὶ τὸ ξηρὸν καὶ τὸ ὑγρὸν, ἀδύνατον ἀνθρώπῳ. γῆ γὰρ ὑγρῷ φυραθεῖσα μέμικται μὲν, ὡς ἄν τῳ δόξειε, καὶ οὕτω κέκραται πᾶσα παντὶ, παράθεσις μήν ἐστι τὸ τοιοῦτο κατὰ σμικρὰ, καὶ οὐ δι’ ὅλων κρᾶσις, ἀλλὰ τὸ δι’ ὅλων ἄμφω κεράσαι θεοῦ καὶ φύσεως ἔργον. ἔτι δὲ μᾶλλον, εἰ τὸ θερμὸν καὶ τὸ ψυχρὸν ὅλα δι’ ὅλων ἀλλήλοις κεραννύοιτο. τὸ μέντοι παράθεσιν ἐργάσασθαι τοιαύτην, ὡς ἐκφεύγειν τὴν αἴσθησιν ἕκαστον τῶν ἁπλῶν σωμάτων, οὐ φύσεως τοῦτό γε μόνης ἢ θεοῦ τὸ ἔργον, ἀλλὰ καὶ ἡμέτερόν ἐστιν. οὐδὲ γὰρ χαλεπὸν ὑγροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ μέσον ἐργάσασθαι πηλὸν ἐκ τῆς τοιαύτης μίξεως· ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ. καί σοι φανεῖται τὸ τοιοῦτο σῶμα καὶ τῇ θερμότητι μὲν καὶ τῇ ψυχρότητι εὔκρατον, ἀλλὰ καὶ σκληρότητός τε καὶ μαλακότητος ἐν τῷ μέσῳ. τοιοῦτο δ’ ἐστὶ καὶ τὸ τῶν ἀνθρώπων δέρμα, μέσον ἀκριβῶς ἁπάντων τῶν ἐσχάτων, θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ, καὶ σκληροῦ καὶ μαλακοῦ, καὶ τούτου μάλιστα τὸ κατὰ τὴν χεῖρα. γνώμων γὰρ αὕτη πάντων ἔμελλεν ἔσεσθαι τῶν αἰσθητῶν, ὄργανον ἁπτικὸν ὑπὸ τῆς φύσεως ἀπεργασθεῖσα τῷ φρονιμωτάτῳ τῶν ζώων οἰκεῖον. ἴσον οὖν ἀπέχειν αὐτὴν ἐχρῆν ἁπάντων τῶν ἄκρων, θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ, καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ. καὶ δὴ καὶ γέγονεν ἐκ τῆς τούτων ἁπάντων ἰσομοιρίας, οὐ μιχθέντων μόνον, ἀλλὰ καὶ δι’ ὅλων ἀλλήλοις κερασθέντων, ὅπερ οὐκ ἔτ’ οὐδεὶς ἡμῶν ἐργάσασθαι δυνατός ἐστιν, ἀλλὰ φύσεως τὸ ἔργον.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
But we can also in some way construct it, by mixing an equal volume of crystal [i.e., ice] with boiling water. For what is blended from the two will be equal to each of the extremes, both to what burns and to what benumbs through cold. There is then no longer any difficulty: by touching the mixture prepared in this way, we possess the mean of the whole substance in the opposition of hot and cold, and we can remember this and judge all other things by comparing them to it as to a rule [kanon, standard]. And indeed, by stirring dry earth, or ash, or some other such precisely parched stuff with water in an equal volume, you will produce a body that is the mean in the opposition of dry and moist. There is no difficulty here either: once you have discerned such a body by sight and touch, set it before your memory, and use this as a rule and criterion for diagnosing fluids and dries that are deficient or in excess.

Let the body that judges be, plainly, moderately warm. For if it be carried to an extreme either of heat or of cold, this mean body of moist and dry will sometimes give a false appearance: at one time it will seem wetter than the proportionate measure, at another drier. For if it be heated more than is necessary, as it melts and flows it will provide an impression of being wetter. But if it is cooled beyond what is fitting, it both sets and congeals, becomes motionless, appears hard to the touch, and from this projects a false impression of dryness. If, however, just as it shared equally in moist and dry, it were also at the mean of heat and cold, such a body would appear to the
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the passage:

But we can also construct this artificially, by mixing an equal mass of ice with boiling water. For the mixture of both will be equally distant from each extreme - from that which burns and that which numbs through cold. Thus it is no longer difficult, having touched what is mixed in this way, to have the mean of all substance in the opposition between hot and cold, to remember this, and to judge all other things by comparing them to it as if to a standard. Indeed, by thoroughly mixing dry earth, or ash, or some other such completely dry substance with an equal volume of water, you will create a substance that is intermediate in the opposition between dry and wet. So here too it is not difficult, having recognized such a substance by both sight and touch, to store it in memory and use it as a standard and criterion for diagnosing deficiencies or excesses of wet and dry qualities. The substance being judged should clearly be moderately warm. For if it is brought to an extreme of either heat or cold, this intermediate substance between wet and dry will sometimes present a false appearance, seeming at times wetter than balanced, at times drier. For if it is heated more than necessary, melting and flowing, it will present the appearance of being wetter than it is. When cooled beyond what is appropriate, it becomes fixed and solid, becomes immobile, and appears hard to the touch, thereby presenting a false appearance of dryness.

paragraphs.content: ὅσα μὲν οὖν σκληρότερα τοῦ δέρματός ἐστι μόρια, καθάπερ ὀστᾶ, καὶ χόνδροι, καὶ κέρατα, καὶ τρίχες, ὄνυχές τε καὶ σύνδεσμοι, καὶ ὁπλαὶ, καὶ πλῆκτρα, πλέον ἐν τούτοις ἐστὶ τὸ ξηρόν· ὅσα δὲ μαλακώτερα, καθάπερ αἷμα, καὶ φλέγμα, καὶ πιμελὴ, καὶ στέαρ, καὶ μυελὸς, ἐγκέφαλός τε καὶ νωτιαῖος, ὑγροῦ πλέον ἐν τούτοις ἐστὶν, ἢ ξηροῦ. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ ὅσῳ τὸ πάντων ξηρότατον ἐν ἀνθρώπῳ μόριον ὑπερβάλλει ξηρότητι τοῦ δέρματος, τοσούτῳ πάλιν ἀπολείπεται τὸ ὑγρότατον. ἔοικε δέ πως ὁ λόγος ἤδη τῶν χρησιμωτάτων αὐτῶν ἐφάπτεσθαι, καὶ διδάσκειν, ἅμα μὲν ὡς οὐχὶ ζώων μόνον, ἀλλὰ καὶ τῶν ἄλλων ἁπάντων σωμάτων εὐκρατότατός ἐστιν ὁ ἄνθρωπος, ἅμα δ’ ὡς τῶν ἐν αὐτῷ μορίων τὸ τῆς χειρὸς δέρμα τὸ ἔσωθεν ἁπάσας ἐκπέφευγεν ἀκριβῶς τὰς ὑπερβολάς. ἐπιστήσαντες οὖν πάλιν ἐνταῦθα τὸν λόγον ἐπισκεψώμεθα, τίς ἄριστα πάντων κέκραται ἄνθρωπος, ὃν καὶ τῆς ὅλης μὲν οὐσίας, ἔτι δὲ μᾶλλον ἀνθρώπων καὶ τῶν ἄλλων ζώων ἐν τῷ μέσῳ χρὴ τάξαντας, καθάπερ τινὰ κανόνα καὶ γνώμονα, τοὺς ἄλλους ἅπαντας τούτῳ παραβάλλοντας, θερμοὺς καὶ ψυχροὺς, καὶ ξηροὺς καὶ ὑγροὺς ὀνομάζειν. δεῖ δὲ συνδραμεῖν ἐς ταὐτὸν ἐπὶ τοῦδε πολλὰ γνωρίσματα. καὶ γὰρ ὡς πρὸς τὴν ὅλην οὐσίαν ἐξετάζοντι μέσον φαίνεσθαι χρὴ τὸν τοιοῦτον, ἔτι δὲ μᾶλλον ὡς πρὸς ἀνθρώπους τε καὶ ζῶα. τὰ μὲν οὖν ἁπάσης τῆς οὐσίας γνωρίσματα κοινὰ προείρηται· τὰ δ’ ὡς ἐν ζώων εἴδεσιν ἐνεργείας τελειότητι κρίνεται τῆς ἑκάστῳ πρεπούσης. πρέπει δ’ ἀνθρώπῳ μὲν εἶναι σοφωτάτῳ, κυνὶ δὲ πρᾳοτάτῳ τε ἅμα καὶ ἀλκιμωτάτῳ, λέοντι δὲ ἀλκιμωτάτῳ μόνον, ὥσπερ γε καὶ προβάτῳ πρᾳοτάτω. καὶ μέν με καὶ ὡς τὰς τοῦ σώματος ἐνεργείας οἰκείας εἶναι χρὴ τῷ τῆς ψυχῆς ἤθει, δέδεικται μὲν καὶ πρὸς Ἀριστοτέλους ἐν τοῖς περὶ ζώων μορίων· λέλεκται δὲ καὶ πρὸς ἡμῶν ὑπὲρ αὐτῶν οὐδὲν ἦττον. ἡ μὲν δὴ μέθοδος ἥδε. τὸ δ’ ἀσκῆσαι γνωρίζειν ἑτοίμως ἐν ἑκάστῳ γένει ζώου καὶ κατὰ τὰ σύμπαντα τὸ μέσον, οὐ τοῦ τυχόντος ἀνδρὸς, ἀλλ’ ἐσχάτως ἐστὶ φιλοπόνου, καὶ διὰ μακρᾶς ἐμπειρίας καὶ πολλῆς γνώσεως ἁπάντων τῶν κατὰ μέρος ἐξευρίσκειν δυναμένου τὸ μέσον. οὕτω γοῦν καὶ πλάσται, καὶ γραφεῖς, ἀνδριαντοποιοί τε καὶ ὅλως ἀγαλματοποιοὶ τὰ κάλλιστα γράφουσί τε καὶ πλάττουσι καθ’ ἕκαστον εἶδος, οἶον ἄνθρωπον εὐμορφότατον, ἢ ἵππον, ἢ βοῦν, ἢ λέοντα, τὸ μέσον ἐν ἐκείνῳ τῷ γένει σκοποῦντες. καί πού τις ἀνδριὰς ἐπαινεῖται, Πολυκλείτου κανὼν ὀνομαζόμενος, ἐκ τοῦ πάντων τῶν μορίων ἀκριβῆ τὴν πρὸς ἄλληλα συμμετρίαν ἔχειν ὀνόματος τοιούτου τυχών. ἔστι μὲν οὖν ἐπιπλέον, ὃν νῦν ἡμεῖς ἐζητοῦμεν, ἢ ὁ κανὼν οὗτος. οὐ μόνον γὰρ ὑγρότητός τε καὶ ξηρότητος ἐν τῷ μέσῳ καθέστηκεν ὁ οὕτως εὔσαρκος ἄνθρωπος, ἀλλὰ καὶ διαπλάσεως ἀρίστης τετύχηκεν, ἴσως μὲν ἑπομένης τῇ τῶν τεσσάρων στοιχείων εὐκρασίᾳ, τάχα δέ τινα θειοτέραν ἀρχὴν ἑτέραν ἐχούσης ἄνωθεν. ἀλλὰ τό γε πάντως εὔκρατον εἶναι τὸν τοιοῦτον ἐξ ἀνάγκης ὑπάρχει· τὸ γὰρ ἐν εὐσαρκίᾳ σύμμετρον εὐκρασίας ἐστὶν ἔγγονον. εὐθὺς δ’ ὑπάρχει τῷ τοιούτῳ σώματι, καὶ ταῖς ἐνεργείαις ἄριστα διακεῖσθαι, καὶ σκληρότητός τε καὶ μαλακότητος ἔχειν μετρίως, θερμότητός τε καὶ ψυχρότητος· καὶ ταῦθ’ ὑπάρχειν ἅπαντα τῷ δέρματι, καὶ τούτῳ μάλιστα τῷ τῆς χειρὸς ἐντὸς, ὅταν μηδένα τύλον ἔχῃ τοιοῦτον, οἷον τοῖς ἐρέττουσί τε καὶ σκάπτουσι γίνεται. διττῆς γὰρ ἕνεκα χρείας τῶν χειρῶν γεγενημένων, ἁφῆς καὶ ἀντιλήψεως, αἱ μαλακαὶ μὲν εἰς τὴν τῆς ἁφῆς ἀκρίβειαν, αἱ σκληραὶ δὲ εἰς τὴν τῆς ἀντιλήψεως ἰσχὺν ἐπιτηδειότεραι. καὶ δὴ καὶ τὸ δέρμα τὸ μέσον οὐ μόνον ἁπάντων ἀνθρωπίνων μορίων, ἀλλὰ καὶ τῆς ὅλης οὐσίας, καὶ πάντων τῶν ἐν γενέσει καὶ φθορᾷ σωμάτων, οὐ τὸ τετυλωμένον ἐστὶ καὶ σκληρὸν καὶ λιθῶδες, ἀλλὰ τὸ κατὰ φύσιν ἔχον, ᾧ δὴ καὶ μάλιστά φαμεν ἀκριβοῦσθαι τὴν ἁφήν.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, in all the parts that are harder than the skin—such as bones, cartilages, horns, hairs, nails, ligaments, shields, and clubs—the dry element is predominant; whereas in those that are softer—such as blood, phlegm, fat [pimelē], suet [stéar], marrow, the brain and spinal cord—the moist element is predominant rather than the dry. Indeed, just as much as the driest part in a human being exceeds the skin in dryness, by just so much in turn the moistest part falls short of it. The discussion now seems in some way to be touching upon their most useful features, and to be showing both that the human being is the most well-balanced [eukratotatos: best “mixed”] not only among animals but among all other bodies, and that among the parts within him the skin of the hand on the inside has most precisely escaped every excess. Let us therefore pause again at this point and examine which human being is best mixed of all, whom we ought to place in the middle—both in respect of the whole substance and, even more, in respect of humans and other animals—and use as a kind of rule and measure, comparing all others to him and calling them hot or cold, and dry or moist. Many diagnostic marks must converge upon this same point. For one examining with reference to the whole substance should find such a person to appear a mean, and even more so with reference to humans and other animals. The common signs with respect to the whole substance have been stated beforehand; but as concerns the species of animals, the judgment is made by the perfection of the activity [energeia: function] appropriate to each. It befits a human being to be most wise, a dog to be at once the gentlest and the most valiant, a lion to be only the most valiant, just as a sheep is the gentlest. That the bodily activities ought to be suited to the character of the soul has been shown also by Aristotle in the Parts of Animals, and we too have spoken about this no less. Such, then, is the method. But the training that enables one to recognize readily, in each genus of animal and in general, the mean—not the task of a random man, but of one extremely industrious, who through
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is my translation of the Greek passage:

Therefore, those parts that are harder than skin, such as bones, cartilage, horns, hair, nails, ligaments, hooves, and spurs - in these the dry element predominates. But in those parts that are softer, such as blood, phlegm, soft fat, hard fat, marrow, brain and spinal cord - in these there is more of the moist element than the dry. Indeed, just as the driest part in humans exceeds the skin in dryness, so too the moistest part falls short of it.

The discussion now seems to touch upon most useful matters, teaching that humans are not only the most well-tempered of animals, but of all bodies, and that among the parts in humans, the skin on the inside of the hand precisely avoids all extremes. Let us pause here and consider what type of human is best-tempered of all, whom we must position in the middle of all substance, and even more so among humans and other animals, like some canon and measure, comparing all others to this standard when calling them hot, cold, dry, or moist.

Many identifying characteristics must converge in this case. For such a person must appear intermediate both in relation to all substance, and even more so in relation to humans and animals. The characteristics of all substance have been stated before; but among animal species, they are judged by the perfection of activity appropriate to each. It is fitting for a human to be wisest, for a dog to be both gentlest and bravest, for a lion to be bravest only, just as for a sheep to be gentlest.

Indeed, that bodily activities should correspond to the character of the soul has been shown by Aristotle in his work On the Parts of Animals, and has been discussed no less by us. This is the method. But to practice recognizing readily what is intermediate in each kind of animal and in all respects is not for just anyone, but requires someone extremely industrious who can discover the mean through long experience and extensive knowledge of all particulars.

[The text continues discussing how sculptors and painters create idealized forms, mentioning Polykleitos' Canon, and concludes with discussion of the proper qualities of human skin, especially that of the hand.]

[Note: This is a medical/philosophical text that appears to be discussing the theory of elements, temperaments, and proper proportion in human physiology.]

paragraphs.content: ὅτι μὲν οὖν σκληρότητός τε καὶ μαλακότητος ἐν τῷ μέσῳ καθέστηκεν ἁπάντων μορίων, ἱκανῶς ἐναργές· ὅτι δὲ καὶ θερμότητος καὶ ψυχρότητος, ἐκ τῆς οὐσίας ἂν αὐτοῦ μάλιστα καταμάθοις. ἔστι γὰρ οἷον ἔναιμόν τι νεῦρον, ἀκριβῶς μέσον ὑπάρχον νεύρου τε καὶ σαρκὸς, ὡς εἰ καὶ κραθέντων ἀμφοῖν ἐγένετο. ἀλλὰ νεῦρον μὲν ἅπαν ἄναιμόν τε καὶ ψυχρόν· σὰρξ δὲ πολύαιμός τε καὶ θερμή· μέσον δ’ ἀμφοῖν τὸ δέρμα, μήτ’ ἄναιμον τὸ πάμπαν, ὡς νεῦρον, ἀλλὰ μηδὲ πολύαιμον, ὡς ἡ σὰρξ, γενόμενον. εἰ δὴ τοῦτο κανόνα τε καὶ οἷον κριτήριον ἁπάντων τῶν τοῦ ζώου μορίων προστησάμενος ἐξετάζεις τε καὶ παραβάλλεις αὐτῷ τἄλλα, τὰς ὀκτὼ διαφορὰς εὑρήσεις τῆς δυσκρασίας ἐν αὐτοῖς. καὶ δὴ καὶ κατὰ μέρος δίειμί σοι περὶ πάντων ἑξῆς. φλέγμα μὲν οὖν ὑγρότατόν ἐστι καὶ ψυχρότατον, αἷμα δὲ θερμότατον, ἀλλ’ οὐχ οὕτως ὑγρὸν, ὡς τὸ φλέγμα. θρὶξ δὲ ξηροτάτη τε καὶ ψυχροτάτη· ἧττον δὲ αὐτῆς ὀστοῦν ψυχρόν ἐστι καὶ ξηρὸν, καὶ τοῦδε χόνδρος ἧττον ξηρός. ἐφεξῆς δὲ χόνδρῳ σύνδεσμος, καὶ ὃν χονδροσύνδεσμον ὀνομάζουσιν, ἔπειτα τένων, εἶθ’ ὑμὴν, καὶ ἀρτηρία, καὶ φλὲψ, αὐτὰ δηλονότι τὰ σώματα τῶν ἀγγείων, εἶθ’ ὅσα νεῦρα σκληρά. τὰ δὲ μαλακὰ νεῦρα κατὰ τὴν τοῦ δέρματος ὑπάρχει φύσιν ἐν τῇ καθ’ ὑγρότητά τε καὶ ξηρότητα μεσότητι. κατὰ γὰρ τὴν ἑτέραν ἀντίθεσιν οὐκ ἔτι μέσον θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ τὸ νεῦρον μαλακὸν, ἀλλὰ τοσοῦτον ἀπολείπεται θερμότητος, ὅσον καὶ αἵματος. οὕτω δὲ καὶ τἄλλα σύμπαντα τὰ πρόσθεν εἰρημένα τοσούτῳ ψυχρότερα δέρματος, ὅσῳ καὶ ἀναιμότερα. καὶ οἵ γε χιτῶνες αὐτοὶ τῶν ἐναιμοτάτων ἀγγείων, ἀρτηρίας λέγω καὶ φλεβὸς, ἄναιμοί τέ εἰσι καὶ ψυχροὶ τῇ φύσει· τῇ γειτνιάσει δὲ τοῦ αἵματος θερμαίνονται, καὶ εἰς μέσην ἀφικνοῦνται κατάστασιν κράσεως. τὸ δὲ αἷμα πάλιν αὐτὸ παρὰ τῆς καρδίας ἔχει τὴν θερμασίαν. φύσει γὰρ ἐκεῖνο τὸ σπλάγχνον ἁπάντων ἐστὶ τῶν τοῦ ζώου μορίων ἐναιμότατόν τε ἅμα καὶ θερμότατον· ἐφεξῆς δ’ αὐτῷ τὸ ἧπαρ.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
That the skin stands as a mean, in respect of both hardness and softness, among all the parts is sufficiently evident; and that it also stands as a mean between heat and cold you would most of all learn from its substance. For it is, as it were, a kind of blood‑bearing nerve [neuron: sinew/nerve], being precisely a middle between nerve and flesh, as though it had come to be from a mixture of both. Now nerve is entirely bloodless and cold, whereas flesh is very full of blood and warm; but the skin is a middle between the two, being neither altogether bloodless, like nerve, nor very full of blood, like flesh.

If, then, taking this as a rule and, as it were, a criterion for all the parts of the living creature, you examine and compare the others with it, you will find in them the eight differences of dyscrasia [imbalanced mixture]. And now I will go through them for you in order, part by part. Phlegm is the wettest and coldest; blood is the warmest, though not so wet as phlegm. Hair is the driest and coldest; bone is less cold and dry than hair, and cartilage is less dry than bone. Next after cartilage comes ligament [syndesmos], and what they call cartilaginous‑ligament [chondrosyndesmos], then tendon, then membrane [hymen], and artery, and vein—by which I mean the very bodies of the vessels—and thereafter all the hard nerves. The soft nerves, in respect of wetness and dryness, have the nature of the skin, occupying the middle condition; but in the other opposition, they are no longer a mean between hot and cold—the soft nerve falls short of heat by as much as blood exceeds it. And so too all the previously mentioned parts are colder than the skin by just so much as they are also more bloodless.

Even the coats [chitones] themselves of the most blood‑bearing vessels—by which I mean the artery and the vein—are by nature bloodless and cold; but by their proximity to the blood they are warmed, and they reach a middle state of mixture [krasis]. The blood itself, in turn, derives its heating from the heart. For by nature that organ, among all the parts of the living creature, is at once the most full of blood and the warmest; next to it comes the liver.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the passage:

It is sufficiently clear that skin stands in the middle of all parts with respect to hardness and softness. And that it also stands in the middle regarding heat and cold, you might best learn from its substance. For it is like a blood-containing sinew, being precisely intermediate between sinew and flesh, as if it had been formed from both being mixed together. Now, every sinew is bloodless and cold, while flesh is rich in blood and warm. The skin is intermediate between both, being neither entirely bloodless like sinew, nor rich in blood like flesh.

If indeed you set this up as a standard and criterion of all parts of the animal, and examine and compare other things to it, you will find the eight differences of poor mixture [dyskrasia] in them. And I shall now go through all of them in detail for you in order. Phlegm is the most moist and cold, while blood is the hottest, though not as moist as phlegm. Hair is the driest and coldest; bone is less cold and dry than hair, and cartilage is less dry than bone. After cartilage comes ligament, and what they call cartilaginous ligament, then tendon, then membrane, and artery, and vein (that is, the actual bodies of the vessels), then the hard sinews.

The soft sinews exist according to the nature of skin in terms of the mean between moisture and dryness. For in the other opposition, the soft sinew is no longer intermediate between hot and cold, but falls as far short of heat as it does of blood. Thus also all the other things mentioned before are as much colder than skin as they are more bloodless. And the coats themselves of the most blood-rich vessels - I mean artery and vein - are bloodless and cold by nature, but are warmed by their proximity to blood, and arrive at a middle state of mixture [krasis]. The blood itself, in turn, has its warmth from the heart. For by nature that organ is of all parts of the animal the most rich in blood and simultaneously the warmest; and after it comes the liver.

[Note: I've preserved key technical terms like dyskrasia (poor mixture/bad temperament) and krasis (mixture/temperament) which are important medical/philosophical concepts in ancient Greek medicine]

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἡ μὲν καρδία βραχὺ δέρματος ἀποδεῖ σκληρότητι, τὸ δ’ ἧπαρ πολύ. καὶ τοίνυν ὑγροτέρα τοσούτῳ δέρματός ἐστιν, ὅσῳ μαλακωτέρα. καὶ μὴν δὴ καὶ σὰρξ ὑγροτέρα δέρματος· ἀλλ’ αὕτη μὲν καὶ θερμοτέρα. νωτιαῖος δὲ ὑγρότερος μὲν, ἀλλὰ καὶ ψυχρότερος· καὶ τοῦδε μᾶλλον ἐγκέφαλος υγρότερος, ἔτι δὲ τούτου μᾶλλον πιμελή, καὶ ἡ πῆξις αὐτῆς, διὰ τὴν τῶν ὑμένων γειτνίασιν· ἐλαίῳ γὰρ ἔοικε παχεῖ, καὶ διὰ τοῦτο πήγνυται, ψυχροῖς καὶ ἀναίμοις ὁμιλοῦσα μορίοις. οὔτε δ’ ἥπατι περιπήγνυσθαι πιμελὴν, οὔτ’ ἀρτηρίαις καὶ φλεψὶν, οὔτε καρδίᾳ δυνατὸν, ἀλλ’ οὐδ’ ἄλλῳ τινὶ θερμῷ πάνυ μορίῳ. διότι δὲ πέπηγε πάνυ ψυχρῷ, διὰ τοῦτο χεῖται θερμαινομένη τοῖς ἄλλοις ὁμοίως πεπηγόσιν. οὐ μὴν ἐγκέφαλός γε θερμαινόμενος χεῖται, καὶ διὰ τοῦτο ἦττον ὑγρός ἐστι πιμελῆς. ἧττον δ’ ὑγρὰ πιμελῆς ἐστι καὶ ἡ τοῦ πνεύμονος σὰρξ, οὐδὲ γὰρ αὕτη χεῖται θερμαινομένη. πολὺ δ’ ἔτι μᾶλλον ἡ τοῦ σπληνός τε καὶ τῶν νεφρῶν ἧττόν ἐστιν ὑγρὰ πιμελῆς. ἅπαντα μέντοι ταῦτα δέρματός ἐστιν ὑγρότερα. τὰς δὲ τούτων ἀποδείξεις ἐν τῷ μεταξὺ λόγῳ διέξειμι· καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ ὅσα λείπει τῇ συμπάσῃ περὶ κράσεων πραγματείᾳ διὰ τῶν ἐφεξῆς δυοῖν ὑπομνημάτων εἰρήσεται.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But the heart falls a little short of the skin in hardness, while the liver falls far short. Accordingly, it is wetter than the skin by just as much as it is softer. And indeed flesh is wetter than skin; but this [flesh] is also hotter. The spinal marrow is wetter, but also colder; and the brain is wetter than this, and still more than that is fat [pimelē] wetter; and its solidification is due
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek passage:

The heart falls a little short of skin in hardness, while the liver falls far short. And indeed it is as much moister than skin as it is softer. Moreover, flesh is moister than skin, but it is also warmer. The spinal cord is moister, but also colder; and the brain is even moister than this, and still more moist than this is fat, and its congealed form, due to its proximity to membranes. For it resembles thick oil, and for this reason it congeals when it associates with cold and bloodless parts. It is not possible for fat to congeal around the liver, nor around arteries and veins, nor around the heart, nor indeed around any other very warm part. Because it congeals in very cold conditions, for this reason it melts when heated, like other congealed substances. The brain, however, does not melt when heated, and for this reason it is less moist than fat. The flesh of the lung is also less moist than fat, for it too does not melt when heated. And still much less moist than fat are the flesh of the spleen and kidneys. Nevertheless, all these are moister than skin. I will set forth the proofs of these matters in the discourse that follows; and indeed whatever remains to be said in the complete treatise concerning temperaments will be addressed in the next two commentaries.

[Note: This appears to be a medical text discussing the relative moisture content and thermal properties of various bodily tissues and organs. The term "temperaments" (κράσεων) refers to the ancient medical theory of bodily humors and their mixtures.]
