paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is my translation of the Greek passage:

"For as far as the contradictions between these men are concerned, nothing can be clearly demonstrated; nor is it at all reasonable to confirm earlier things from later ones. Let us therefore judge hot and cold bodies by sensation - that which is already actually so, and no longer potentially so - setting aside both the primary judgment and all other identifying characteristics. And so I release you to make your own good judgment through experience, while I will explain my own judgment. For having carefully touched many bodies in succession - not only of children and infants, but also of adolescents and those in their prime - I found that neither group spoke the truth, neither those who said simply that a person in their prime was hotter, nor those who said they were colder than a child. For if you remove all other external alterations and examine only the differences arising from age alone, neither appears to you simply hotter than the other. Their degrees of heat differ in quality due to unequal perspiration, through which some people, deceiving either others or themselves, consider either the child's or the young person's warmth to be stronger. For children's warmth is more vaporous, abundant, and more pleasant to the touch, while that of those in their prime has something sharp and unpleasant about it. This difference in impression persuades most people to declare that the body of those in their prime is hotter. But this is not so. For to one who has trained their touch to distinguish stronger, weaker, and equal heat in different materials, I know well that children's heat will appear either equal in strength to that of those in their prime, or greater. The training is as follows - for one must begin with the clearest examples. In baths, sometimes the air is so hot that no one can bear it but seems to burn, while sometimes it is so cold that one cannot sweat. And indeed I need not mention that there is a third condition besides these, which we most desire - the well-tempered one. These same three conditions appear in the water of the swimming pool. For it is often found to be so hot as to burn, so cold as not even to warm up, or well-tempered so as to warm moderately. If therefore I should ask you which is hotter - the well-tempered water or the well-tempered air - you would not be able to say either one."

[Note: εὔκρατος (eukratos) is translated as "well-tempered," referring to a balanced or moderate temperature state]
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
For as far as the disputes of men are concerned, nothing can be clearly demonstrated; nor is it at all reasonable for prior matters to be confirmed by later ones. Let us therefore judge by sensation the hot and the cold body—that which is already so in actuality [kat’ energeian] and no longer in potentiality [dynamei]—setting aside the initial judgment and all other criteria. And so I release you to the experiment, trusting that you will judge well, while I myself will set forth my own judgment.

For, having carefully touched many bodies in succession—

paragraphs.content: ἀμφοῖν γὰρ ὄντων ὁμοίως ἡδέων τε καὶ συμμέτρων τῷ σώματι, τὸ μὲν θερμότερον λέγειν αὐτῶν, τὸ δὲ ψυχρότερον, οὐδένα νοῦν ἔχειν ἡγοῦμαι. καὶ μὴν εἰ νοήσαις τὸ τῆς δεξαμενῆς ὕδωρ εἰς ἄκρον θερμότητος ἀφικνούμενον, ὡς ζεῖν, ἢ τὸν ἀέρα τελέως ἐκφλογούμενον, ὅτι πρὸς ἀμφοῖν ὡσαύτως καυθήσῃ, πρόδηλον. εἰ δὲ δὴ καὶ νοήσαις αὖθις ἢ τὸ ὕδωρ οὕτω ψυχρὸν, ὡς ἐγγὺς ἤδη πήξεως εἶναι, ἢ τὸν ἀέρα τελέως ἐψυγμένον, ὡς ἐν τοῖς νιφετοῖς γίγνεται, δῆλον ὡς καὶ πρὸς τούτων ἑκατέρων ὁμοίως ψυγήσῃ τε καὶ ῥιγώσεις. οὐκοῦν καὶ θερμότητα καὶ ψύξιν ἄκραν ὡσαύτως ἀέρι νοήσεις ἐγγινομένην, ὡσαύτως καὶ ὕδατι, καὶ τῶν ἄκρων ἑκατέρων τὸ μέσον ὁμοίως ἀμφοῖν ἐγγινόμενον· ὥστε καὶ τὸ μεταξὺ πάντων τῶν ἄκρων τε καὶ τοῦ μέσου κατά τε τὸ ὕδωρ καὶ τὸν ἀέρα τὰς αὐτὰς ὑπεροχάς τε καὶ διαστάσεις ἕξει. καὶ τοσούτῳ ποτὲ φήσεις εἶναι τοῦ μετρίου θερμότερον θάτερον, ὅσῳ θάτερον. οὕτω δὲ καὶ ψυχρότερον τοῦ μετρίου τοσούτῳ φήσεις εἶναί ποτε τὸ ὕδωρ, ὅσῳ καὶ τὸν ἀέρα. καίτοι τό γε τῆς προσβολῆς ἴδιον οὐ ταὐτὸ ἑκατέροις ἦν. οὐ γὰρ ὡσαύτως ὕδωρ εὔκρατον, ὡς ἀὴρ εὔκρατος, προσπίπτει. καὶ τί δεῖ λέγειν ἐπὶ τῶν οὕτως ἀνομοίων; αὐτοῦ γὰρ τοῦ ἀέρος ὁμοίως ὄντος θερμοῦ διαφέρουσαι γίγνονται προσβολαὶ παρὰ τὸ ποτὲ μὲν οἷον ἀχλυώδη τε καὶ ἀτμώδη, ποτὲ δὲ οἷον λιγνυώδη τε καὶ καπνώδη, ποτὲ δὲ καθαρὸν ἀκριβῶς ὑπάρχειν. ἐν πολλαῖς οὖν καὶ διαφερούσαις ἰσότης γίνεται θερμότητος, ἐξαπατῶσα τοὺς ἀσκέπτους ὡς ἄνισος, ὅτι γε κατὰ πᾶν ὁμοία φαίνεται. λελογισμένου μήν ἐστιν ἀνδρὸς τοὺς λογισμοὺς, οὓς εἴρηκα, καὶ γεγυμνασμένου τὴν αἴσθησιν ἐν πολλῇ τῇ κατὰ μέρος ἐμπειρίᾳ, τὴν ἰσότητα τῆς θερμότητος ἐξευρεῖν ἔν τε τοῖς παισὶ καὶ τοῖς ἀκμάζουσι, καὶ μὴ τῷ τὴν μὲν ἐφ’ ὑγρᾶς οὐσίας φαίνεσθαι, τὴν δ’ ἐπὶ ξηρᾶς, ἐξαπατᾶσθαι. καὶ γὰρ λίθος ὕδατι δύναταί ποτε τὴν ἴσην δέξασθαι θερμασίαν, οὐδὲν διαφέρον, εἰ ξηρὸς μὲν ὁ λίθος ἐστὶν, ὑγρὸν δὲ τὸ ὕδωρ. οὕτως οὖν ἔμοιγε μυριάκις ἐπισκεψαμένῳ καὶ παῖδας καὶ νεανίσκους πολλοὺς, καὶ μειράκια, καὶ τὸν αὐτὸν παῖδα καὶ βρέφος καὶ μειράκιον γενόμενον, οὐδὲν μᾶλλον ἐφάνη θερμότερος οὔτε παιδὸς ἀκμάζων, οὔτ’ ἀκμάζοντος παῖς. ἀλλ’, ὡς εἴρηται, μόνον ἐν μὲν τοῖς παισὶν ἀτμωδεστέρα τε καὶ πολλὴ καὶ ἡδεῖα, ἐν δὲ τοῖς ἀκμάζουσιν ὀλίγη καὶ ξηρὰ καὶ οὐχ ὁμοίως ἡδεῖα τῆς θερμασίας ἡ προσβολή. πολὺ μὲν γὰρ τῆς τῶν παίδων οὐσίας, ὑγρᾶς οὔσης, ἐκτὸς ἀποῤῥεῖ, βραχὺ δὲ τῆς τῶν ἀκμαζόντων, ξηρᾶς ὑπαρχούσης. οὐδέτερος οὖν αὐτῶν ἁπλῶς φαίνεται θερμότερος, ἀλλ’ ὁ μὲν τῷ πλήθει τῆς διαπνοῆς, ὁ δὲ τῇ δριμύτητι. τὸ γὰρ ἔμφυτον θερμὸν ὁ παῖς ἔχει πλέον, εἴ γ’ ἐξ αἵματος καὶ σπέρματος ἡ γένεσις αὐτῷ, καὶ ἥδιον· ἐν δὲ τοῖς ἀκμάζουσιν ὀλίγη καὶ ξηρὰ καὶ οὐχ ὁμοίως ἡδεῖα τῆς θερμασίας ἡ προσβολή.

paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is my translation of the Greek passage:

"For when both are equally pleasant and proportionate to the body, to say that one is warmer and the other colder, I consider makes no sense. Indeed, if you were to imagine the water in a reservoir reaching extreme heat, as to boil, or the air becoming completely inflamed, it is obvious that you would be burned similarly by both. And if you were to imagine again either water so cold as to be near freezing, or air completely chilled, as happens in snowfalls, it is clear that you would be similarly chilled and shiver from either of these. Therefore, you will understand that both extreme heat and cold occur similarly in air as in water, and the middle point between each extreme occurs similarly in both. Thus, all the gradations between the extremes and the middle point will have the same degrees of excess and intervals in both water and air. And you will say that one is as much warmer than moderate as the other. Similarly, you will say that water is sometimes as much colder than moderate as air is.

Yet the particular quality of their contact [with the body] was not the same for both. For temperate water does not affect us in the same way as temperate air. And what need is there to speak of things so dissimilar? For even with air being similarly warm, different sensations occur depending on whether it is misty and vaporous, or sooty and smoky, or perfectly clear. Thus equality of warmth exists in many different forms, deceiving the unobservant into thinking it unequal, because it does not appear similar throughout.

It is the mark of a man trained in the reasoning I have described, and whose perception is exercised through much particular experience, to discover the equality of warmth in both children and adults, and not to be deceived because one appears in moist substance and the other in dry. For a stone can sometimes receive the same warmth as water, it making no difference that the stone is dry and the water is wet. Thus, in my thousands of examinations of many children, youths, and adolescents, and of the same person as infant, child, and youth, an adult did not appear any warmer than a child, nor a child than an adult. But, as stated, only in children is the sensation of warmth more vaporous, abundant, and pleasant, while in adults it is slight, dry, and not similarly pleasant. For much flows outward from children's substance, being moist, but little from adults', being dry. Therefore, neither appears simply warmer than the other, but one through the abundance of perspiration, the other through sharpness. For a child has more innate heat, if indeed their generation is from blood and seed, and it is more pleasant; while in adults the contact of warmth is slight, dry, and not similarly pleasant."

[Note: This appears to be from Galen's work on temperaments, discussing the nature of heat in different bodies and substances.]

paragraphs.content: Θερμοῦ μὲν δὴ καὶ ψυχροῦ σώματος ἁφὴ μόνη γνώμων ἐστίν· ὑγροῦ δὲ καὶ ξηροῦ σὺν τῇ ἁφῇ λογισμός. τὸ μὲν γὰρ ξηρὸν σκληρὸν πάντως· ἀλλὰ τοῦτο μὲν ἁφῇ αἰσθητόν· οὐ μὴν, εἴ τι καὶ σκληρὸν, εὐθὺς ἤδη καὶ ξηρόν. ἀχώριστον μὲν γάρ ἐστι ξηροῦ σώματος ἡ σκληρότης, οὐ μὴν ἴδιόν γε τούτου μόνου. καὶ γὰρ τὸ πεπηγὸς ὑπὸ ψύξεως σκληρὸν, ὥσπερ ὁ κρύσταλλος. ὅθεν οὐδ’ εὐθὺς ἐπιχειρεῖν δεῖ τῇ τοῦ ξηροῦ τε καὶ ὑγροῦ διαγνώσει, πρὶν ἐπισκέψασθαι, πῶς ἔχει θερμότητος ἢ ψυχρότητος. οὔτε γὰρ, εἰ μετὰ ψυχρότητος ἄκρας σκληρὸν, ἤδη τοῦτο ξηρὸν, οὔτ’, εἰ μετὰ θερμότητος σφοδρᾶς μαλακὸν, εὐθέως ὑγρόν.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Touch alone is the criterion [gnōmōn] for a body’s heat and cold; but for the moist and the dry, reasoning together with touch is required. For the dry is in every case hard—and this is perceptible by touch—but it does not follow that, if something is hard, it is straightway also dry. For hardness is inseparable from a dry body, yet it is not peculiar to this alone; what has been congealed by cold is hard as well, like crystal. Hence one should not immediately attempt the discrimination [diagnōsis] of the dry and the moist before examining how it stands with respect to heat or cold. For neither, if it is hard together with extreme cold, is it thereby dry, nor, if it is soft together with intense heat, is it straightway moist.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

Touch alone is the judge of a hot and cold body; but for wet and dry, reasoning accompanies touch. For what is dry is certainly hard; this indeed is perceptible by touch; however, not everything that is hard is necessarily dry. For while hardness is inseparable from a dry body, it is not unique to it alone. For that which has been frozen by cold is also hard, like ice. Hence one should not immediately proceed to the diagnosis of dry and wet, before examining how it stands regarding heat or cold. For neither if something is hard with extreme cold is it necessarily dry, nor if something is soft with intense heat is it immediately wet.

[Note: "γνώμων" (judge/criterion) and "διάγνωσις" (diagnosis/distinction) are technical terms in ancient medical and philosophical texts]

The translation preserves the logical structure of the argument about the relationship between sensory perception (particularly touch) and the determination of basic qualities (hot/cold, wet/dry), which appears to be from a medical or natural philosophical text.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: Of a hot and cold body, touch alone is the criterion [γνώμων]; but of a wet and dry one, it is reasoning along with touch. For the dry is in every case hard; but while this is perceptible by touch, nevertheless, if something is hard, it is not thereby immediately dry. For hardness is inseparable from a dry body, but it is certainly not a property peculiar [ἴδιον] to it alone. For that which has been solidified by cold is also hard, like ice [κρύσταλλος]. Therefore, one must not attempt to diagnose the dry and the wet straightaway, before first considering its state with respect to heat or coldness. For if something is hard in conjunction with extreme cold, it is not on that account dry; nor, if it is soft in conjunction with intense heat, is it immediately wet.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ὅταν μετρίως ᾖ θερμὸν, σκοπεῖν ἐφεξῆς, εἰ μαλακόν ἐστιν ἢ σκληρόν. εἰ μὲν γὰρ μαλακὸν, ὑγρὸν, εἰ δὲ σκληρὸν, ξηρόν. ἀλλ’ εἴπερ ταῦθ’ οὕτως ἔχοι, τῶν ἐν ἀνθρώπου σώματι μορίων σκληρῶν οὐδὲν ἂν εἴη ὑγρόν. οὐ γὰρ ἐγχωρεῖ τοσαύτην ἐν αὐτῷ γενέσθαι ψύξιν, ὡς σκληρυνθῆναί τι διὰ πῆξιν. εἰς μὲν γὰρ σύστασίν τινα τὸ τέως ῥυτὸν ἀφίξεταί ποτε, καθάπερ ἡ πιμελή. τὸ γὰρ ἐλαιῶδες ἐν αἵματι, ῥυτὸν ὂν καὶ λιπαρὸν, ὅταν ἐν ψυχρῷ γένηται χωρίῳ, πήγνυται, σκληρὸν μὴν οὐδ’ οὕτω γίγνεται. δεόντως οὖν εἴρηται τοῖς παλαιοῖς, ὑγροτάτη μὲν ἡ πιμελὴ, δεύτερον δ’ ἐπ’ αὐτῇ τὸ σαρκῶδες γένος, εἴδη δ’ αὐτοῦ πλείω. πρώτη μὲν ἡ κυρίως ὀνομαζομένη σὰρξ, ἣν οὐκ ἂν εὕροις καθ’ αὑτὴν οὐδαμόθι τοῦ σώματος, ἀλλ’ ἔστιν ἀεὶ μόριον μυός. ἐφεξῆς δὲ ἑκάστου τῶν σπλάγχνων ἡ ἴδιος οὐσία. καλοῦσι δ’ αὐτὴν οἱ περὶ τὸν Ἐρασίστρατον παρέγχυμα, καὶ ὡς περὶ μικροῦ καὶ φαύλου διανοοῦνται πράγματος, οὐκ εἰδότες, ὡς ἡ καθ’ ἕκαστον σπλάγχνον ἐνέργεια τῆς σαρκὸς ταύτης ἐστίν.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But whenever it is moderately warm, one should next examine whether it is soft or hard. For if it is soft, it is moist; if hard, dry. Yet if things stood in this way, none of the hard parts in a human body would be moist. For so great a cooling cannot occur in it that something should be hardened through congealment. What was previously fluid will indeed at some point reach a certain consistency, as fat [pimelē: bodily fat] does. For the oily element in the blood, being fluid and unctuous, when it comes into a cold place, congeals; yet even so it does not become hard. Rightly, then, did the ancients say that fat is the moistest, and next after it comes the fleshy kind [sarkōdes], which has several species. First is what is strictly called “flesh” [sarx], which you would not find anywhere in the body by itself, but is always a part of muscle [mys]. Next is the peculiar substance of each of the viscera [splanchna]. Those around Erasistratus call this the “parenchyma” [parenchyma], and they think it a small and trivial matter, not realizing that the specific activity of each organ resides in this very flesh.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

But when it is moderately warm, examine next whether it is soft or hard. For if it is soft, it is moist, and if hard, dry. However, if these things were so, none of the hard parts in the human body would be moist. For it is not possible for such cooling to occur within it that something would become hardened through congealing. For what was previously fluid will sometimes arrive at a certain consistency, just like fat. For the oily element in blood, being fluid and greasy, when it comes to be in a cold place, congeals, yet even so does not become hard. Therefore, it was rightly said by the ancients that fat is the most moist, and second after it is the fleshy kind, of which there are several types. First is what is properly called flesh, which you would not find anywhere in the body by itself, but is always part of a muscle. Next is the particular substance of each of the viscera [internal organs]. The followers of Erasistratus call this parenchyma [tissue substance], and they think of it as something small and insignificant, not knowing that the function of each organ depends on this flesh.

[Note: "parenchyma" (παρέγχυμα) is a technical medical term referring to the functional tissue of organs]
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
But when it is moderately warm, one must examine next whether it is soft or hard. For if it is soft, it is moist; but if hard, it is dry. Yet if this were so, none of the hard parts in the human body would be moist. For it is not possible for such great cooling to occur in it that something becomes hard through congealing. For what was previously fluid will at some point arrive at a certain consistency, just like fat. The oily element in the blood, being fluid and greasy, congeals whenever it is in a cold place, but even so it does not become hard.

Appropriately, therefore, it has been said by the ancients that fat is the most moist, and second to it is the fleshy type of substance, and of this there are several forms. First is that which is properly called flesh [Greek: σάρξ, *sarx*], which you would not find by itself anywhere in the body, but is always a part of a muscle. Next is the proper substance of each of the internal organs. The followers of Erasistratus call this parenchyma [Greek: παρέγχυμα], and they think of it as a small and trivial matter, not knowing that the function [Greek: ἐνέργεια, *energeia*] of each internal organ belongs to this very flesh.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ τούτων μὲν οὔπω νῦν ὁ καιρός. ὅτι δ’ αὐτὸ τὸ ἴδιον ἐγκεφάλου σῶμα καὶ πνεύμονος ἐφεξῆς ἐστι τῇ πιμελῇ καθ’ ὑγρότητα, τῇ μαλακότητι τεκμαίρεσθαι πάρεστιν. οὐ γὰρ δὴ ὑπὸ ψυχροῦ γε πέπηγεν, ὅτι μηδὲ θερμῷ χεῖται. πλησίον δὲ τούτων καὶ ὁ μυελὸς τὴν φύσιν ἐστὶν, οὐ μὴν ὁμοιογενὴς ὁ καθ’ ἕκαστον ὀστοῦν μυελὸς ἐγκεφάλῳ τε καὶ νωτιαίῳ. ἀλλ’ ἐγκέφαλος μὲν καὶ νωτιαῖος ἐκ ταὐτοῦ γένους· οἱ δ’ ἄλλοι ξύμπαντες μυελοὶ φύσεως ἑτέρας εἰσίν.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But as for those matters, now is not yet the time. That the very substance proper to the brain—and next in order the lung—stands close to fat [pimelē: suet/fat] in respect of moisture and softness can be inferred. For it has certainly not been congealed by cold, since neither is it liquefied by heat. And marrow too is near these in its nature, yet the marrow in each individual bone is not of the same kind as the brain and the spinal [marrow/cord]. Rather, the brain and the spinal [marrow/cord] are of the same genus, while all the other marrows are of a different nature.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation:

But now is not yet the time for these matters. That the distinctive substance itself of the brain and lung comes next after fat in terms of moisture can be determined by its softness. For indeed it is not congealed by cold, just as it is not melted by heat. And close to these in nature is marrow, although the marrow in each bone is not of the same kind as the brain and spinal cord [literally: spinal marrow]. Rather, the brain and spinal cord are of the same kind, while all other forms of marrow are of a different nature.

[Note: "νωτιαῖος" specifically refers to the spinal cord, though literally translated as "spinal marrow" in ancient medical terminology]

This appears to be from a medical text discussing the physical properties and classifications of various soft tissues in the body, particularly comparing the brain, spinal cord, and different types of marrow.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: But this is not yet the opportune moment for these matters. That the actual substance of the brain and, next, of the lung is akin to soft fat [pimele] in its moistness, one may infer from its softness. For it has certainly not been congealed by cold, since it is not even melted by heat. And the marrow is also close to these in nature, yet the marrow in each bone is not of the same kind as the brain and the spinal marrow [notiaios]. Rather, the brain and the spinal marrow are of the same kind; but all the other marrows are of a different nature.

paragraphs.content: ὑγρότερος μέν ἐστι καὶ θερμότερος ἐγκέφαλος νωτιαίου, καὶ διὰ τοῦτο καὶ μαλακώτερος· καὶ μέντοι καὶ αὐτοῦ τοῦ ἐγκεφάλου τὰ πρόσθεν ὑγρότερα τοσοῦτον, ὅσονπερ καὶ μαλακώτερα. πάντα μὴν ταῦτα δέρματος οὐχ ὑγρότερα μόνον, ἀλλὰ καὶ ψυχρότερα, καὶ ὅλως ἄναιμον πᾶν ἐναίμου ψυχρότερον. ἐγγυτάτω δ’ ἐστὶ δέρματος καὶ ἡ τῶν μαλακῶν νεύρων φύσις· ἡ δὲ τῶν σκληρῶν, οἷόν περ αὐτὸ τὸ δέρμα, καθ’ ὑγρότητα δηλονότι καὶ ξηρότητα. θερμότητι γὰρ ἀπολείπεται τοσοῦτον, ὅσον εἰκὸς ἀπολείπεσθαι τὸ παντελῶς ἄναιμον ἐναίμου σώματος. ἡ δὲ τοῦ σπληνὸς, καὶ ἡ τῶν νεφρῶν, καὶ ἡ τοῦ ἥπατος σὰρξ ὑγροτέρα μὲν τοσούτῳ δέρματος, ὅσῳ καὶ μαλακωτέρα· θερμοτέρα δὲ, ὅσῳ καὶ πολυαιμοτέρα. καὶ μὴν καὶ ἡ τῆς καρδίας σὰρξ ἁπάντων μὲν τούτων ξηροτέρα τοσοῦτον, ὅσον καὶ σκληροτέρα· θερμοτέρα δὲ οὐ τούτων μόνον, ἀλλὰ καὶ πάντων ἁπλῶς τῶν τοῦ σώματος μορίων. καί σοι τοῦτο σαφῶς ἔνεστιν αἰσθήσει μαθεῖν ἐν ταῖς τῶν ζώων ἀνατομαῖς ταῖς κατὰ τὸ στέρνον γιγνομέναις, εἰς τὴν ἀριστερὰν κοιλίαν τῆς καρδίας καθέντι τοὺς δακτύλους· εὑρήσεις γὰρ οὐκ ὀλίγῳ τινὶ τὸ χωρίον τοῦτο τῶν ἄλλων ἁπάντων θερμότερον. ἀλλ’ ἡ μὲν τοῦ ἥπατός τε καὶ σπληνὸς καὶ νεφρῶν καὶ πνεύμονος σὰρξ ἁπλῆ τὴν φύσιν ἐστὶ, ταῖς καθ’ ἕκαστον σπλάγχνον ἀρτηρίαις καὶ φλεψὶ καὶ νεύροις περιπεφυκυῖα. τῆς καρδίας δ’ οὐχ ἁπλοῦν τὸ τῆς σαρκὸς εἶδος, ἀλλ’ οἷαί πέρ εἰσιν αἱ ἐν τοῖς μυσὶν ἶνες, αἷς ἡ σὰρξ περιπέπηγε, τοιαῦται κᾀν τῇ καρδίᾳ. πλὴν οὐ ταὐτὸ γένος τῶν ἰνῶν, ἀλλ’ αἱ μὲν ἐν τοῖς μυσὶν νεύρων εἰσὶ καὶ συνδέσμων μόρια. τῆς καρδίας δὲ τὸ τῶν ἰνῶν γένος ἴδιον, ὥσπερ καὶ τοῦ τῆς ἀρτηρίας καὶ φλεβὸς χιτῶνος, ἐντέρων τε καὶ γαστρὸς καὶ μήτρας καὶ τῶν κύστεων ἑκατέρων. ἔστι γὰρ οὖν δὴ κᾀν τούτοις ἅπασι τοῖς ὀργάνοις τὴν οἰκείαν σάρκα περιπεπηγυῖαν ἰδεῖν ταῖς ἰδίαις αὐτῶν ἰσίν. αὗται μὲν οὖν αἱ σάρκες θερμότεραι τοῦ δέρματος ὑπάρχουσιν, αἱ δ’ ἶνες, αἱ μὲν ὀλίγῳ τινὶ μᾶλλον, αἱ δ’ ἧττον, βραχὺ δέρματος ψυχρότεραί τέ εἰσι καὶ ξηρότεραι, τινὲς δ’ ὅμοιαι κατὰ πᾶν εἰσι τῇ τοῦ δέρματος οὐσίᾳ. πάντες δ’ ὑμένες ἤδη ξηρότεροι δέρματος, ὥσπερ γε καὶ αἱ περὶ τὸν ἐγκέφαλόν τε καὶ τὸν νωτιαῖον μήνιγγες· ὑμένες γὰρ δὴ καὶ αἵδε. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ σύνδεσμοι πάντες, εἰς ὅσον σκληρότεροι δέρματος, εἰς τοσοῦτο καὶ ξηρότεροι. καὶ οἱ τένοντες δὲ, κᾂν τῶν συνδέσμων εἰσὶ μαλακώτεροι, δέρματος γοῦν ἐναργῶς ἤδη σκληρότεροι. χόνδροι δὲ μετὰ τοὺς συνδέσμους εἰσί. καί τι μέσον ἀμφοῖν σῶμα· καλοῦσι δ’ αὐτὸ νευροχονδρώδη σύνδεσμον ἔνιοι τῶν ἀνατομικῶν. ἔστι δὲ τοῦτο σύνδεσμος σκληρὸς καὶ χονδρώδης.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
The brain is moister and warmer than the spinal marrow, and for this reason softer as well; and, in fact, the front parts of the brain itself are so much moister as they are softer. Yet all these are not only moister than the skin, but also colder; and in general, everything that is bloodless is colder than what has blood. Closest to the skin is the nature of the soft “nerves” [i.e., the true nerves]; the nature of the hard ones—just like the skin itself—is the same as regards moisture and dryness. In warmth, however, it falls short by so much as it is reasonable that something entirely bloodless should fall short of a body that has blood.

The flesh of the spleen, kidneys, and liver is moister than the skin by as much as it is softer, and warmer by as much as it is richer in blood. And the flesh of the heart, while drier than all of these by as much as it is harder, is warmer not only than these, but, quite simply, than all the parts of the body. You can clearly learn this by sense-perception in animal dissections performed through the sternum, if you insert your fingers into the left ventricle of the heart; you will find that this region is by no small amount warmer than all the others.

But the flesh of the liver, spleen, kidneys, and lung is by nature simple, having arteries, veins, and “nerves” [here: tendons/ligaments/nervous elements] grown around it in each organ. The heart’s flesh, however, is not of a simple sort; rather, just as there are fibers in the muscles into which the flesh is set, such fibers are present in the heart as well—only not of the same kind. Those in the muscles are parts of “nerves” and ligaments [i.e., tendinous/ligamentous fibers], whereas the kind of fibers in the heart is peculiar to it, just as is the tunic [outer coat] of the artery and the vein, and likewise those of the intestines, the stomach, the womb, and both bladders [urinary and gallbladder]. In all these organs, then, one can see their own proper flesh set around by their own proper fibers.

These fleshes are warmer than the skin, while the fibers—some a little more, some less—are slightly colder and drier than the skin, and some are in every respect like the substance of the skin. All membranes are already drier than the skin, as indeed are the meninges around the brain and spinal marrow [meninges = protective membranes]; for these too are membranes. And all ligaments, in proportion as they are harder than the skin, are so much drier as well. The tendons, although they are softer than ligaments, are in any case plainly harder than the skin. After the ligaments come the cartilages. There is also a body intermediate between the two, which some anatomists call the “neurochondrous” ligament. This is a ligament that is hard and cartilaginous.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Ancient Greek paragraph:

The brain is moister and warmer than the spinal cord, and for this reason also softer; moreover, the front parts of the brain itself are as much moister as they are softer. All these parts are not only moister than skin, but also colder, and in general all bloodless tissue is colder than tissue with blood. The nature of soft nerves is very close to that of skin; but that of hard nerves is like the skin itself, clearly in terms of moisture and dryness. For it falls short in warmth by as much as one would expect completely bloodless tissue to fall short of tissue with blood. The flesh of the spleen, kidneys, and liver is as much moister than skin as it is softer; and warmer to the degree that it has more blood. Indeed, the flesh of the heart is as much drier than all these as it is harder; and warmer not only than these, but simply than all parts of the body. And you can clearly learn this by sensation in dissections of animals performed at the chest, by placing your fingers in the left cavity of the heart; for you will find this region not a little warmer than all others. But while the flesh of the liver, spleen, kidneys, and lungs is simple in nature, growing around the arteries, veins, and nerves in each organ, the form of the heart's flesh is not simple, but just as there are fibers in the muscles to which the flesh is fixed, so too in the heart. However, it is not the same kind of fibers, for those in muscles are parts of nerves and ligaments. The heart's type of fibers is unique, just like that of the coat of arteries and veins, intestines, stomach, womb, and both bladders [urinary and gall]. For indeed in all these organs one can see their proper flesh fixed to their own particular fibers. These flesh types are warmer than skin, while the fibers - some slightly more, others less - are a little colder and drier than skin, and some are similar in every way to the substance of skin. All membranes are already drier than skin, just as are the meninges around the brain and spinal cord; for these too are membranes. And indeed all ligaments are as much drier as they are harder than skin. And tendons, even though they are softer than ligaments, are clearly already harder than skin. Cartilages come after ligaments. And there is a substance between both; some anatomists call it neurocartilaginous ligament [fibrocartilage]. This is a hard and cartilaginous ligament.

[Note: This appears to be a medical text, likely from Galen, discussing the relative moisture, warmth, and texture of various bodily tissues.]
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ὀστοῦν δὲ τὸ πάντων ξηρότατον, ὃ καλύπτει τὸ δέρμα. καὶ τῶν ἐξεχόντων αὐτοῦ ξηροτάτη μὲν ἡ θρὶξ, ἐφεξῆς δὲ κέρας, εἶτ’ ὄνυχές τε καὶ ὁπλαὶ, καὶ πλῆκτρα, καὶ ῥάμφη, καὶ ὅσα τοιαῦτα καθ’ ἕκαστον τῶν ἀλόγων ζώων ἐστὶ μόρια. τῶν δὲ χυμῶν ὁ μὲν χρηστότατός τε καὶ οἰκειότατός ἐστι τὸ αἷμα. τούτου δὲ οἷον ὑπόστασίς τε καὶ ἰλὺς χολὴ ἡ μέλαινα. ταῦτ’ ἄρα καὶ ψυχροτέρα τέ ἐστι καὶ παχυτέρα τοῦ αἵματος· ἡ δέ γε ξανθὴ θερμοτέρα μακρῷ. ψυχρότατον δὲ καὶ ὑγρότατον ἁπάντων τῶν ἐν τῷ ζώῳ τὸ φλέγμα. κριτήριον δὲ καὶ τῆς τούτου διαγνώσεως ἡ ἁφὴ, καθάπερ καὶ Ἱπποκράτης ἐν τῷ περὶ φύσεως ἀνθρώπου πεποίηται λόγῳ. ἀλλ’ ὅτι μὲν ψυχρὸν, ἡ ἁφὴ μόνη γιγνώσκει· τὸ δ’, ὅτι καὶ ὑγρὸν, ἁφή τε ἅμα καὶ ὄψις καὶ λογισμός.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Bone is the driest of all, which the skin covers. And among the things that project from it, the driest is hair, next horn, then nails and hooves, and spurs, and beaks, and all such parts as belong to each of the non-rational animals. Of the humors [bodily fluids], the best and most proper to the organism is blood. Of this, the deposit and sediment is black bile; this, accordingly, is both colder and thicker than blood, whereas yellow bile is much hotter by far. Coldest and wettest of all things in the animal is phlegm. The criterion for identifying this is touch—just as Hippocrates has done in his treatise On the Nature of Man. But that it is cold is recognized by touch alone; that it is also wet is recognized by touch together with sight and reasoning.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

The bone is the driest of all things, which the skin covers. And of its protruding parts, the hair is the driest, followed by horn, then nails and hooves, and spurs, and beaks, and whatever such parts exist in each of the irrational animals. Among the humors, the most useful and most proper is the blood. Of this, black bile is like a sediment and mud. Therefore, it is both colder and thicker than blood; while the yellow [bile] is far hotter. The coldest and wettest of all things in the living creature is phlegm. The criterion for diagnosing this is touch, just as Hippocrates has explained in his treatise "On the Nature of Man." However, while touch alone recognizes that it is cold, the fact that it is also wet is known through touch together with sight and reasoning.

[Notes:
- "humors" (χυμῶν) refers to the four bodily fluids in ancient medical theory
- "black bile" (χολὴ ἡ μέλαινα) and "yellow bile" (ξανθὴ) are technical medical terms
- "On the Nature of Man" (περὶ φύσεως ἀνθρώπου) is a Hippocratic treatise]
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ἁφὴ μὲν καὶ ὄψις, ὅτι τοιοῦτο ἑκατέρῳ φαίνεται· ὁ λογισμὸς δὲ, διορισάμενος, ὡς οὐ πλήθει θερμότητος, ἀλλ’ ὑγρότητι συμφύτῳ τοιοῦτο ἐγένετο. περὶ μὲν οὖν τῶν κατὰ τὸ σῶμα μορίων τε καὶ χυμῶν ᾧδε ἔχει.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Touch and sight [the senses] report that it is such as it appears to each; but reasoning, having made the distinction, [concludes] that it became such not through an abundance of heat, but through connate moisture [inborn/inherent humidity]. Thus, as regards the bodily parts and humors, the case stands as follows.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek passage:

"Touch and sight each show that it appears this way; but reason, making a distinction, [shows] that it became this way not due to an abundance of heat, but due to innate moisture. This, then, is how matters stand concerning the parts of the body and its humors."

[Notes: 
- "ἁφὴ" (touch) and "ὄψις" (sight) are technical terms in Greek medical and philosophical writing referring to sensory perception
- "χυμῶν" (humors) refers to the bodily fluids in ancient medical theory
- "συμφύτῳ" (innate/natural) literally means "grown together with" and is a technical term in medical contexts]

The translation preserves the original's logical structure, moving from sensory evidence to rational analysis, and concluding with a summary statement about bodily conditions.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: Touch and sight [report] that it appears to be of such a kind to each; but reason, having made a distinction, [concludes] that it became so not by an abundance of heat, but by an innate moisture. This, then, is the situation concerning the parts and the humors [Greek: *chymoi*] of the body.

paragraphs.content: Περὶ δὲ τῶν ἑπομένων ταῖς κράσεσιν ἐφεξῆς χρὴ διελθεῖν. ἕπεται μὲν γὰρ καὶ τὰ προειρημένα, μᾶλλον δ’ ἀχώριστα τελέως ἐστὶ, ξηρῷ μὲν σκληρότης, ὑγρῷ δὲ μαλακότης, ὅταν γε μετὰ χλιαρᾶς ᾖ θερμότητος. ἀλλὰ καὶ παχύτητες ἕξεως καὶ λεπτότητες ἕπονται κράσεσιν, οὐ ταῖς συμφύτοις μόνον, ἀλλὰ κᾂν ἐξ ἔθους μακροῦ τις ἐπίκτητος γένηται. πολλοὺς γὰρ καὶ τῶν φύσει λεπτῶν ἐθεασάμην παχυνθέντας, καὶ τῶν παχέων λεπτυνθέντας, τοὺς μὲν ἀργίᾳ τε καὶ ἁβρᾷ διαίτῃ τὴν ὅλην κρᾶσιν ὑπαλλάξαντας ἐπὶ τὸ ὑγρότερον, τοὺς δὲ ἐν ταλαιπωρίαις πλείοσι καὶ φροντίσι καὶ διαίτῃ λεπτῇ καταξηρανθέντας. εἰρήσεται δὲ καὶ τούτων τὰ γνωρίσματα. κάλλιον γὰρ ἡμᾶς αὐτοὺς ἔκ τινων σημείων ὁρμωμένους, πρὶν παρ’ ἑτέρου πυθέσθαι, δύνασθαι γνωρίζειν, εἰ φύσει τοιοῦτος ἦν ὁ ἄνθρωπος, ἢ ἐξ ἔθους ἐγένετο. διδάσκαλος δὲ καὶ τούτων τῶν γνωρισμάτων, ὥσπερ οὖν καὶ τῶν ἄλλων ἁπάντων, ὁ θαυμάσιος Ἱπποκράτης.
paragraphs.openai_translation: As for the things that follow upon the mixtures [krasis: bodily temperament], we must take them up in order. For what was said before also follows—indeed, it is rather completely inseparable—namely, that hardness attends on dryness, and softness on moisture, whenever, at any rate, it is accompanied by a tepid warmth. Moreover, stoutness of habit [hexis: bodily condition] and leanness follow upon mixtures, not only those that are inborn, but even when someone becomes thus by long-established habit. For I have seen many who were naturally lean become stout, and many of the stout become lean—the former, through idleness and a delicate regimen [diaita: mode of living], having altered their whole mixture toward the moister; the latter, through many hardships and cares and a spare regimen, having been dried out. The diagnostic marks [gnōrismata] of these, too, will be set forth. For it is better that we ourselves, starting from certain signs, be able to recognize—before asking another—whether a person was such by nature or became so through habit. And the teacher of these marks, as indeed of all the others, is the admirable Hippocrates.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

Concerning the characteristics that follow from the mixtures [temperaments/κράσεις], we must proceed to discuss these next. For while the previously mentioned characteristics follow, or rather are completely inseparable - hardness follows dryness, and softness follows moisture, at least when accompanied by mild warmth - both thickness and thinness of constitution also follow from mixtures, not only from those present from birth, but also when acquired through long habit. For I have observed many naturally thin people becoming thick, and thick people becoming thin - some altering their entire mixture toward the more moist through inactivity and luxurious living, others becoming dried out through excessive hardships, anxieties, and a sparse diet. The identifying marks of these conditions will also be discussed. For it is better that we ourselves, proceeding from certain signs, should be able to recognize whether a person was naturally such or became so through habit, before learning this from another. And the teacher of these identifying marks, just as indeed of all others, is the admirable Hippocrates.

[Notes: 
- κράσεις refers to the medical theory of bodily "mixtures" or "temperaments"
- The text appears to be from a medical treatise discussing physical constitutions and their changes]
paragraphs.gemini_translation: Next, it is necessary to discuss in order the things that follow from the temperaments [kraseis, lit. 'mixtures'; the specific balance of the four humors determining a person's constitution]. For the qualities previously mentioned also follow from them—or rather, they are completely inseparable: hardness from the dry and softness from the moist, at least when this is accompanied by a mild heat. But thickness and thinness of bodily condition [hexis, a stable state or disposition, often physical] also follow from the temperaments—not only from the congenital ones, but also from any acquired temperament that may arise from long-standing habit. For I have observed many who are by nature thin become fat, and many who are fat become thin: the former having altered their entire temperament toward the moister through idleness and a luxurious regimen, the latter having been dried out by many hardships, cares, and a meager diet. The diagnostic signs of these conditions will also be discussed. For it is better that we ourselves, proceeding

paragraphs.content: ὅσοι μὲν γὰρ εὐρυτέρας ἔχουσι τὰς φλέβας, θερμότεροι φύσει· ὅσοι δὲ στενοτέρας, ψυχρότεροι. τοῦ θερμοῦ γὰρ ἔργον ἀνευρῦναί τε καὶ διαφυσῆσαι ταύτας. ὥστ’ εὐλόγως εἰς ταὐτὸ.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For all who have wider veins are by nature hotter, while those with narrower [veins] are colder. For it is the function of heat to widen and distend these [i.e., to dilate/expand the veins]. Hence it is reasonable that the two should go together.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

"For those who have wider blood vessels are naturally warmer, while those who have narrower ones are colder. For it is the function of heat to widen and inflate these [vessels]. Thus, reasonably, these things come to the same point."

[Notes: 
- φλέβας (phlebas) specifically refers to "blood vessels" or "veins"
- The term θερμοῦ (thermou) refers to bodily heat or warmth in a medical context
- The final phrase εἰς ταὐτὸ (eis tauto) literally means "to the same thing/point"]

This appears to be from a medical text discussing the relationship between blood vessel size, body temperature, and the nature of heat.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: For those who have wider vessels [φλέβας] are hotter by nature, while those who have narrower ones are colder. For it is the function of heat both to dilate and to distend these [vessels]. Therefore, it logically amounts to the same thing.

paragraphs.content: ὡς τὸ πολὺ, συντρέχει στενότης μὲν φλεβῶν ἕξει πιμελώδει τε καὶ παχυτέρᾳ, λεπτότης δ’ ἕξεως εὐρύτητι φλεβῶν. εἰ δ’ ἅμα τις εἴη πιμελώδης τε καὶ παχὺς, καὶ τὰς φλέβας εὐρείας ἔχοι, δι’ ἔθος οὗτος, οὐ φύσει, πιμελώδης ἐγένετο· ὥσπερ εἰ καὶ στενὰς μὲν ἔχοι τὰς φλέβας, εἴη δὲ ἰσχνὸς, οὐδ’ οὗτος ἐξ ἀνάγκης φύσει τοιοῦτος. κᾀν τοῖσι λιμαγχονικοῖσι, φησὶ, τὰς μετριότητας ἀπὸ τούτων σκεπτέον, τῆς τῶν ἀγγείων εὐρύτητος δηλονότι καὶ στενότητος, οὐ τῆς ἄλλης ἕξεως ὅλου τοῦ σώματος. οἱ μὲν γὰρ στενὰς ἔχοντες τὰς φλέβας ὀλίγαιμοί τέ εἰσι καὶ μακρὰς ἀσιτίας οὐ φέρουσιν ὅσοις δ’ εὐρεῖαι, καὶ πλῆθος αἵματος, τούτοις ἔνεστι καὶ χωρὶς βλάβης ἀσιτοῦσιν. αἱ δ’ αἰτίαι τῶν εἰρημένων ἤδη μὲν δῆλαι, κᾂν ἐγὼ μὴ λέγω, τοῖς γε προσέχουσι τὸν νοῦν. ἐπεὶ δ’ οὐ πάντες προσέχουσιν, ἀναγκαῖον ἴσως ἐστί τι καὶ δι’ ἐκείνους εἰπεῖν. ὅσον ἐν αἵματι πῖόν τέ ἐστι καὶ κοῦφον καὶ λεπτὸν, ἐν μὲν τοῖς θερμοτέροις σώμασι τροφὴ γίνεται τοῦτο τῷ θερμῷ, κατὰ δὲ τὰ ψυχρότερα διασώζεται. καὶ τῶν φλεβῶν ἔξω διηθούμενον, ἐπειδὰν μὲν ψυχροῖς περιπέσῃ μορίοις, οἷοί περ οἱ ὑμένες εἰσὶν, ἐκείνοις περιπήγνυται· κατὰ δὲ τὰ φύσει θερμότερα μόρια, (τοιαῦτα δ’ ἐστὶ δηλονότι τὰ σαρκώδη,) δαπανᾶταί τε πρὸς τοῦ θερμοῦ, καὶ διαφορεῖται, πλὴν εἴ ποτε πρὸς τῷ ψυχροτέρῳ τῆς κράσεως ἔτι καὶ τὸ τῆς διαίτης ἀταλαίπωρον ἐπιθρέψει ἔτι καὶ αὐτοῖς τοῖς σαρκώδεσι μορίοις πιμελήν. οὕτω τοι καὶ τὰ φωλεύοντα ζῶα πολλάκις εὑρίσκεται πιμελωδέστερα. καὶ γυναῖκες ἀνδρῶν, ὅτι καὶ τῇ κράσει ψυχρότερον ἄῤῥενος τὸ θῆλυ, καὶ οἰκουρεῖ τὰ πολλά.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For the most part, narrowness of the veins goes along with a fatty and thicker habit [hexis], while thinness of habit goes with breadth of the veins. And if someone should be both fatty and stout and also have wide veins, such a person has become fatty through custom, not by nature; likewise, if he should have narrow veins and be lean, he too is not of necessity such by nature. And, he says, in those prone to hunger-attacks [λιμαγχονικοί: liable to hunger-fainting], one must judge the proper measures from these factors—plainly the width and narrowness of the vessels, not from the other habit of the whole body. For those who have narrow veins are poor in blood [oligaemic] and do not endure long fasts, whereas those with wide veins, having an abundance of blood, can also go without food without harm. The causes of the aforesaid are already clear—even if I do not state them—to those who pay attention; but since not everyone does, it is perhaps necessary to say something for their sake as well. Whatever in the blood is rich, light, and fine, in hotter bodies this becomes nourishment for the heat, while in colder bodies it is preserved. And when filtered outside the veins, whenever it encounters colder parts, such as the membranes [hymenes], it congeals upon them; but in parts naturally hotter—clearly the fleshy parts—it is spent by the heat and carried off, unless it should happen that, in addition to a colder mixture [krasis], the untroubled ease of regimen [i.e., lack of exertion] fosters fat even in the fleshy parts themselves. Thus too, animals that lie in dens are often found to be fatter; and women more than men, because the female is, in its mixture, colder than the male, and for the most part stays indoors.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

For the most part, narrowness of veins coincides with a fatty and thicker constitution, while thinness of constitution coincides with wideness of veins. If someone is both fat and thick, yet has wide veins, this person has become fat through habit, not by nature; just as if someone has narrow veins but is lean, this person is not necessarily so by nature. And in cases of fasting [limagchonikos], he says, one must examine the moderate conditions from these factors - namely the wideness and narrowness of vessels, not the other aspects of the whole body's constitution. For those who have narrow veins are both low in blood and cannot endure long periods without food; while those with wide veins have an abundance of blood, and can fast without harm.

The causes of what has been said are already clear, even if I do not explain them, to those who apply their minds. But since not everyone does apply their mind, it is perhaps necessary to say something for their sake. Whatever in blood is fatty, light, and thin becomes nourishment for heat in warmer bodies, while in colder bodies it is preserved. When it filters outside the veins, when it encounters cold parts, such as membranes, it congeals around them; but in naturally warmer parts (which are clearly the fleshy parts), it is consumed by heat and dispersed, except when, in addition to a colder temperament, an inactive lifestyle contributes to the development of fat even in the fleshy parts themselves. Thus indeed, hibernating animals are often found to be fatter. And women more than men, because the female is colder in temperament than the male, and spends much time indoors.

[Note: "limagchonikos" refers to therapeutic fasting or dietary restriction in medical contexts]
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
For the most part, narrowness of the veins corresponds to a fatty and thick constitution [hexis], while thinness of constitution corresponds to a wideness of the veins. But if someone were at once both fat and thick and yet had wide veins, this person became fat through habit [ethos], not by nature [physis]. Likewise, if a person had narrow veins but were thin, he too is not necessarily so by nature. And in the case of those suffering from extreme hunger [limanchonikoi], he says, one must assess their capacities based on these factors—that is, on the wideness and narrowness of their vessels—and not on the overall constitution of their whole body. For those who have narrow veins have little blood [oligaimoi] and cannot bear long periods of fasting; but for those whose veins are wide and who have an abundance of blood, it is possible to go without food even without harm.

The causes of what has been said are already clear, even if I do not state them, at least to those who apply their minds. But since not all do so, it is perhaps necessary to say something for their sake as well. Whatever in the blood is fatty, light, and thin becomes nourishment for the innate heat in hotter bodies, but is preserved in colder ones. And when it is filtered outside the veins, if it encounters cold parts, such as the membranes are, it congeals around them. But in the naturally hotter parts (and such, clearly, are the fleshy parts), it is both

paragraphs.content: ὅσαι μὲν οὖν ἕξεις σωμάτων εὔκρατοί τέ εἰσι φύσει καὶ πονοῦσι τὰ μέτρια, ταύτας ἀναγκαῖον εὐσάρκους γίνεσθαι, τοῦτ’ ἔστι πάντῃ συμμέτρους. ὅσαις δὲ τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν αὔταρκες, ἀπολείπεται δ’ οὐ πολλῷ τῆς ἄκρας συμμετρίας τὸ θερμὸν, αὗται πολύσαρκοι γίνονται. πολύσαρκοι δὲ καὶ ὅσαι φύσει μὲν εὔκρατοι, ῥᾳθύμως δὲ καὶ ἀπόνως βιοῦσιν. εἴρηται γὰρ δὴ καὶ τοῦτο κάλλιστα πρὸς τῶν παλαιῶν, ὡς ἐπίκτητοι φύσεις εἰσὶ τὰ ἔθη. καὶ οὐδὲν ἴσως διοίσει τοῦθ’ ἅπαξ εἰρηκότας νῦν μηκέτι διορίζεσθαι καθ’ ἕκαστον κεφάλαιον, εἴτε φύσει ψυχρότερος, εἴτ’ ἐξ ἔθους ὅδε τις ἐγένετο, ἀλλὰ τοῦτο μὲν ἀπολείπειν τοῖς ἀναγινώσκουσιν, αὐτὸν δὲ βραχυλογίας ἕνεκα τὰς οἰκείας ἑκάστῃ τῶν κράσεων ἕξεις τοῦ σώματος ἐπελθεῖν. εἰσὶ δή τινες ἰσχνοί τε ἅμα καὶ φλέβας ἔχοντες μικρὰς, ἀλλ’ εἰ τέμοις ἐξ αὐτῶν ἡντιναοῦν, προσπίπτει πιμελὴ, δῆλον ὡς ὑποπεφυκυῖα τῷ δέρματι κατὰ τὸν ἔνδον ὑμένα. σπάνιον μὲν οὖν ἐπ’ ἀνδρῶν τὸ τοιοῦτο, ἐπὶ δὲ γυναικῶν καὶ πάνυ πολλάκις εὑρισκόμενον. ἔστι γὰρ καὶ φύσεως ψυχροτέρας καὶ ἀργοτέρου βίου. τὸ τοιοῦτο γνώρισμα. πιμελὴ μὲν γὰρ ἀεὶ διὰ ψύξιν ἕξεως γίνεται· πολυσαρκία δὲ πλήθους αἵματος ἔγγονος· εὐσαρκία δὲ φύσεως εὐκράτου γνώρισμα. πάντως μὲν οὖν οἱ πολύσαρκοι καὶ τὴν πιμελὴν εὐθέως ἔχουσι πλείονα τῶν εὐκράτων· οὐ μὴν ἀνάλογος ἀεὶ ταῖς σαρξὶν ἡ πιμελὴ συναύξεται, ἀλλ’ ἔστιν ἰδεῖν τῶν παχέων τοὺς μὲν τὴν σάρκα πλείονα, τοὺς δὲ τὴν πιμελὴν ἔχοντας, ἐνίοις δὲ ὁμοίως ἄμφω συνηύξηται. τούτοις μὲν οὖν, οἷς ὁμοίως ἄμφω συνηύξηται, τοσούτῳ πλέον ὑγρόν ἐστιν ὑπὲρ τὴν εὔκρατον φύσιν, ὅσον καὶ ψυχρόν. οἷς δ’ ἡ πιμελὴ πλείων, τὸ ψυχρὸν ἐπὶ τούτων πλέον ἐστὶν, ἤπερ τὸ ὑγρόν· ὥσπερ οἷς ἡ σὰρξ πλείων, ὑγρότης μέν ἐστι τοῦ δέοντος πλείων, οὐ μὴν καὶ ψύξις.
paragraphs.openai_translation: So then, all bodily states that are by nature well-tempered and take moderate exercise must become well-fleshed—that is, proportionate in every respect. But in those for whom the moist element is sufficient while the hot falls short by not much of perfect symmetry, these become fleshy [corpulent]. And those are fleshy as well who are by nature well-tempered but live lazily and without toil. For this too has been most excellently said by the ancients: habits are acquired natures [i.e., “custom is second nature”]. And perhaps there will be no difference if, having said this once for all now, I no longer distinguish in each section whether someone became colder by nature or through habit, but leave this to the readers, while I myself, for the sake of brevity, go through the bodily dispositions [hexeis] appropriate to each of the temperaments
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is my translation of the Greek paragraph:

Therefore, those bodily conditions which are naturally well-tempered and engage in moderate exercise necessarily become well-fleshed, that is, entirely proportionate. Those in which the moisture is sufficient, and the heat falls not far short of perfect symmetry, become fleshy. Those who are naturally well-tempered but live lazily and without exertion also become fleshy. For indeed, this has been most excellently stated by the ancients, that habits become acquired natures. And perhaps it will make no difference if, having stated this once, we no longer distinguish in each chapter whether someone became colder by nature or by habit, but leave this to the readers, and for the sake of brevity, proceed to discuss the bodily conditions proper to each temperament.

There are indeed some who are both lean and have small veins, but if you cut any of these, fat appears, clearly growing beneath the skin along the inner membrane. This condition is rare in men but is found quite frequently in women. For this is characteristic of both a colder nature and a more inactive life. Fat always develops due to a cold condition; fleshiness is the offspring of an abundance of blood; well-proportioned flesh is the mark of a well-tempered nature. Therefore, fleshy people always immediately have more fat than those who are well-tempered; however, fat does not always increase proportionally with flesh, but among stout people, one can observe some having more flesh, others more fat, and in some cases both increase equally.

In those where both increase equally, the moisture exceeds the well-tempered nature by as much as the cold does. In those where fat is more abundant, the cold element exceeds more than the moist; just as in those where flesh is more abundant, there is more moisture than necessary, but not more coldness.

[Note: Terms like "well-tempered" (εὔκρατος) and "temperament" (κρᾶσις) refer to the ancient medical theory of bodily humors and their balance.]
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ὅταν γὰρ, ἐν τοῖς οἰκείοις ὅροις μένοντος τοῦ θερμοῦ, προσγένηταί τις αἵματος χρηστοῦ πλεονεξία, πολυσαρκίαν ἀναγκαῖον ἀκολουθῆσαι. τὸ δὲ, ὅσῳ χρὴ πλέον εἶναι τοῦ συμμέτρου τὸ αἷμα, μέτρῳ μὲν οὐχ οἶόν τε μηνῦσαι καὶ σταθμῷ, λόγῳ δ’ ἐγχωρεῖ διελθεῖν. ὡς ἐπειδὰν μήπω νοσῶδες μηδὲν γένηται τῷ τοῦ ζώου σώματι σύμπτωμα παχυνομένῳ, τὸ πλῆθος τῆς ὑγρότητος τηνικαῦτα τῶν τῆς ὑγείας ὅρων ἐντός ἐστιν. ἐπιδέδεικται γὰρ ἡμῖν καὶ δι’ ἄλλων, ὡς ἀναγκαῖόν ἐστιν, οὐ σμικρὸν ὑποθέσθαι πλάτος τῆς ὑγιεινῆς καταστάσεως.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For whenever, with the heat remaining within its proper bounds [i.e., the innate heat], there arises an excess of good blood, corpulence [polysarkia: fleshy overgrowth] must follow. As to how much the blood ought to exceed the proportionate amount, it is not possible to indicate it by measure or by scale, but it can be set out by rational account: namely, so long as no morbid symptom has yet occurred in the animal’s body as it grows thick/fattened, the amount of moisture is then within the limits of health. For it has also been shown by us elsewhere that it is necessary to assume no small breadth in the healthy condition [i.e., a considerable range of what counts as healthy].
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

For when, while the heat remains within its proper limits, some excess of good blood occurs, an increase in flesh mass must necessarily follow. As for how much the blood should exceed the balanced amount, it is not possible to indicate this by measure and weight, but it can be explained by reasoning. When no unhealthy symptom yet occurs in the animal's body as it grows thick, the abundance of moisture is at that point still within the bounds of health. For we have demonstrated elsewhere that it is necessary to assume that there is no small breadth [or range] in the healthy condition.

[Notes on technical terms:
- πολυσαρκία (polysarkia) = "increase in flesh mass"
- σύμμετρος (symmetros) = "balanced, proportionate"
- ὑγιεινῆς καταστάσεως (hygieinēs katastaseōs) = "healthy condition/state"]

The translation maintains the medical/philosophical context while preserving the logical structure of the argument about bodily conditions and health.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: For when an excess of good blood is added, while the innate heat remains within its proper limits, an overabundance of flesh [polysarkia] must necessarily follow. Now, how much greater than the commensurate amount the blood must be, it is not possible to declare by measure or by weight, but it is possible to explain by principle [logos]. To wit: so long as no morbid symptom has yet arisen in the body of the creature as it grows fatter, the quantity of the fluid is at that time within the bounds of health. For it has been demonstrated by us elsewhere that it is necessary to posit a considerable breadth [platos] for the healthy state.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ καὶ νῦν φαίνεται σχεδὸν ἐν ὅλῳ τῷ λόγῳ, τὴν μὲν εὔκρατόν τε καὶ μέσην φύσιν οἶον κανόνα τῶν ἄλλων ἀεὶ τιθεμένοις, ὅσαι δ’ ἐφ’ ἑκάτερα τῆσδε, δυσκράτους ἀποφαίνουσιν· ὅπερ οὐκ ἂν ἦν, εἰ μὴ τὸ μᾶλλόν τε καὶ ἧττον ἡ ὑγιεινὴ κατάστασις ἐδέχετο. ἄλλη μὲν γάρ ἐστιν ὑγιεινὴ, ἄλλη δὲ νοσώδης δυσκρασία· νοσώδης μὲν, ἡ ἐπὶ πλεῖστον ἀποκεχωρηκυῖα τῆς εὐκράτου, ὑγιεινὴ δὲ, ἡ ἐπὶ ὀλίγον. ὁρίσαι δὲ οὐδ’ ἐνταῦθα μέτρῳ καὶ σταθμῷ τὸ ποσὸν ἐγχωρεῖ· ἀλλ’ ἱκανὸν γνώρισμα τῆς ὑγιεινῆς δυσκρασίας τὸ μηδέπω μηδεμίαν ἐνέργειαν τοῦ ζώου βεβλάφθαι σαφῶς.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But even now it seems, almost throughout the whole discussion, that we invariably set the well-tempered and mean nature [eukratos, the “well-mixed” middle condition] as a kind of standard for the others, while those that incline to either side of this they declare to be dyscratic [dyskrasia, an imbalance of mixture]; which would not be so, unless the healthy condition admitted of “more and less.” For there is one kind of dyscrasia that is healthy, and another that is morbid: morbid is that which has departed the furthest from the well-tempered state, while healthy is that which has done so only a little. Yet even here it is not possible to determine the amount by measure and weight; rather, an adequate sign of the healthy dyscrasia is that none of the organism’s functions has as yet been clearly impaired.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the passage:

"But even now it appears, throughout nearly the whole discussion, that we are always setting up the well-tempered and middle nature as a sort of standard for the others, while declaring those natures that deviate to either side of this to be poorly-tempered [dyscrastic]. This would not be the case if the healthy condition did not admit of degrees of more and less. For there is one type of healthy imbalance [dyscrasia], and another that is diseased: the diseased type is that which has departed furthest from the well-tempered state, while the healthy type has departed only slightly. It is not possible here either to define the quantity by measure and weight, but a sufficient indication of a healthy imbalance is that no function of the living being has yet been clearly impaired."

[Notes on technical terms:
- "well-tempered" (εὔκρατον) and "poorly-tempered" (δυσκράτους) refer to the balance of bodily qualities in ancient medical theory
- "dyscrasia" (δυσκρασία) is a medical term referring to an imbalanced bodily state]
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ὅσον δ’ οὖν μεταξὺ τοῦ τε ἄκρως ἐνεργεῖν καὶ τοῦ βεβλάφθαι σαφῶς ἐνέργειαν ὑπάρχει, τοσοῦτο καὶ τῆς ὑγιείας τὸ πλάτος ἐστὶ καὶ τῆς κατ’ αὐτὴν δυσκρασίας. τούτῳ δ’ ἐφεξῆς ἐστιν ἡ νοσώδης δυσκρασία, ὅταν γε διὰ δυσκρασίαν νοσῇ τὸ ζῶον. οὐ γὰρ δὴ διὰ ταύτην γε μόνην, ἀλλὰ καὶ κατ’ ἄλλας διαθέσεις οὐκ ὀλίγας, ὑπὲρ ὧν ἐν τοῖς περὶ τῆς τῶν νοσημάτων διαφορᾶς λογισμοῖς ἐπὶ πλέον εἰρήσεται· νυνὶ δὲ πάλιν ἀναληπτέον τὸν ἐξ ἀρχῆς λόγον. ὡς γὰρ, τοῦ συμφύτου θερμοῦ τὴν ἀρίστην εὐκρασίαν φυλάττοντος, αὐξηθὲν τὸ ὑγρὸν ἐν ὅροις ὑγιεινοῖς οὐ πιμελώδη τὸν ἄνθρωπον, ἀλλὰ πολύσαρκον ἀποδείκνυσι, συναυξομένης μὲν ἐπ’ ὀλίγον καὶ τῆς πιμελῆς, ἀλλὰ πολλῷ πλείονι μέτρῳ τῆς σαρκός· οὕτως αὖ πάλιν, εἰ τὸ ὑγρόν τε καὶ ξηρὸν ἀκριβῆ τὴν πρὸς ἄλληλα φυλάττοι συμμετρίαν, ἧττον δ’ εἴη θερμὸς ὁ ἄνθρωπος, ἀνάγκη πιμελῶδες μᾶλλον ἢ πολύσαρκον γενέσθαι τοῦτο τὸ σῶμα. εἰ δ’ αὖ πάλιν αὐξηθείη τὸ θερμὸν, ἐν συμμετρίᾳ μενούσης τῆς ἑτέρας ἀντιθέσεως, πλέον ἀπολείπεται τούτου τὸ ζῶον πιμελῆς ἢ σαρκός· ὥσπερ, εἰ καὶ κρατήσει ποτὲ τὸ ξηρὸν, ἐν συμμετρίᾳ μενούσης τῆς τέρας ἀντιθέσεως, ἰσχνότερόν τε ἅμα καὶ σκληρότερον ἔσται τὸ σῶμα. ταῦτ’ εἴρηταί μοι, καὶ δῆλον ἤδη, ὡς οὐ λόγῳ μόνῳ ἐδείχθησαν αἱ ἁπλαῖ δυσκρασίαι τοῖς τῶν ζώων ὑπάρχουσαι σώμασιν, ἀλλὰ καὶ τὰ γνωρίσματα σαφῆ πασῶν ἐστιν· οὔκουν ἐν θερμότητι καὶ ψυχρότητι, καὶ μαλακότητι καὶ σκληρότητι μόνον, ἀλλὰ καὶ ταῖς ἄλλαις ἁπάσαις τῆς ἕξεως τοῦ ὅλου σώματος διαφοραῖς, ὧν ὑπὲρ μὲν τῆς κατὰ λεπτότητα καὶ πάχος εἴρηται νῦν, ὑπὲρ δὲ τῶν ἄλλων ἤδη λεγέσθω.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
To the extent that there is an interval between acting at the utmost and being clearly harmed by exertion, to that extent too is the breadth of health, and of the dyscrasia [imbalanced mixture] compatible with it. Next to this comes diseased dyscrasia, whenever the living creature is ill on account of a dyscrasia—for it is not on account of this alone, but also in accordance with quite a number of other dispositions, about which more will be said in the discussions on the differences of diseases; for now, we must take up again the argument from the beginning.

For just as, when the innate heat preserves the best eukrasia [well-balanced mixture], an increase of the moist element within healthy bounds does not make a person fat [pimelodes], but rather well-fleshed [polysarkos]—the fat increasing a little, but the flesh by a much greater measure—so again, if
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the passage:

"The extent that exists between peak functioning and clearly impaired functioning corresponds to the breadth of both health and its associated dyscrasia [imbalance of elements]. Following this is the diseased dyscrasia, when indeed the living being is sick due to dyscrasia. For certainly it is not due to this alone, but also due to many other conditions, about which more will be said in our discussions concerning the differences of diseases; but now we must return to our original argument.

For just as, when the innate heat maintains the best balance, an increase in moisture within healthy bounds makes a person not fatty but rather fleshy, with fat increasing a little but flesh increasing by a much greater measure; so conversely, if the moist and dry maintain precise symmetry with each other, but the person is less warm, this body necessarily becomes more fatty rather than fleshy. And if, on the other hand, the heat increases while the other opposition [wet-dry] remains in symmetry, the living being loses more fat than flesh; just as, if the dry ever dominates while the other opposition [hot-cold] remains in symmetry, the body will become both leaner and harder.

These things have been stated by me, and it is now clear that the simple dyscrasias existing in the bodies of living beings have not been demonstrated by reason alone, but there are also clear identifying marks of all of them; not only in heat and cold, and softness and hardness, but also in all other differences of the constitution of the whole body, of which those concerning thinness and thickness have now been discussed, and let us now speak about the others."

[Note: "dyscrasia" refers to an imbalance or bad mixture of the fundamental bodily qualities in ancient medical theory]
paragraphs.gemini_translation: Therefore, just as great as the range of function that exists between functioning perfectly and being clearly impaired, so great also is the breadth of health and of the dyscrasia [imbalance of humors] that falls within it. Next in order to this is the morbid dyscrasia, which occurs when the living creature becomes diseased on account of a dyscrasia. For it is not on account of this alone that it becomes diseased, but also on account of many other conditions, about which more will be said at greater length in the treatises concerning the differentiation of diseases; but for now, we must take up again the argument from the beginning. For just as, when the innate heat maintains the best eucrasia [good mixture, balance], an increase in the moist element within healthy limits renders a person not fatty but fleshy—with the fat increasing a little as well, but the flesh by a much greater measure—so, in turn, if the moist and

paragraphs.content: Δασεῖα μὲν ἡ θερμὴ καὶ ξηρὰ κρᾶσίς ἐστιν, ἀλλ’ αὕτη μὲν ἐσχάτως· μετρίως δ’ ἡ θερμὴ μὲν, σύμμετρος δὲ κατὰ τὴν ἑτέραν ἀντίθεσιν· ὥσπερ γε καὶ ἡ ξηρὰ μὲν, εὔκρατος δὲ κατὰ τὸ θερμόν τε καὶ ψυχρὸν· ἔστι γὰρ καὶ ἥδε μετρίως δασεῖα. ψιλαὶ δὲ τριχῶν αἱ ψυχραὶ πᾶσαι κράσεις, εἴτ’ οὖν ἀμέτρως ἔχοιεν ὑγρότητος, εἴτε μετρίως. ἀλλ’ ἐσχάτως μὲν ἄτριχος ἡ ψυχρὰ καὶ ὑγρὰ κρᾶσίς ἐστιν· ἔλαττον δὲ ταύτης ἡ ψυχρά τε ἅμα καὶ κατὰ τὴν ἑτέραν ἀντίθεσιν εὔκρατος· ἔτι δ’ ἔλαττον ἡ ψυχρὰ καὶ ξηρά. καίτοι δόξει τις, ὡς ἐν γῇ ξηρᾷ ταῖς πόαις ἀδύνατόν ἐστι καὶ φυῆναι, καὶ τραφῆναι, καὶ αὐξηθῆναι, τὸν αὐτὸν λόγον κᾀν τῷ δέρματι ταῖς θριξίν· ἔχει δ’ οὐχ οὕτως. γῆ μὲν γὰρ ὡς γῆ ξηρὰ λέγεται, δέρμα δὲ ὡς δέρμα. καὶ τοίνυν τὸ μὲν ἐν γῇ ξηρὸν ἄνικμον ἐσχάτως ἐστί· τὸ δ’ ἐν ἀνθρώπου σώματι, καὶ τῶν ὁμοίων ἀνθρώπῳ ζώων, οὐκ ἄνικμον, ἐπιτήδειόν τε καὶ μάλιστα πάντων εἰς γένεσιν τριχῶν. ἐκ μὲν γὰρ τῶν ὀστρακοδέρμων τε καὶ μαλακοστράκων, οἷον ὀστρέων, καὶ καράβων, καὶ καρκίνων, ὅσα τε φολιδωτὰ τῶν ζώων ἐστὶν, ὥσπερ οἱ ὄφεις, ἢ λεπιδωτὰ, καθάπερ οἱ ἰχθύες, οὐκ ἂν δύναιτο φύεσθαι θρίξ· ὄντως γάρ ἐστι τὰ τούτων δέρματα τελέως ξηρὰ δίκην ὀστράκου τινὸς ἢ πέτρας. ἐκ μέντοι τῶν μαλακοδέρμων, οἷον καὶ ἄνθρωπός ἐστιν, ὅσον περ ἂν ξηρότερόν τε καὶ θερμότερον ᾖ τὸ δέρμα, τοσόνδε μᾶλλον ἐγχωρεῖ φύεσθαι τρίχας.
paragraphs.openai_translation: The hot and dry krasis [mixture/temperament] is hairy, but this is so in the extreme; in a moderate way, the hot [krasis] that is proportionate with respect to the other opposition [i.e., moisture/dryness]; and likewise the dry [krasis] that is well-tempered [eukratos] with respect to hot and cold—for this too is moderately hairy. All the cold kraseis are smooth as to hairs [i.e., produce little hair], whether they possess moisture immoderately or moderately. But in the extreme, the cold and moist krasis is hairless; less so than this is the cold [krasis] that at the same time is well-tempered with respect to the other opposition; and still less [hairless] is the cold and dry
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

A hot and dry mixture [krasis] produces thick hair growth, especially when these qualities are extreme. Moderate hair growth occurs with a hot temperature balanced by moderation in the other opposition [wet/dry], just as a dry mixture that is well-tempered regarding hot and cold also produces moderately thick hair. All cold mixtures result in sparse hair, whether they have excessive or moderate moisture. The cold and wet mixture produces extreme hairlessness, while the cold mixture that is well-tempered in the other opposition produces somewhat less hairlessness, and the cold and dry mixture even less so.

Someone might suppose that, just as plants cannot grow, be nourished, and increase in dry earth, the same reasoning applies to hair in skin. But this is not the case. For earth is called dry as earth, but skin is called dry as skin. Thus, dryness in earth means complete absence of moisture, but dryness in human bodies and similar animals is not complete dryness - in fact, it is most conducive to hair growth.

For while hair cannot grow from shell-covered creatures and soft-shelled ones, such as oysters, crayfish, and crabs, nor from scale-covered animals like snakes, nor from fish with their scales - since their skins are truly completely dry like pottery or stone - nevertheless, in soft-skinned creatures like humans, the drier and warmer the skin is, the more readily hair can grow.

[Notes: "krasis" refers to the medical theory of bodily mixtures/temperaments in ancient medicine]
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
The hot and dry temperament [κρᾶσις] is hairy, and this one to an extreme degree. Moderately so is the temperament that is hot, but well-balanced in the other opposition [wet and dry]; just as is the one that is dry, but well-tempered with respect to the hot and the cold; for this too is moderately hairy. But all cold temperaments are bare of hair, whether they possess moisture immoderately or moderately. The cold and moist temperament, however, is hairless to an extreme degree; less so than this is the temperament that is cold and at the same time well-tempered in the other opposition; and still less so, the cold and dry.

And yet someone might think that, just as in dry earth it is impossible for grasses to sprout, be nourished, and grow, the same reasoning applies to hairs in the skin. But it is not so. For earth is called dry *as earth*, and skin *as skin*. And so, what is dry in earth is extremely devoid of moisture; but what is dry in the body of a human being, and of animals like humans, is not devoid of moisture, but is suitable—indeed, most suitable of all—for the generation of hair. For hair could not grow from the hard-shelled and soft-shelled creatures, such as oysters, lobsters, and crabs, nor from as many animals as are scaly, like snakes, or scaled, like fish. For the skins of these creatures are in fact completely dry, like some shell or rock. However, in the case of soft-skinned creatures, such as a human being is, the drier and hotter the skin may be, the more it allows for hairs to grow.

paragraphs.content: ἵνα γὰρ, ὡς ἐκεῖνοι προκαλοῦνται, τῷ τῆς γῆς ἑπώμεθα παραδείγματι, τὰς πόας οὔτ’ ἐν ξηρᾷ καὶ αὐχμώδει πάνυ γῇ φύεσθαι δυνατὸν, οὔτ’ ἐν ὑγρᾷ καὶ τελματώδει, ἀλλ’ ἐπειδὰν μὲν ἄρχηται δαπανᾶσθαι τὸ περιττὸν τῆς ὑγρότητος, ἐκφύονται τῆς γῆς· αὐξάνονται δ’ ἐπὶ πλέον, ὅταν καὶ ἥδε ξηραίνηται, μετρίως μὲν ἐν τῷ ἦρι, τάχιστα δὲ καὶ μέχρι πλείστου κατὰ τὴν ἀρχὴν τοῦ θέρους· ἀποξηραίνονται δὲ, τελέως αὐανθείσης τῆς γῆς, ἐν μέσῳ τῷ θέρει. καί σοι πάρεστιν, εἰ βούλει, καὶ νῦν, ὥσπερ που κᾀν τῷ πρὸ τούτου λόγῳ δέδεικται, τὸ μὲν ἔαρ, ὅτι τῶν ὡρῶν εὐκρατότατόν ἐστιν, εἰκάζειν εὐκράτου δέρματος φύσει, καὶ μάλιστά γε τὰ μέσα τῆς ὥρας τῆσδε· τηνικαῦτα γὰρ οὖν καὶ ἡ γῆ μέση πως ὑγρότητός τε καὶ ξηρότητός ἐστιν. ὅσα δὲ τῷ θέρει συνάπτει τῆς ἠρινῆς ὥρας, ταῦτ’ ἤδη ξηροτέραν ἔχει τοῦ συμμέτρου τὴν γῆν, ἔτι δὲ μᾶλλον ἀρχομένου θέρους.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For, since—as they bid us—we are to follow the example of the earth: grasses can grow neither in very dry and parched ground nor in wet and marshy ground; rather, when the excess of moisture begins to be used up, they sprout from the earth. They grow yet more as the earth itself dries—moderately in spring, but most rapidly and to the greatest extent at the beginning of summer; and they dry up, when the earth has been completely parched, in mid-summer. And you may, if you wish, even now—as was shown, I think, also in the preceding discussion—liken spring, since it is the most well-balanced of the seasons, to a skin that is by nature well-balanced [eukratos = of well-mixed temperament], and especially the middle part of this season; for at that time the earth too is in a sort of mean between moisture and dryness. But whatever portion of spring borders upon summer, in that period the earth is already drier than what is proportionate, and still more so when summer begins.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here's my translation of the Greek paragraph:

For, following their challenge to use the example of the earth, it is impossible for plants to grow either in completely dry and parched soil, or in wet and marshy ground, but when the excess moisture begins to be consumed, they spring forth from the earth. They grow more abundantly when this too dries, moderately in spring, but most rapidly and extensively at the beginning of summer. They wither when the earth becomes completely dried out in midsummer. And now, if you wish, as was also shown in the previous discussion, you may compare spring, being the most temperate of seasons, to the nature of well-tempered skin, especially the middle period of this season. For at that time the earth is somehow intermediate between moisture and dryness. But those parts of the spring season that border on summer already have earth that is drier than the balanced state, and even more so at the beginning of summer.

[Notes:
- εὐκράτου: "well-tempered" refers to a balanced mixture of qualities
- συμμέτρου: "balanced state" refers to the ideal proportion or measure]

The translation maintains the medical/philosophical context while preserving the original's use of natural phenomena to illustrate physiological principles.
